titleStmt.title: The arraignments, tryals and condemnations of Charles Cranburne and Robert Lowick for the horrid and execrable conspiracy to assassinate His Sacred Majesty King William in order to a French invasion of this kingdom who upon full evidence were found guilty of high-treason before His Majesty's justices of Oyer and Terminer at Westminster, and received sentence the 22d. of April, 1696, and were executed at Tyburn the 29th of the said month : in which tryals are contained all the learned arguments of the King's councel, and likewise the councel for the prisoners, upon the new act of Parliament for regulating tryals in cases of treason.
titleStmt.author: Cranburne, Charles, d. 1696.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: I Do appoint Samuel Heyrick, and IÅ¿aac Cleave, to Print the Tryals of Charles Cranburne, and Robert Lowick, and that no other perÅ¿on preÅ¿ume to Print the Å¿ame.
THe Tryals of Charnock, King, and Keys, as likewiÅ¿e of Sir John Friend, and Sir William Parkyns, and AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, are all Printed and Sold by Samuel Heyrick, and IÅ¿aac Cleave.

THE ARRAIGNMENTS, TRYALS AND CONDEMNATIONS OF Charles Cranburne, and Robert Lowick, FOR THE Horrid and Execrable ConÅ¿piracy to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate His Sacred MajeÅ¿ty King WILLIAM, in order to a French InvaÅ¿ion of this Kingdom. Who upon full Evidence were found Guilty of HIGH-TREASON, BEFORE His MajeÅ¿ty's JuÅ¿tices of Oyer and Terminer at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, and Received Sentence the 22d. of April, 1696. And were Executed at Tyburn the 29th. of the Å¿aid Month. In which Tryals are contained All the Learned Arguments of the King's Councel, and likewiÅ¿e the Councel for the PriÅ¿oners, upon the New Act of Parliament for Regulating Tryals in CaÅ¿es of TreaÅ¿on.
LONDON, Printed for Samuel Heyrick at Grays-Inn-Gate in Holbourn, and IÅ¿aac Cleave at the Star, next to Sergeants-Inn in Chancery-lane, M. DC. XCVI.

div.head: Die Martis ViceÅ¿imo primo Die Aprilis, Anno Domini, 1696. Annoque Regni Regis Gulielmi Tertii, Octavo.
At the SeÅ¿Å¿ion of Oyer and Terminer for the County of MiddleÅ¿ex, Sitting in the Court of King's-Bench at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter.
div.p: AFTER the Tryal of AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood was over, while the Jury were withdrawn to ConÅ¿ider of their Verdict, the Court proceeded in this manner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney Who will you have tryed next?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Cranburne. if your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Then, Keeper of Newgate, Å¿et Charles Cranburne to the Bar.

sp.speaker: L. C. Jâª Holt.
sp.p: You, Gentlemen, that are of Council for the PriÅ¿oner, if you have any thing to move for your Clyent, you may move it; but firÅ¿t let the PriÅ¿oner be here.

div.p: Then Charles Cranburne was brought to the Bar in Irons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Look you, Keeper. You Å¿hould take off the PriÅ¿oners Irons when they are at the Bar, for they Å¿hould Å¿tand at their eaÅ¿e when they are Tryed.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.p: My Lord, We have no InÅ¿truments here to do it juÅ¿t now.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: You may Å¿end to the Gate-HouÅ¿e and borrow InÅ¿truments.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Powel.
sp.p: It Å¿hould be done indeed; they ought to plead at eaÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well, go on Sir Bartholomew Shower.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, before Sir Bartholomew Shower enter upon his Exceptions, unleÅ¿s thoÅ¿e Exceptions of his are Å¿ome of the particulars mention'd in this Act, he muÅ¿t not do it now, after Plea pleaded, before the Tryal; but he muÅ¿t do it in ArreÅ¿t of Judgment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: It is true, Regularly; but let him uÅ¿e his own Judgment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: It is very true; the courÅ¿e has not been to allow them to move to QuaÅ¿h an Indictment for TreaÅ¿on, or Felony; but it may be done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Sure it muÅ¿t be only for Å¿uch things as they cannot take advantage of in ArreÅ¿t of Judgment after the Verdict.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: It has not been the courÅ¿e, but it may be done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Not where there is an IÅ¿Å¿ue join'd, and a Jury return'd to Try that IÅ¿Å¿ue; I believe that never was done, nor attempted.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: If there were any prejudice to the King by it, it were not fit for us to alter the courÅ¿e; but let us hear what his Exceptions are.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower
sp.p: I have Å¿everal Exceptions; Five at leaÅ¿t; one of them is within the very words of the Act, that is, improper Latin; I am Å¿ure Å¿ome of it is Å¿o.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well, let's hear what that is.

sp.speaker: Sir B Showers.
sp.p: It Å¿ays, Anno Regni dicti Domini Regis nunc Septimo, and Lewis is the laÅ¿t King mention'd before; and Å¿o here is no year of the King of England mention'd. It is a certain Rule, that Relatives muÅ¿t refer to the laÅ¿t Antecedent, and that Rule holds always, unl â¢ Å¿s there be words that accompany the Relative, which undeniably Å¿hew to what it refers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Ay; but do we call the French King Dominus Rex?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: He would have been Å¿o, if he had Å¿ucceeded in his InvaÅ¿ion, and this AÅ¿Å¿ â¢ Å¿Å¿ination.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: In every Indictment, if there be occaÅ¿ion to mention a former King, it is always nuper Rex, and Å¿uch a one, naming the name of the King, where the preÅ¿ent King's name does intervene, to prevent ConfuÅ¿ion; and Å¿o in Civil Actions it is the Å¿ame; and Å¿o it Å¿hould have been here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Ay; but I tell you, it is Dominus Rex nunc, which is Our King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: It is not Å¿aid Angliae.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: But whereever it is Dominus Rex, we underÅ¿tand it of the King of England, and no body elÅ¿e. Read the Indictment.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Necnon eundem Dominum Regem ad Mortem & finalem DeÅ¿tructionem ponere & adducere, ac Å¿ubditos Å¿uos fideles, & Liberos Homines Hujus Regni Angliae in Å¿ervitutem intolerabilem, & miÅ¿errimam Ludovico Regi Gallico Å¿ubjugare, & Mancipare, Decimo Die Februarij, Anno Regni Dicti Domini Regis, nunc Septimo, & DiverÅ¿is aliis Diebus, &c.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Can any man imagine this to be the French King?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, Your LordÅ¿hip is not to imagine one way or other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: In the Å¿tricteÅ¿t SenÅ¿e and Grammar in the World, it muÅ¿t mean King William, and no other. We do not need any imagination, when in the Å¿tricteÅ¿t ConÅ¿truction, it is plain who it refers to.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: I am Å¿ure no Grammar can make it good; nothing but a Å¿uppoÅ¿ition can help it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: When it is Å¿aid, Dictus Dominus Rex, if Sir Bartholomew Shower can find out another Dominus Rex in the Indictment, then he may make Å¿omething of his Objection; but the Dominus is only apply'd to our own King throughout.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: BeÅ¿ides, as to the Rule that Sir Bartholomew Shower mentions, it is that ad proximum Antecedens fiat Relatio niÅ¿i impediat Sententia. That's the ReÅ¿triction of the Rule, it muÅ¿t relate to the next Antecedent, unleÅ¿s the Å¿enÅ¿e would be prejudiced; but here if this ConÅ¿truction Å¿hould be, it would make this ClauÅ¿e to be no better than nonÅ¿enÅ¿e, viz. That the Subjects and Freemen of this Realm were to be brought into intolerable Slavery to Lewis the French King, Å¿uch a Day in the Seventh year of the Reign of our Lord the French King.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: We Å¿ay it is little better then NonÅ¿enÅ¿e, I am Å¿ure it is looÅ¿e, and uncertain, and not Grammar, but carries a new Form with it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: No, It is as well as it can be.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Then, My Lord, there is another Exception; it is Å¿aid, DiverÅ¿is Diebus & Vicibus tam antea quam poÅ¿tea; and then afterwards it Å¿ays, poÅ¿tea Å¿cilicet eodem Decimo Die Februarij; that is repugnant; it is as much as to Å¿ay, That upon the Tenth of February, and two days afterwards (to wit) the Å¿aid Tenth day of February; that is, after two days after the Tenth of February, viz. upon the Å¿ame Tenth day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That PoÅ¿tea is another Sentence, and relates to other maters.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: It can't in propriety of Speech be Å¿aid to be afterwards the Å¿ame day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: If Sir Bartholomew Shower remembers the Evidence that we have given this day, he will find it was in Fact Å¿o; they met on the Saturday Morning, and afterwards met again the Night of the Å¿ame Day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: There is nothing in that Objection Å¿ure, it is a Common Form, when they tell of Different matters.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Well then, if you will hear the reÅ¿t which are not of the Å¿ame nature, we Å¿hall come to what we think a fatal Exception; we Å¿ay this Indictment of High-TreaÅ¿on being againÅ¿t a Subject born, ought to have had the words in it, Contra Supremum naturalem Ligeuni Dominum Å¿uum; according to Calvin's CaÅ¿e in the 7th Report. Folâª Septimo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: It is Contra Ligeantiae Å¿uae Debitum, is it not?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p:
That won't help it, My Lord, for all that is applicable to an Alien Born: And Å¿o is the CaÅ¿e in my Lord Dyer, 144. where it is Å¿aid, That
if an Indictment of TreaÅ¿on be againÅ¿t an Alien, you muÅ¿t not put in the word naturalem, if you do, it will be faulty, becauÅ¿e he owes but a Local Allegiance to the King of England; and not a natural one. Now we Å¿ay, there are none of theÅ¿e PriÅ¿oners but are Subjects born, and the conÅ¿tant Form in Queen Elizabeth's Time, and Queen Mary's, was to put in the word Naturalem Dominum, and they cannot Å¿hew me any of thoÅ¿e PreÅ¿idents. without it. There was occaÅ¿ion in Tucker's CaÅ¿e to look into this matter, and Å¿earch all the PreÅ¿idents. I have look'd into my Lord Coke's Entries, and all the PreÅ¿idents; I have Å¿een my Lord of EÅ¿Å¿ex's Indictment, and all the others in Queen Elizabeth's Time, and thoÅ¿e of the Traitors in the Powder-Plot, and thoÅ¿e of the Regicides, and Tuckers own Indictment it Å¿elf; all along it is Naturalem Dominum Å¿uum; and the reaÅ¿on for it is, he that is Alien born, you never put in naturalem Dominum Å¿uum, becauÅ¿e he owes a double Allegiance; one Natural, to his own King under whoÅ¿e Dominion he was born, and the other Local, to the King in whoÅ¿e Dominions he reÅ¿ides, for he is bound to obÅ¿erve the Laws of the place where he lives: And if he violate them, he does break the Allegiance that he owes to the Government where he lives, upon account of the Protection he enjoys under it. But if he be born a Subject of the King of England, he has but one natural Liege-Lord; and he being an EngliÅ¿hman born, the King Å¿tands in that Relation to him, as he does to all his Native Subjects, but not to Foreigners; and therefore it was thought requiÅ¿ite to be, and has always been inÅ¿erted into Indictments of TreaÅ¿on againÅ¿t Subjects born. And my Lord, we think the very ReÅ¿olution of the Court, afterwards affirm'd in the HouÅ¿e of Lords that Revers'd Tucker's Attainder, went upon this Opinion, That the Law required naturalem Ligeum Dominum to be put in. There the Exception was, that Contra Debitum Legeanciae Å¿uae was omitted; To which it was Objected, that there was Dominum Supremum Naturalem, which was Equivalent: No, it was anÅ¿wered, both were requiÅ¿ite, becauÅ¿e every act charg'd in the Indictment ought to be laid againÅ¿t the Duty of his Allegian â¢ e. Now in Indictments of TreaÅ¿on, there are certain words that are eÅ¿Å¿ential, becauÅ¿e of their Relation between the King and his People. There are certain Forms of words, which if the conÅ¿tant practice has been to make uÅ¿e of them, the omiÅ¿Å¿ion is an Error. ThoÅ¿e uÅ¿ual Forms ought to be obÅ¿erv'd, and the want of them will be a fatal Exception; Å¿o we think it would be in this CaÅ¿e, as much as if the word proditorie had been left out; or as if in a CaÅ¿e of Felony and Burglary, the words FelonicÃ¨, and Burglariter had been left out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: My Lord, we take the Practice, and PreÅ¿idents to be the Rule of Law in the CaÅ¿e; and I have look'd over a great many PreÅ¿idents, beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e that Sir Bartholomew Shower has Cited; and I never Å¿aw any one PreÅ¿ident of an Indictment of TreaÅ¿on againÅ¿t a Subject born without the word naturalem; and all the CaÅ¿es cited by Sir Bartholomew Shower are full in the point. Courteer's CaÅ¿e in my Lord Hobbart, 271. where 'tis Å¿aid, that if there be an Indictment againÅ¿t a Subject born, it muÅ¿t be Contra naturalem Dominum; if againÅ¿t an Alien, naturalem muÅ¿t be left out. To Å¿ay Contra Legiantiae Å¿uae Debuum will not do, it is not enough, for that may be Å¿aid againÅ¿t an Alien, becauÅ¿e he owes a Local Allegiance, tho' not a Natural one. And I take it, upon this difference, this Indictment is not good.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I do not know how far you will think it proper to enter into this matter before the Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney. I think you had as good Å¿peak to it now as at another time; tho' I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s it is not Å¿o proper in point of practice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
Well, My Lord, then we will Å¿peak to it now. The Objection is, That the word naturalem Dominum is not in the Indictment; which they Å¿ay is contrary to the uÅ¿ual Form: As to the PreÅ¿idents, there are a great many where it has been, and I am Å¿ure a great many where it has not been; and I am Å¿ure for this Six, Seven or Eight Years laÅ¿t paÅ¿t, it has always been omitted: And, with SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to your LordÅ¿hip, it is not at all neceÅ¿Å¿ary: If there be words in the indictment which Å¿hew, that what he did was againÅ¿t the Duty of his Allegiance to his Lawful and Undoubted Lord (which are the
words in this Indictment). It is true, if he be not a Subject born, naturalem cannot be in, becauÅ¿e that is contradictory to the Obedience which he owes, for it is not a Natural Obedience that he owes, but a Local; but if a Man be a Subject born, and commits TreaÅ¿on againÅ¿t the Allegiance that he ows, that is againÅ¿t his natural Allegiance; for whatÅ¿oever he does againÅ¿t his Allegiance, he does againÅ¿t his natural Allegiance, and Å¿o there's no need to put in the word naturalem; becauÅ¿e he owes no other Allegiance but that; it is Å¿ufficient if that be put in which Å¿hews its being againÅ¿t his Allegiance. If they could Å¿hew that a Subject born has two Allegiances, one that is natural, and the other that is not natural; then if you would proÅ¿ecute him you muÅ¿t Å¿hew, whether it was againÅ¿t his Natural, or againÅ¿t his other Allegiance. But when he has none but a natural Allegiance, certainly againÅ¿t his Allegiance, without putting in natural, will be well enough. It is true where there is no natural Allegiance, it muÅ¿t be wrong if you put it in, becauÅ¿e you put in that Allegiance which he does not owe; but where he is a Subject born, to put in natural Liege-Lord there is no ground at all for it; there are words enow that Å¿hew it was againÅ¿t his Allegiance to his Lawful and Undoubted Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Look you, Sir Bartholomew Shower, how does it appear, that theÅ¿e Men are Subjects born? The matter you go upon does not appear upon the Indictment, and you are not to go off from that.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Every man is preÅ¿um'd to be Å¿o, unleÅ¿s the contrary appears.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: You quote Calvin's CaÅ¿e, and the other CaÅ¿es that are there put; thoÅ¿e are all CaÅ¿es of Aliens; there is Dr. Lopez's CaÅ¿e; He being an Alien comes into England, and commits High TreaÅ¿on: Why, Å¿ay they, how Å¿hall we Indict this man? We cannot Å¿ay it is Contra Naturalem Dominam Å¿uam; for he owes no Natural Allegiance to the Queen of England; How Å¿hall we do to frame a good Indictment againÅ¿t this man? They conÅ¿idered of this; and they Å¿aid it will be a good Indictment, to charge him with High-TreaÅ¿on, or any one elÅ¿e, leaving out the word Naturalem: For if it appear he has committed an Offence againÅ¿t the Laws of the Kingdom, and againÅ¿t the Duty of his Allegiance, which is High-TreaÅ¿on, that's enough. Now as to Tucker's CaÅ¿e, it was ReverÅ¿ed for want of the ConcluÅ¿ion, contra Debitum Ligeantiae Å¿uae. ThoÅ¿e words are material; for let the Offence be never Å¿o much againÅ¿t the PerÅ¿on of the King, as to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate him, or Levy War againÅ¿t him, yet Å¿till if it be not againÅ¿t the Duty of his Allegiance, as it cannot be if he owes him none, it is not High-TreaÅ¿on. And therefore if it be againÅ¿t his Allegiance, whether that Allegiance be Natural, or Local, it is all one, it's enough to make it High-TreaÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: In that CaÅ¿e in Dyer, they Å¿hew where it was a fault to put the word in, but they can Å¿hew no CaÅ¿e where it has been adjudged to be a fault to leave the word out.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: No doubt it would be a fault to have that in, Contra Naturalem Dominum Å¿uum, where there is only a Local Allegiance due.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: How does it appear whether it is the one or the other that is due?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: It is no matter whether the one or the other do appear, it is High-TreaÅ¿on be it the one or the other, if it be againÅ¿t the Duty of his Allegiance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: SuppoÅ¿e an Indictment againÅ¿t an Alien were, Contra Naturalem Dominum.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: That would be ill, becauÅ¿e then you had laid it more Å¿pecially, and otherwiÅ¿e than really it is, and reÅ¿trained it where you ought not to do it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: How then, my Lord, Å¿hall it appear that he only ow'd a Local Obedience?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: It may be given in Evidence, That he is an Alien born.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: He may plead it in abatement to the Indictment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: He ought to be acquitted, for you have Indicted him of a Crime againÅ¿t his Natural Allegiance, when he owes no Å¿uch. But Allegiance generally comprehends all Å¿orts of Allegiance, Natural, and Local.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: How then, my Lord, come all the Lawyers of all Ages to put in thoÅ¿e words in Indictments of High TreaÅ¿on againÅ¿t Subjects born?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: No, I have Å¿een Abundance of Precidents, that have only Crontra Legiaentiae Å¿uae Debitum Generally, and for the moÅ¿t part are; for Allegiance is the Genus, and if that be Å¿uggeÅ¿ted, all the Å¿pecies are contain'd under that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Well, have they any more.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Yes, we have more.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Well, you Å¿hall have them all in time. My Lord, here is another Objection, and that's this; here is one fact that they have laid, and that is the Second Overt Act in this Indictment, that they ConÅ¿ented and Agreed that Fourty Men (Whereof theÅ¿e Four were to be Four) but do not lay it to be done TrayterouÅ¿ly. They Å¿ay ConÅ¿enÅ¿erunt Agreaverunt & AÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿erunt, but not proditorie; and I never Å¿aw an Indictment that laid an expreÅ¿s Overt Act, without Repeating the Word again. If your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es, the Words in the Indictment are thus; as to the firÅ¿t Overt Act, it is laid in this manner, Et ad execrabilem AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inationem illam exequend. at Å¿uch a time and Å¿uch a place proditorie tractaverunt propoÅ¿uerunt & ConÅ¿ultaverunt devijs modis & medijs et &c, and then comes this which we except againÅ¿t; & ConÅ¿enÅ¿erunt Agreaverunt & AÅ¿Å¿encerunt quod Quadraginta Homines &c. Now this is a plain DiÅ¿tinct Act, and there is no proditorie to it; and if ever they can Å¿hew me any Indictment, in which an Overt Act was laid, of which they gave any Evidence, and it had not the Word proditorie in it I am very much miÅ¿taken. I am Å¿ure, I never Å¿aw any Å¿uch. And it is not enough to Å¿ay, that the nature of the thing is Å¿uch, as that it cannot but be a TreaÅ¿onable Act; but they muÅ¿t alledg it to be Å¿o, by the expreÅ¿s uÅ¿e of that Word, which the Law has appointed to expreÅ¿s this Crime by. In the CaÅ¿e of an Indictment for Felony, if it be not Å¿aid Felony, it is not good. They are not to DiÅ¿cribe that by Circumlocution, which is a particular Crime fixt by Law, they muÅ¿t uÅ¿e the Verba Artis, the terms of Art, and no other: If your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es it may be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Let it be red if you pleaÅ¿e; but take it in EngliÅ¿h, and it is no more then this, they Did TrayterouÅ¿ly CompaÅ¿s the Death of the King, and for that purpoÅ¿s they Did TrayterouÅ¿ly meet, and ConÅ¿ult about the ways and means, and did ConÅ¿ent and agree that Fourty Men, &c.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Reads, Et ad exrcrabilem Horrendam & DeteÅ¿tabilem AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inationem Anglice AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination & Interfectionem illam Citus exequendum & anno ac DiverÅ¿is alijs Diebus & Vicibus apud parochiam predictam in Comitatu predicto proditorie tractaverunt, propoÅ¿uerunt & ConÅ¿ultaverunt de vijs modis & medijs ac Tempore & Loco ubi quando qualiter & quomodo Dictum Dominum Regem Å¿ic ex Incidijs facilius Interficerent.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: There is an end of that, now go on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No, Sir Bartholomew, you miÅ¿take there is no end of it, that's done at the Å¿ame time with that which followes.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: No it it is not the Å¿ame Overt Act; but let him go on.

p.hi: Et ConÅ¿enÅ¿erunt Agreaverunt & EÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿erunt quod quadraginta Homines EqueÅ¿tres.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Well, you need read no further for our Objection. We Å¿ay, there wants the Word Proditorie: For there are two Overt Acts, the one is, that they TrayerouÅ¿ly did ConÅ¿ult of the ways and means, how to Kill the King, and that Overt Act we agree to be well laid: But then it Å¿ays they ConÅ¿ented, and agreed that there Å¿hould be Forty Men, whereof theÅ¿e Four Å¿hould be Four, but does not Å¿ay they TrayterouÅ¿ly agreed are not theÅ¿e DiÅ¿tinct Acts?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phillips.
sp.p: Surely, My Lord, they are diÅ¿tinct Acts, for this part of the Indictment upon which Sir Bartholomew grounds his Objection, is that Overt Act of which the LiÅ¿t in Mr. Rookwood's caÅ¿e was urg'd by the Kings Councel, and agreed by the Court to be an Evidence.

div.p: Then the Jury againÅ¿t Mr. Rookwood came in, and deliver'd in their Verdict, as it is in his Tryal, then afterwards the Court went on thus.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, the Objection is, that proditorie is not in Incerted into that Particular ClauÅ¿e of the Indictment, which Å¿hews there Particular agrement that there Å¿hould be Forty Men, whereof the Four nam'd in the Indictment were to be Four. Now your LordÅ¿hip ObÅ¿erves how the Indictment Runs, it is for CompaÅ¿Å¿ing and Imagining the Death and DeÅ¿truction of the King; and it Å¿etsforth for this purpoÅ¿e, that to effect this CompaÅ¿Å¿ing and Imagination, they Proditorie tractaverunt & ConÅ¿ultaverunt de vijs medijs & Modis, how they Å¿hould Kill the King. Now that which Imediatley follows after is, the particular method, and means that were agreed upon, that is, that there Å¿hould be Forty Men. Now this is the Å¿trangeÅ¿t Å¿uggeÅ¿tion that ever was, when we have Å¿et forth, that TrayterouÅ¿ly they Did Å¿o agree of the ways and means, and then Å¿et forth the particular means that here muÅ¿t be proditorie again to that. This is Å¿uch a ConÅ¿truction as I cannot but admire how it could come into any ones head. It is part of the Å¿entence; for the other part, as we have laid it, is not Compleat before: It may be it might be Å¿ufficient without Å¿etting forth the particular way, and means, but when it is Å¿et forth, it is part of the Å¿entence, and Refers to the firÅ¿t beginning.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Aye Å¿ure Å¿o it does.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I cannot tell what they would have unleÅ¿s they would have us repeat the Word proditorie in every line.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Or before every Verb.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: No, but I think it ought to be repeated at every Overt Act.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: If your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es, after that they have Å¿et forth that this was the particular method and way agreed upon at their ConÅ¿ultation, that Forty HorÅ¿emen or thereabouts Å¿hould go about it, of which the PerÅ¿ons Indicted were to be Four, it goes on, & Quilibet eorum proditorie Å¿uper Å¿e SuÅ¿cepit eÅ¿Å¿e unum there it is put in, and it appears to be as particular as poÅ¿Å¿ible can be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Sir Bartholomew Shower Å¿ays, that when we have Alledg'd that they did TrayterouÅ¿ly treat, propoÅ¿e, and ConÅ¿ult of the means and ways of Killing the King, there we have done the Å¿entence and made that one Overt Act. Now how is the Å¿entence done? The next Word is a Conjunction Copulative, & ConÅ¿enÅ¿erunt, &c. And what is the uÅ¿e of a Conjunction Copulative? But to Convey the Force of the Words in a Former Å¿entence to the Å¿entence following, and to prevent the Repetition of every Word in the Å¿ubÅ¿equent Å¿entence that was in the precedent: But it is plain, they are both one and the Å¿ame Overt Act, and theÅ¿e Å¿ubÅ¿equent Words are only an Explanation, more particularly of the Overt Act Å¿etforth in the precedent Words.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: In anÅ¿wer to that, that has been Å¿aid, if they Å¿hew me any precedent, where an Indictment has been for High TreaÅ¿on, Å¿etting forth Å¿everal Overt Acts, and not the Word proditorie Å¿et to every Overt Act, then they anÅ¿wer my Objection. If the Word Quod had come in, that would have made them diÅ¿tinct to be Å¿ure; and I think they are as diÅ¿tinct Acts now; Å¿uppoÅ¿e they had Concluded at the end of the word Interficerent that had been a good Overt Act, I am Å¿ure they will agree that: And if it be Å¿o, then the other is a good Overt Act too. For it is a diÅ¿tinct thing from that which was a perfect Å¿entence before; and it either requires a likewiÅ¿e or the Word Proditorie muÅ¿t be repeated. They have not Å¿o much as Å¿aid Å¿imiliter ConÅ¿enterunt or Å¿imili modo ther is an (&) indeed, but that does not Å¿o Couple the Å¿entences together, as not to make them diÅ¿tinct Acts. There are Å¿everal ets thorough the whole Indictment, but that does not, as Mr. Cowper would have it, Couple altogether to make one Overt Act.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p:
My Lord, if what Mr. Cowper Å¿ays be allow'd, (viz.) that the & makes it one intire Sentence, then there is no Overt Act at all, for
after the TreaÅ¿on alledg'd and the ClauÅ¿e is coupled to another by an Et, and conÅ¿equently by Mr. Cowper's way of arguing the whole Indictment is but one intire Sentence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: I do not underÅ¿tand your meaning as to that, they tell you Preditore it is alledg'd to the ConÅ¿ulting, Contriving and Agreeing, then they tell you what was the Å¿ubject Matter of that Contrivance and Agreement to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, and in order to that they agreed there Å¿hould be 40 Men, is not that good enough, without Proditore to every line.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: No it is not Å¿aid in Ordine ad, there is no Å¿uch thing; but onely they did ConÅ¿ult of the Ways and Means, and did Agree that 40 HorÅ¿emen Å¿hould do it, and afterwards did agree to provide HorÅ¿es and InÅ¿truments of War. Now that being with a Qoud que, they Å¿ay makes a new Overt Act; but I cannot underÅ¿tand why Qoud que is not as much a Copulative as Et, and the one Å¿hould not have the Å¿ame effect as the other.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: FirÅ¿t it tells you there was a ConÅ¿ult and Agreement to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, and for the AccompliÅ¿hing of the Å¿aid AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, afterwards eiÅ¿dem die & Anno Proditorie Tractaverunt & ConÅ¿ultaverunt de vijs & modis, how they Å¿hould Kill the King.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: That is one Overt Act, Å¿ay we, and there you Å¿hould Å¿top.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Et ConÅ¿enÅ¿erunt & Agreaverunt quod quadraginta Homines, &c. it is all at the Å¿ame time, and muÅ¿t be Intended the Å¿ame ConÅ¿ult and Contrivance; that they ConÅ¿ulted of the ways and means, and then agreed Å¿o many Men Å¿hould be provided.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: No, My Lord, we Å¿ay that is another Overt Act.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: It Å¿eems to me to be a Å¿pecifying, and particulariÅ¿ing the way and means, that they had ConÅ¿ulted of, and Concluded on.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower,
sp.p: If it had been a Å¿pecifying, it had been much better to put in either then and there, or that this was the ReÅ¿ult of the ConÅ¿ultation.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: It do's Å¿eem to me Å¿o, that it was the ReÅ¿ult of the ConÅ¿ultation, and it is well enough.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: If this be well enough, I do not know, what will not be well enough.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: You had better have Å¿av'd theÅ¿e kind of Exceptions 'till the Tryal was over.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: But, my Lord, if there be one Overt Act ill laid, I Å¿ubmit it whether they can give any Evidence of that Overt Act.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: No doubt of that they cannot; but we think it is as well laid as it could be laid.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Truly I am not well Å¿atified, that it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary after you have laid the ProditoriÃ¨, as to the particular TreaÅ¿on, to lay it again to the Overt Act. For the Overt Act is but Evidence of the TreaÅ¿on: The TreaÅ¿on it Å¿elf lies in the CompaÅ¿Å¿ing which is an Act of the mind.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p:
You cannot Indict a Man of TreaÅ¿on for AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inating or Killing the King; but you muÅ¿t in every Å¿uch CaÅ¿e frame the Indictment upon the Article for CompaÅ¿Å¿ing and Imagining the Death of the King; which muÅ¿t be laid to be done TrayterouÅ¿ly. Then when afterwards you Å¿ay the PerÅ¿on accuÅ¿ed did Wound him, or ImpriÅ¿on him, or ConÅ¿ult and agree to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate Him, or did actually AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate Him, theÅ¿e are but Å¿o many Overt Acts of CompaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death, and you having firÅ¿t Å¿aid that he did Proditorie compaÅ¿s and imagin the King's Death, you have thereby Å¿hewn that you charge him with a greater Offence then Felony (which my Lord Coke Å¿ays is the uÅ¿e of the word Proditorie,) and that being thus done, I do not apprehend it to be neceÅ¿Å¿ary that you Å¿hould ad Proditorie to all the reÅ¿t of the following particularsâª for they
are only external DiÅ¿coveries of the inward TreaÅ¿on; and more properly deemed to be lividence of the TreaÅ¿on, than to be the TreaÅ¿on it Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: The TreaÅ¿on is conÅ¿ummate in the Intention, beÅ¿ides the words of the Statute make that the TreaÅ¿on, not the Overt Act, that is but Evidence, and Å¿o it was held, (not upon this Exception, but upon the reaÅ¿on that my Lord Speaks off) in CaÅ¿e of the Regecides of King Charles the FirÅ¿t, That the Indictment Å¿hould not be for Killing the King, but for CompaÅ¿Å¿ing and Imagining his Death; and the Killing was alledged as an Overt Act.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: It muÅ¿t be Å¿o if it were for levying of War.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: MoÅ¿t true, for levying the War is the TreaÅ¿on, but in this CaÅ¿e we think it is no exception.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Thent let us have the Fifth.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, here is another Thing. It is a QueÅ¿tion whether there be any Overt Act preÅ¿ented by the Jury at all. The Indictment Å¿ay's, Juratores pro Domino Rege preÅ¿entant, that they as falÅ¿e Traytors did CompaÅ¿s the Death of the King, and the Slaughter of his Subjects, and they did Meet, and ConÅ¿ult, and Agree how to do it, Et ijdem ChriÅ¿topherus Knightley and the reÅ¿t, to fulfil their Å¿aid Trayterous Intentions and Imaginations did. Afterwards the tenth of February Buy Arms and HorÅ¿es. Now our Objection is, that it does not appear, that any one of theÅ¿e Overt Acts are the preÅ¿entment of the Jury; With SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion they ought to have begun it again, either with a Quodque, or Å¿omething that Å¿hould have referred it to the firÅ¿t, Juratores preÅ¿entant, or elÅ¿e they muÅ¿t have begun quite again, with a Juratores Ulterius preÅ¿entant, and not have coupled them as this is with an ulterius preÅ¿entant, and not have Coupled them as this is with an Et. The moÅ¿t forms begin with an Ulterius preÅ¿entant, but here we find no Overt Act is Å¿o Introduced. They might preÅ¿ent part, and not preÅ¿ent the other part, for any thing that does appear. Every Thing ought to be laid poÅ¿itively, as the Jury's. Dictum, it may be onely the Clerks Å¿aying, and not the Juries, for any thing that do's appear. Your LordÅ¿hip remembers the CaÅ¿e of the King and Trobridge: Trobridge upon a Writ of Error to ReverÅ¿e a Judgment for Erecting and Continuing a Cottage againÅ¿t the form of the Statute, now Contra formam Statuti was in the begining of the Indictment; but not in the ConcluÅ¿ion; to the Erecting, but not to the Continuing. And tho there was there Juratores, Ulterius dicunt, it was not Å¿uper Sacramentum Å¿uum, and they did not Å¿ay, he did continue it againÅ¿t the Statute, and there being no formal, preÅ¿entment that he maintain'd the Cottage notwithÅ¿tanding the Act, Et did no Å¿o Couple it to the firÅ¿t part, as to make it a good preÅ¿entment. So we Å¿ay in this CaÅ¿e, this is a fault, and different from all the Common Forms; there ought to be a Direct preÅ¿entment of each Overt Act, and not Coupled by an Et. For Et will not do it; for it is a DiÅ¿tinct Overt Act every one, and Å¿hould have been Et Quod ConÅ¿ultaverunt, quodque Agreaverunt, that a certain number Å¿hould do Å¿o and Å¿o, and to be Å¿ure, it Å¿hould have been Å¿o at the laÅ¿t Overt Act, which is onely, Et ijdem ChriÅ¿tophorus Knightley did Buy Arms and HorÅ¿es. Now this laÅ¿t Et, being a looÅ¿e Conjunction Copulative, in common Sence ought to Refer to that which they had agreed upon, for that is laÅ¿t mention'd there, and the natural Sence leads thither, and not to the begining of the Bill Juratores preÅ¿entant quod.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: I Å¿hall not trouble your LordÅ¿hip further, they ought to have put in a Quodque, or an Ulterius preÅ¿entant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where would you have the Quodque, or the Æ²lterius preÅ¿entant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Either to every Overt Act, or at leaÅ¿t to that laÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Ge.
sp.p:
The Indictment Å¿etsforth, that they Commited Å¿uch, and Å¿uch TreaÅ¿on; Their objection is that Quodque is not put in to every overt Act, and
our AnÅ¿wer is, That the firÅ¿t Quod governs all that relates to that TreaÅ¿on. It may be if there were two diÅ¿tinct TreaÅ¿ons in the Indictment, when you come to Å¿et forth the Second TreaÅ¿on, you Å¿hould Å¿ay Juratores ulterius preÅ¿entant the Second TreaÅ¿on; but the Overt Acts to prove the Å¿ame TreaÅ¿on, are all parts of that TreaÅ¿on, and make but one Species of TreaÅ¿on, which is the imagining the Death of the King. There's the TreaÅ¿on; and to bring it to paÅ¿s, they did Å¿o, and Å¿o: This, my Lord, muÅ¿t be part of the finding of the Jury as well as the TreaÅ¿on it Å¿elf, of which theÅ¿e are the Overt Acts. But then if you will lay the levying of War in the Å¿ame Indictment, then it may be you muÅ¿t Å¿ay Juratores ulterius preÅ¿entant quod, &c. But it had been a Å¿trange AbÅ¿urdity to Å¿ay, Juratores ulterius preÅ¿entant Å¿uch and Å¿uch Overt Acts: For the Overt Act is not a further Indictment, but only a Å¿etting forth that which is Evidence, upon which they found the Indictment for TreaÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What the Indictment Å¿ays, is a direct Affirmation as can be all along in the PreÅ¿entment of the Jury, that the PriÅ¿oner and others did compaÅ¿s and imagine the Death of the King, and to bring it about, they did conÅ¿ult together, and did agree to make uÅ¿e of Å¿uch and Å¿uch Means, and were to have a Party of 40 Men, and they bought Arms and HorÅ¿es. Now it does not repeat quodque, or ulterius preÅ¿entant quod, to every one of thoÅ¿e Sentences, that they did Å¿o and Å¿o, and that they did Å¿o and Å¿o. Now I would feign know the Difference between Å¿aying, and they did Å¿uch a thing, and Å¿aying, and that they did Å¿uch a thing. That's all the Difference that they think to overturn this Indictment for. The omitting of a Juratores ulterius preÅ¿entant, certainly is nothing; for the firÅ¿t PreÅ¿entment runs through the whole Indictment, and there does not need an Æ²lterius.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Certainly there Å¿hould have been a Quodque at leaÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: No indeed, I think it is better as it is, than as you would have had it; becauÅ¿e the firÅ¿t Quod goes through the whole, That in Order thereunto he did Å¿o and Å¿o, would you have it Å¿aid & quod in Order thereunto he did Å¿o and Å¿o, but that may be good SenÅ¿e, I think it is not Å¿o good as the other. This Indictment is for one Å¿ort of TreaÅ¿on, and that is, for compaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death of the King; and it is, I think, more proper to have but one Quod, than to have more; for it makes the whole Indictment more entire. As to the Juratores ulterius preÅ¿entant, that is never proper, where the Species of TreaÅ¿on is the Å¿ame: For indeed if there had been two diÅ¿tinct TreaÅ¿ons, the one for compaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death of the King, and the other for levying of War, in that CaÅ¿e you muÅ¿t bring it in by ulterius preÅ¿entant: becauÅ¿e they are two Å¿everal Offences, tho' comprisd in one Bill, and they are in Law as two Indictments. And Å¿o it is in the CaÅ¿e that you mention'd of Cottages: It is one Offence to erect a Cottage, and another Offence to continue a Cottage, and they are to have Å¿everal PuniÅ¿hments; and becauÅ¿e they were jumbled them both together in one Indictment, that Indictment was held to be nought: For by Law, the Indictment for erecting a Cottage, ought to conclude contra formam Statuti, and then the Jury muÅ¿t begin again, & ulterius preÅ¿entant quod the Cottage was continu'd againÅ¿t the Form of the Statute; becauÅ¿e they are Å¿everal Offences. But here the High TreaÅ¿on is but one, and the Å¿ame Offence, and the other things are but Overt Acts to manifeÅ¿t this TreaÅ¿on, the compaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death of the King; and truly I think it is better as it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: I have Å¿een Å¿everal Precedents of Indictments, where the Å¿everal Overt Acts were to the Å¿ame High TreaÅ¿on, but Å¿till they had each an ulterius preÅ¿entant.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I believe it is hard to find many Indictments in the Å¿ame Words: I am Å¿ure all are not.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Is it not as great an Affirmation to Å¿ay, and they did Å¿uch a thing, as to Å¿ay, and that they did Å¿uch a thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: I cannot reconcile it to my ReaÅ¿on, but it Å¿hould be as good SenÅ¿e without that as with.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: In a long Deed it begins, This Indenture witneÅ¿Å¿eth, that the Party granted Å¿o and Å¿o, and the Party Covenants thus and thus; and Å¿o it goes on commonly, without renewing the Word That to the Å¿ubÅ¿equent ClauÅ¿es: But yet the firÅ¿t ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion [This Indenture witneÅ¿Å¿eth, that] governs the whole Deed, tho' it be many Skins of Parchment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: If you begin with an Indenture, you begin, That it witneÅ¿Å¿eth Å¿o, and Å¿o, without Renewing, unleÅ¿s it be a very diÅ¿tinct Thing.

sp.speaker: S. B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, we think that Similitude makes for us. A. B. Covenants Å¿o and Å¿o in a Conveyance, and then further, that Å¿o and Å¿o.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: But there you reÅ¿train that in the Beginning of the Covenant to every Particular in that Covenant.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Will your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿e to call the Jury now?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Have you a Mind to go on with the Trial, or to go to Dinner?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I believe your LordÅ¿hip can try but one more to Night, and that may be as well after Dinner as before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well then, adjourn till 5 a Clock, and in the mean time, you Keeper, knock off the PriÅ¿oners Fetters.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.p: They Å¿hall, my Lord.

div.p: Then the Court adjourned till 5 a Clock in the Afternoon, it being then about 3.
PoÅ¿t Meridiem, the 21Å¿t of April, 96. The Court returned, and was reÅ¿um'd about 6 in the Evening.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Keeper of Newgate, bring Charles Cranburne to the Bar (which was done) Charles Cranburne, hold up thy Hand. (which he did) ThoÅ¿e good Men that you Å¿hall hear called and perÅ¿onally appear, are to paÅ¿s between our Sovereign Lord the King and you, upon Tryal of your Life and Death; and therefore if you will challenge them or any of them, your time is to Å¿peak unto them as they come to the Book to be Å¿worn, and before they be Å¿worn.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly deÅ¿ire I may have Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Aye, Aye. He had them.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Where is George Ford?

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Vouz Avez.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.
sp.p: I challenge him.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.
sp.p: I challenge him.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.
sp.p: I challenge him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: If your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es, thoÅ¿e that were of the laÅ¿t Jury I hope Å¿hall not be call'd of this Jury: This PriÅ¿oner being tryed upon the Å¿ame Indictment the laÅ¿t was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: If they be not, it Å¿hall be in EaÅ¿e to them, but it is not in favour of you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: We humbly conceive, having given their Verdict upon the Å¿ame Indictment, they are not Å¿uch indifferent PerÅ¿ons, as the Law intends they Å¿hould be, and think it is good reaÅ¿on they Å¿hould not Å¿erve upon this Jury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: What tho' it be upon the Å¿ame Indictment, the Evidence is not the Å¿ame; for they are diÅ¿tinct Offences.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: I do not know whether it be a good CauÅ¿e of Challenge, but Å¿ubmit it to your LordÅ¿hip.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well, you may doubt of it if you pleaÅ¿e, and try the Exception.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.
sp.p: I challenge him.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.
sp.p: I challenge him.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.
sp.p: I challenge him; he was upon the laÅ¿t Jury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: That is no reaÅ¿on; Will you challenge him peremptorily?

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Look upon the PriÅ¿oner, Sir. You Å¿hall well and truly try, and true Deliverance make between our Sovereign Lord the King and the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, whom you Å¿hall have in Charge, and a true Verdict give, according to your Evidence, Å¿o help you God.

sp.speaker: Cranburne.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.

p.hi: The Names of the Twelve Sworn were theÅ¿e,

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.

sp.speaker: Cryer. Oyez.
sp.p: If any one can inform my Lords the King's JuÅ¿tices of Oyer and Terminer, the King's Serjeant, or the King's Attorney General, before this InqueÅ¿t be taken of the High-TreaÅ¿on, whereof the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar Å¿tands indicted, let them come forth and they Å¿hall be heard; for now the PriÅ¿oner Å¿tands at the Bar upon his Deliverance: And als others that are bound by Recognizance to give Evidence againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, let them come forth, and give their Evidence, or elÅ¿e they forfeit their Recognizance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, Do you think we Å¿hall be able to try the other to Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: That is according as this holds, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: I Å¿peak it for the EaÅ¿e of the Jury, that they might be diÅ¿patch'd, and not attend another Day.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I doubt we cannot try any more than this to Night.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p:
Well it is no great Matter, it will be but a Morningâª Work; it may be too great a StreÅ¿s and a Hurry to do any more to Night; and therefore we will diÅ¿charge the Jury for to Night, thoÅ¿e of them that
are not Å¿worn; but we will be here to Morrow-Morning by Å¿even a Clock; and therefore pray Gentlemen attend early.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p:
Charles Cranburne, Hold up thy Hand, (which he did) You that are Å¿worn, look upon the PriÅ¿oner, and hearken to his CauÅ¿e: He Å¿tands indicted by the Name of Charles Cranburne, late of the PariÅ¿h of St. Paul Covent-Garden, in the County of MiddleÅ¿ex, Yeoman, for that he with ChriÅ¿topher Knightly, late of the Å¿ame PariÅ¿h and County, Gentleman, Robert Lowick, late of the Å¿ame PariÅ¿h and County, Gentleman, and AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, late of the Å¿ame PariÅ¿h and County Gentleman, the Fear of God in their Hearts not having, nor weighing the Duty of their Allegiance, but being mov'd and Å¿educ'd by the InÅ¿tigation of the Devil, againÅ¿t the moÅ¿t Serene, moÅ¿t IlluÅ¿trious, moÅ¿t Clement, and moÅ¿t Excellent Prince, our Sovereign Lord, William the third, by the Grace of God, of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, King, Defender of the Faith, &c. their Å¿upreme, true, rightful, lawful, and undoubted Lord, the Cordial Love, and the true and due Obedience, Fidelity and Allegiance which every faithful Subject of our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, towards him our Å¿aid Lord the King Å¿hou'd bear, and of Right ought to bear, withdrawing and wholly to extinguiÅ¿h intending and contriving, and with all their Strength, purpoÅ¿ing, deÅ¿igning and conÅ¿piring the Government of this Kingdom of England, under him our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, of Right, duly, happily, and very well eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, altogether to Å¿ubvert, change and alter; as alÅ¿o our Å¿aid Lord the King to Death and final DeÅ¿truction to put and bring, and his faithful Subjects, and the Freemen of this Kingdom of England into intolerable and moÅ¿t miÅ¿erable Slavery to Lewis the French King to Å¿ubjugate and enthral, the 10th day of Feb. in the 7th year of the Reign of our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, and divers other days and times, as well before as after, at the PariÅ¿h of St. Paul Covent-Garden aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, FalÅ¿ly, MaliciouÅ¿ly, DeviliÅ¿hly, and TrayterouÅ¿ly did compaÅ¿s, imagine and contrive, purpoÅ¿e, deÅ¿ign and intend our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, to Å¿lay, kill and murder, and a miÅ¿erable Slaughter among the faithful Subjects of him our Å¿aid Lord the King, throughout this whole Kingdom of England to make and cauÅ¿e, and their Å¿aid moÅ¿t Wicked, Impious, and DeviliÅ¿h TreaÅ¿ons, and Trayterous CompaÅ¿Å¿ings, Contrivances and PurpoÅ¿es aforeÅ¿aid, to fulfil, perfect, and bring to effect, they the Å¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightley, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburne, and very many other falÅ¿e Traytors, to the Jurors unknown. Afterwards, to wit the Å¿ame Tenth Day of February, in the Year aboveÅ¿aid, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, and divers other Days and Times, as well before as after, there and elÅ¿ewhere in the Å¿ame County, falÅ¿ely, malitiouÅ¿ly, adviÅ¿edly, Å¿ecretly, traiterouÅ¿ly, and with Force and Arms, did meet, propoÅ¿e, treat, conÅ¿ult, conÅ¿ent, and agree, him our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, by lying in wait and wile, to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate, Kill and Murder: And that execrable, horrid, and deteÅ¿table AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination and Killing the Å¿ooner to execute and perpetrate. Afterwards, to wit, the Å¿ame Day and Year, and divers other Days and Times, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, traiterouÅ¿ly did treat, propoÅ¿e, and conÅ¿ult of the Ways, Manner, and Means, and the Time and Place where, when, how, and in what manner our Å¿aid Lord the King Å¿o by lying in wait the more eaÅ¿ily they might kill: And did conÅ¿ent, agree, and aÅ¿Å¿ent, that Forty HorÅ¿emen, or thereabouts (of whom they the Å¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightley, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburne, Å¿hould be four, and every one of them trayterouÅ¿ly took upon himÅ¿elf to be one) with Guns, Muskets, and PiÅ¿tols, charged with Gun-powder and Leaden-Bullets, and with Swords, Rapiers, and other Weapons, armed, Å¿hould lie in wait, and be in ambuÅ¿h our Å¿aid Lord the King, in his Coach being, when he Å¿hould go abroad, to Å¿et upon; and that a certain and competent Number of thoÅ¿e Men Å¿o arm'd, upon the Guards of our Å¿aid
Lord the King, then attending him, and being with him, Å¿hould Å¿et upon, and them Å¿hould fight with, and overcome; whilÅ¿t others of the Å¿ame Men Å¿o armed, him our Å¿aid Lord the King Å¿hould AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate, Slay, Kill and Murder. And they the Å¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightley, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburne, the TreaÅ¿ons, and all their treaÅ¿onable Intentions, PurpoÅ¿es and Contrivances aforeÅ¿aid to execute, perform, fulfil, and bring to effect. Afterwards, (to wit) the aforeÅ¿aid Tenth Day of February, in the Seventh Year aboveÅ¿aid, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, divers HorÅ¿es, and very many Arms, Guns, PiÅ¿tols, Swords and Rapiers, and other Weapons, Ammunition, and Warlike things, and Military InÅ¿truments, falÅ¿ely, malitiouÅ¿ly, Å¿ecretly and traiterouÅ¿ly did obtain, buy, gather together, and procure; and to be bought, obtain'd, gather'd together, and procur'd, did cauÅ¿e with that intent them in and about the deteÅ¿table, horrid, and execrable AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, Killing, and Murder of our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, as aforeÅ¿aid, to be us'd, imploy'd, and beÅ¿tow'd: And the Å¿ame PremiÅ¿Å¿es the more Å¿afely and certainly to execute, do, and perpetrate, the aforeÅ¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightley, with one Edward King (late of High-TreaÅ¿on in contriving and conÅ¿piring the Death of our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, duly convicted and attainted) by the ConÅ¿ent and AÅ¿Å¿ent of divers of the Traytors and ConÅ¿pirators aforeÅ¿aid, the aforeÅ¿aid Tenth Day of February, in the Seventh Year aboveÅ¿aid, trayterouÅ¿ly did go, and came unto the place propoÅ¿ed, where Å¿uch intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, Killing, and Murder of our Å¿aid Lord the King, by lying in wait, Å¿hould be done, perpetrated and committed, to view, Å¿ee, and obÅ¿erve the conveniency and fitneÅ¿s of the Å¿ame place for Å¿uch lying in Wair, AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and Killing, there to be done, perpetrated, and committed; and that place Å¿o being Å¿een and obÅ¿erved. Afterwards, to wit, the Å¿ame Day and Year, his ObÅ¿ervations thereof to Å¿everal of the Å¿aid Traytors and ConÅ¿pirators did relate and impart, to wit, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid; and the Å¿aid Charles Cranburne the Å¿ame Day and Year there, in order the Å¿ame execrable, horrid, and deteÅ¿table AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination and Killing of our Å¿aid Lord the King, by the Traytors and ConÅ¿pirators aforeÅ¿aid, the more readily and boldly to execute, perpetrate, and commit, adviÅ¿edly, knowingly, and trayterouÅ¿ly did bear and carry among divers of thoÅ¿e Traytors and ConÅ¿pirators forward and backward from Å¿ome to others of them, a LiÅ¿t of the Names of divers Men of them who were deÅ¿igned and appointed our Å¿aid Lord the King, Å¿o as aforeÅ¿aid, by lying in wait, to Kill and Murder, againÅ¿t the Duty of his Allegiance, and againÅ¿t the Peace of our Å¿aid Sovereign Lord the King that now is, his Crown and Dignity, and againÅ¿t the Form of the Statute in that CaÅ¿e made and provided. Upon this Indictment he hath been arraigned, and thereunto hath pleaded Not guilty, and for his Tryal hath put himÅ¿elf upon God and the Countrey, which Countrey you are; your Charge is to inquire whether he be guilty of the High-TreaÅ¿on whereof he Å¿tands indicted, or not guilty: If you find him guilty, you are to inquire what Goods or Chattels, Lands or Tenements, he had at the time of the High-TreaÅ¿on committed, or at any time Å¿ince: If you find him not guilty, you are to enquire whether he fled for it: If you find that he fled for it, you are to inquire of his Goods and Chattels as if you find him guilty: If you find him not guilty, nor that he did fly for it, you are to Å¿ay Å¿o and no more; and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Montague.
sp.p:
May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury; This is an Indictment of High-TreaÅ¿on that is found againÅ¿t four PerÅ¿ons; but the particular TreaÅ¿on againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar is for compaÅ¿Å¿ing and imagining the Death of the King, and endeavouring to Å¿ubvert the Government, and enÅ¿lave the Nation to Lewis the French King: And the Indictment Å¿ets forth, that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar did for this purpoÅ¿e meet and conÅ¿ult with Å¿everal falÅ¿e Traytors to the King and Government,
of the way, manner, and means how, and the time and place when and where to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King; and at length they agreed that forty HorÅ¿emen Å¿hould go together, and Å¿et upon the King in his Coach, as he returned from Hunting; Å¿ome to attack the Coach, while others Å¿et upon the Guards. The Indictment does further charge him with getting HorÅ¿es and Arms, and particularly with carrying a LiÅ¿t of the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inators from one to another. TheÅ¿e are the particular things charged in the Indictment, and to this Indictment he has pleaded Not guilty; if we prove the Fact, Gentlemen, we don't doubt your JuÅ¿tice.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury; The PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, Charles Cranburne, is indicted for High-TreaÅ¿on, in compaÅ¿Å¿ing and imagining the Death of the King. Gentlemen, the Overt Acts laid in the Indictment to prove the PriÅ¿oner guilty are, That he was at Å¿everal Meetings and ConÅ¿ultations about the manner of putting this DeÅ¿ign in Execution; at which Meetings it was agreed, That there Å¿hould be about forty HorÅ¿emen in Number prepare'd, and arm'd for that purpoÅ¿e, and they did provide HorÅ¿es and Arms for that very thing, and did agree to put it in execution.

Gentlemen, the Evidence that you will hear produc'd againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar will be of this Nature. You will hear from the WitneÅ¿Å¿es, that about ChriÅ¿tmas laÅ¿t, or the Beginning of January, Sir George Barclay did come over from France from the late King James, to whom he was an Officer in his Guards, with a CommiÅ¿Å¿ion for attacking the Prince of Orange, or levying War upon his PerÅ¿on. He came over about that time, and Å¿everal Troopers of the late King James's Guards, to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him in that barbarous ConÅ¿piracy. When Sir George Barclay came over, he did acquaint with this DeÅ¿ign Å¿everal PerÅ¿ons in England, that he thought proper to be Accomplices with him in it, particularly Capt. Porter, Mr. Chernock, Sir William Parkyns, and Å¿everal others whoÅ¿e Names you will hear of, and they had Å¿everal Meetings about it the Beginning of February, at Capt. Porter's Lodgings, at the Nagg's Head in Covent-Garden, at the Sun Tavern in the Strand, at the Globe Tavern in Hatton-Garden, and Å¿everal other Places where they conÅ¿ulted in what manner they might attempt and accompliÅ¿h this Bloody DeÅ¿ign.

Gentlemen, you will hear, that at theÅ¿e Meetings it was propos'd, that they Å¿hould do it by AmbuÅ¿cade as the King came from Richmond a Hunting, whither he uÅ¿ed to go upon Saturdays: Others were for doing it on this Å¿ide the Water. And Å¿o their Opinions being divided, it was thought neceÅ¿Å¿ary to find out and Å¿ettle which was the beÅ¿t Place; and in order thereunto they employ'd Capt. Porter, Mr. Knightly, and Mr. King (who was executed) to view the Ground, and accordingly they went, and pitch'd upon the Lane between Brentford and Turnam Green for this purpoÅ¿e, as the moÅ¿t convenient Place: And having Å¿o done, they came back and gave an Account to thoÅ¿e that had appointed to meet 'em, to hear the SucceÅ¿s of their Expedition, to the Nagg's Head in Covent-Garden, and in that Place you will find by the Evidence, that thoÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons, who were the Heads of the ConÅ¿piracy, undertook to find their Å¿everal Proportions of Men, for whom they would undertake that would go with them, and be concern'd in this DeÅ¿ign. Sir George Barclay was to furniÅ¿h about 20. He had the Command of the Troopers that came from France, and thoÅ¿e other Officers that came thence, were under him. Capt. Porter was to furniÅ¿h 7, Chernock was to furniÅ¿h 8, Sir William Parkyns was to furniÅ¿h 5 HorÅ¿es and 3 Men, and, I think, Lowick was to furniÅ¿h Å¿ome more: In the whole Number they reckon'd there Å¿hould be about 40.

It will appear, Gentlemen, that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, Mr. Cranburn was one of the Men that Capt. Porter undertook to get, and engage in this DeÅ¿ign; and accordingly Capt. Porter did acquaint Mr. Cranburn with it; and he did undertake to be one, and to be ready to go with him, and be concerned in this AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination. You will find he was acquainted with it about the 14th of February, the Day before the firÅ¿t time that they intended
to aÅ¿Å¿ault the King: Then he did undertake and agree to prepare himÅ¿elf againÅ¿t the next Day. The next Day which was the 15th of February, they had Å¿everal Meetings, and they were making Preparation in order to go out. It happen'd by great Providence his MajeÅ¿ty did not go abroad that Day, and thereupon they diÅ¿pers'd themÅ¿elves; but they had Meetings afterwards, at which Meetings the PriÅ¿oner was preÅ¿ent, with Capt. Porter, Mr. PendergraÅ¿s, La Rue, and Å¿everal others that were concerned in the ConÅ¿piracy, particularly the 21Å¿t of February, the Day before the Å¿econd time they were to have put this in Execution. Capt. Porter being at the Sun-Tavern, with Å¿everal other Gentlemen, and they reÅ¿olving to have it executed the next Day, if the King went abroad. Capt. Porter Å¿ent for Cranburn, and Keys that was executed, and Kendrick and Sherborn, four of thoÅ¿e that he had undertaken for, (of whom, I Å¿ay, Cranburne, the Prifoner at the Bar, was one) and then he acquainted 'em that they were reÅ¿olv'd to go on with it the next Day. And then they agreed to be in a readineÅ¿s accordingly. The next Day the PriÅ¿oner with Å¿ome others met at Mr. Porter's, where they were preparing to go out and attack the King, and they had Å¿everal DiÅ¿courÅ¿es about the Ways and and Means of doing it; and particularly Capt. Porter at that time Å¿aid, that he had a very good Gun that held about 6 or 8 Bullets, and that Mr. PendergraÅ¿s was to have, who was to attack the Coach, and Å¿hoot into the Coach: Mr. Cranburne was there preÅ¿ent at that time, and Mr. Cranburne was employ'd particularly by Capt. Porter to carry a LiÅ¿t that Porter writ of the Names of Å¿everal Men that were to act in it under him, and this he was to carry to Chernock. Porter writ it and gave it him, and he carry'd it with Directions to bring it back with the LiÅ¿t of the Names of Mr. Chernock's Men. Cranburne did accordingly at that time carry the LiÅ¿t of the Names to Capt. Chernock, and brought it back with an additional LiÅ¿t, from Capt. Chernock, of his Men.

At that time you will hear farther, when Cranburne brought the LiÅ¿t, he brought an Account that he heard the King did certainly go abroad: for Mr. Chernock had Intelligence Å¿o from Chambers, who lay at KenÅ¿ington to get Intelligence: At which there was very great rejoycing among all that were preÅ¿ent at that time, hoping they Å¿hould have an Opportunity to put this execrable DeÅ¿ign in Execution; and Å¿o they prepar'd all of 'em to go out. There were Å¿everal Inns in Turnam Green and Brentford, and thereabouts, and they were to be plac'd, two or three in an Inn, that they might be ready to get together when time Å¿hould Å¿erve. It happen'd the King did not go abroad that Day neither, there being Å¿ome DiÅ¿covery of this DeÅ¿ign, and Å¿o they did diÅ¿perÅ¿e themÅ¿elves, as apprehending it was diÅ¿cover'd.

Gentlemen, it will appear by Å¿everal WitneÅ¿Å¿es, that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar was engag'd in this Horrid TreaÅ¿onable DeÅ¿ign, and was to have acted a Part in it. We will call our WitneÅ¿Å¿es that will make the Particulars out to you, and we do not queÅ¿tion but you'll do what is right. FirÅ¿t, call Capt. Porter, (who was Å¿worn.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, if you pleaÅ¿e, Capt. Porter, give the Court and the Jury an Account what you know of this wicked intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and what Å¿hare the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar had in it.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p:
My Lord, before this wicked AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was on foot, the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, Mr. Cranburne, was employ'd by me to buy Arms. I us'd to give him Money to go to the Brokers to buy Arms at Å¿econdhand, and he brought a Sword-Cutler to me, of whom I bought about 20 Swords. And when Sir George Barclay came into England, and this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s was reÅ¿olv'd upon, I acquainted him with the DeÅ¿ign, and promis'd to mount him. He never was at any of the Meetings with Capt. Chernock, Sir George Barclay, or Sir William Parkyns; but he went to look for a HorÅ¿e, and was ready both Saturdays to go along with me. On Saturday the 22d I Å¿ent him with a MeÅ¿Å¿age to Sir William Parkyns, for the Note for the two HorÅ¿es, which he had promiÅ¿ed me to furniÅ¿h me with, out of his five that he was to furniÅ¿h; he came back again, and told me that there was
a MeÅ¿Å¿enger came and Å¿aid that the King did go out, and he knew where to have the two HorÅ¿es; that Mr. Charnock was affraid we Å¿hould not have the full number of Men, and deÅ¿ired me to Å¿end him the Names of my Men; I did write a LiÅ¿t of the Names of my Men, and I went afterwards to the Blew-PoÅ¿ts in Spring-Garden, whither he was to come to me; he did Å¿o, and he brought back the LiÅ¿t of my Men, with the LiÅ¿t of Mr. Charnocks Men written underneath it, and at the Å¿ame time News was brought that the King did not go abroad that day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: You Å¿ay, that before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was Å¿et on foot, you imployed him to buy Arms and HorÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: Cap. Porter.
sp.p: My Lord, I acquainted him with it the Friday before the firÅ¿t Saturday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: You Å¿aid before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination you imployed him to buy Arms: When was that?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I Å¿aid before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was on foot I imployed him to buy Arms. I told him I was to be a Captain in Colonel Parker's Regiment, and promiÅ¿ed to make him my Quarter-MaÅ¿ter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: How long a go was this? was it a week before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was on foot?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: He has known of my being a Captain in Colonel Parker's Regiment this two years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I do doubt my Lord, he does not diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the times when he bought the Arms, and when the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he does now; I miÅ¿apprehended him at firÅ¿t, and thought he Å¿aid he had imployed him to buy Arms a week before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was on foot; but he Å¿ays it was a longer time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I deÅ¿ire my Lord, he may be askt what time he bought Arms before this AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination: When was the laÅ¿t time he bought Arms?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: It was Å¿everal Month before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was it within a year before it.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes I believe it was within a year. I gave him Å¿everal times Money for that purpoÅ¿e, in all above Ten pounds, and he told me one with another, he had bought ten CaÅ¿e of PiÅ¿tols, and kept them in the HouÅ¿e till there were occaÅ¿ion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long ago is it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I believe about a year; within a year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did you firÅ¿t acquaint him with the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: PreÅ¿ently after Sir George Barclay acquainted me with it, I Å¿ent to him, to deÅ¿ire him to get the PiÅ¿tols clean and ready.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you tell him of the DeÅ¿ign?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I told him there was a DeÅ¿ign on foot, and I would tell him more when I Å¿aw him next; and I deÅ¿ir'd him to get the Swords from the Sword-Cutlers, and the PiÅ¿tols clean and ready. And I met him afterwards, and told him of the DeÅ¿ign, and that we intended to do it on Saturday the fifteenth; and he ingaged to be ready and make one. On the Friday before the twenty Å¿econd he went with me to the Cock-pit, and there we met with one Mr. Gun, and I askt him if he knew where any good Hackney-HorÅ¿es might be had? He Å¿aid he believed he did; and I Å¿ent Cranburn with him, and he came back, and told me he had found two or three out in Bloomsbury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Look ye Capt. Porter, you muÅ¿t not Å¿peak Å¿o faÅ¿t, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to underÅ¿tand Å¿o much matter as you deliver without diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing of times. You Å¿aid, that Å¿ome long time before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was on foot you Å¿ent him to buy Arms, for what purpoÅ¿e were thoÅ¿e Arms?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, he has told youâ

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Pray let me hear it from him again.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I Å¿ay, My Lord, he knew of my being a Captain in Colonel Parker's Regiment this two years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: But what were thoÅ¿e Arms for that he bought?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: To be ready againÅ¿t King James landed, which was deÅ¿igned Å¿everal times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Why now you make the matter clear to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, that is not the thing we go upon, that is but introductory to the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s that we are now a Trying. Therefore we deÅ¿ire to know of him: Captain Porter, when did you firÅ¿t acquaint Cranburn of the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination of the King?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: As Å¿oon as Sir George Barclay acquainted me with it, and deÅ¿ired me to get what Men I could to effect it, I Å¿ent for Cranburn to my Lodgings in Norfolk-Å¿treet, and he came to me one Morning; and I told him there was a deÅ¿ign on foot, and I would tell him more of it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When was it that Sir George Barclay acquainted you with it?

sp.speaker: Cap. Porter.
sp.p: About the latter end of January.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And what Å¿aid he to it when you acquainted him with it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: He did agree to go with me, and I promiÅ¿ed to furniÅ¿h him with HorÅ¿e and Arms; and on Friday before the fifteenth I Å¿ent him with three CaÅ¿e of PiÅ¿tols to Sir William Parkins, to furniÅ¿h the three Men he was to mount with his own HorÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Who was to have thoÅ¿e three CaÅ¿e of PiÅ¿tols.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Sir William Parkins was, and he carried them to Sir William Parkin's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long was this, do you Å¿ay, before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was to have been?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: It was Friday before the fifteenth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That was before the firÅ¿t time that it was to have been done.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes, and Friday before the laÅ¿t, I Å¿ent him to look after the HorÅ¿es that Gunn Å¿aid he believed he could help me to, and he came to me to the Sun-Tavern in the Strand, and told me he and Jeffrey Gunn had found three HorÅ¿es in Bloomsbury, and I came out of the Room where I was with Sir George Barclay and others, and there was Kendrick and Keys, and Cranburn, and I told them we were reÅ¿olved to put it in execution the next day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Well pray what diÅ¿courÅ¿e had you with him the next day?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: The next day, the 22d. he came to my Lodging at Maiden-Lane, and I Å¿ent him to Sir William Parkins for a Note for the two HorÅ¿es, that I was to mount of his: He came back and told me he knew where to have them, and that Captain Chernock was affraid we Å¿hould not have our Compliment of Men, and deÅ¿ired me to Å¿end him an account what Men I could bring, which I did by Mr. Cranburn, and being to go to the Blew-poÅ¿ts, Ordered him to bring it to me thither, and he did bring it back to me to the Blew-posts with Captain Chernocks LiÅ¿t underneath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Captain Porter, was there any body preÅ¿ent when you Å¿ent the LiÅ¿t, and the PriÅ¿oner brought it back to you?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes there was Mr. La Rue, and Captain PendergraÅ¿s, and Mr. King, I know of none elÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray do you remember what Healths were drank after you heard the King was not to go abroad?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I don't Remember what Healths were drank that day particularly, but whether it were ThurÅ¿day or Friday (I cannot tell particularly the day) We drank a Health to the Å¿queezing of the Rotten Orange upon the next Saturday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who was preÅ¿ent that day when that Health was Drank.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Mr. Cranburn was there preÅ¿ent at that time, and did Drink the Health.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cooper.
sp.p: Pray Sir did he meet you by appointment on Saturday the 15th, or was it by accident?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: By appointment, as all the reÅ¿t did, to get ready as all the reÅ¿t did, to go upon the DeÅ¿ign; and Å¿o it was both Days.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: If they have done with Mr. Porter we would ask him a QueÅ¿tion or two for the PriÅ¿oner: We deÅ¿ire to know when it was that thoÅ¿e Arms were bought, that he talks of: For we muÅ¿t acknowledge that Mr. Cranburn heretofore went upon Å¿everal MeÅ¿Å¿ages for Capt. Porter, When was that buying of Arms?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I tell you I cannot exactly tell the Month.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: Do you remember the Year?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I believe it was leÅ¿s than a Year before the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was on Foot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: If you remember Sir, it was a Month before Col. Parker was put in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: It was Å¿everal times, I cannot tell the particular times.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord I deÅ¿ire to know when he firÅ¿t Communicated this DeÅ¿ign to Mr. Cranburn, and who was by, and where was it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter,
sp.p: I told you I Å¿ent for Mr. Cranburn one Day in the Week before the 15th, and he came to me at my Lodging in Norfolk-Street, and I acquainted him that Sir George Barclay was come, and there was Å¿uch a DeÅ¿ign on Foot; and I deÅ¿ired him to get thoÅ¿e PiÅ¿tols that he had of mine ready, and cleaned, that they might be ready for the Execution.

sp.speaker: Sir. B. Shower.
sp.p: What Day was that?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: One Day in the Week before the 15th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: Did you ever name Sir George Barclay to me in your Life?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes I did, I told you he was come from France.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: Where was that, at Mr.âin Norfolk-Street, where I lay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: Who was by?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: No body but my Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Upon what occaÅ¿ion did you meet there?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I Å¿ent for him to my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long had Sir George Barclay been in Town, before that time?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I cannot tell the time when he came to Town.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long was it after he came to Town before you Å¿aw him? Had you Å¿een him a Week or a Fortnight before? Pray recollect your Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I told you that the firÅ¿t time I heard of him, was the latter end of January; Capt. Charnock told me he was come, but I was then Sick of the Gout.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Now then I would deÅ¿ire to know, who was by upon the Friday before the 22th at the Sun Tavern in the Strand, when you and Mr. Cranburn were there?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I did tell you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: I deÅ¿ire to know, whether there was any body beÅ¿ides Mr. Cranburn, Kendrick, and Keys?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Sir, I will tell you all I can remember; I was in one Room with Sir George Barclay, and there was Sir William Parkins, Capt. Charnock, and my Å¿elf; and afterwards I went into another Room, where there was Kenrick, and Cranburn, and Keys, and Jeffrey Gunn came in afterwards, I remember no body elÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Was not Gun there when you firÅ¿t came in?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: To the beÅ¿t of my Remembrance, he came in afterwards.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, this may be a very material part of our Defence, and therefore we muÅ¿t inquire a little the more into it. Mr. Porter is pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿ay, that he was in a Room with Sir George Barclay, and Charnock, and Sir William Parkins; and he came out into another Room, where was Mr. Cranburn, Kendrick and Keys: and there he Å¿ays, after he had been there Å¿ome time, Gunn came in, I deÅ¿ire to know, whether Gunn was there when he firÅ¿t came in?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: To the beÅ¿t of my Remembrance, he came in afterwards, but I cannot poÅ¿itively tell, for I was in and out Å¿everal times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: At the time that you Communicated this DeÅ¿ign to Mr. Cranburn, what Å¿aid he to you?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: When I firÅ¿t Communicated the thing to him, I told him there was a thing on Foot for the Service of King James, and deÅ¿ired him to go along with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: What kind of Service did you tell him it was?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: He asked me, what kind of Service it was? I told him Sir George Barclay was come over, and I told the whole DeÅ¿ign of the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination of the Prince of Orange, that it was intended to take him off, as he came from Richmond from Hunting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: And pray what did Mr. Cranburn Å¿ay to you?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: He Å¿aid he would be ready to go along with me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: You Å¿ay, you Å¿ent by him Three CaÅ¿e of PiÅ¿tols to Sir William Parkins, at that time did you tell him for what DeÅ¿ign thoÅ¿e PiÅ¿tols were?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I told him, they were for the 3 Men that Sir William Parkins was to Mount upon 3 of his 5 HorÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: Did you Å¿peak to me to carry thoÅ¿e PiÅ¿tols to Sir William Parkins?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I think Å¿o, to the beÅ¿t of my Remembrance I ordered you my Å¿elf to carry them.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Captain Porter, I deÅ¿ire you to recollect your Å¿elf, and tell us plainly, whether the DeÅ¿ign was Communicated to Mr. Cranburn before the 15th.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Certainly Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Are you Å¿ure of it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I am Å¿ure of it.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: I ask you, becauÅ¿e you know what has been Å¿aid upon this OccaÅ¿ion in other Trials.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Where did you write the Note, that you Å¿ay you Å¿ent to Sir William Parkins? Was that Note Sealed or was it not?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I did not tell you that I writ a Note.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: You Swore that you wrote a Note, and Å¿ent it by me to Sir William Parkins for 2 HorÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I Å¿aid no Å¿uch thing Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Look you Capt. Porter, let him ask you any QueÅ¿tions, and if they be proper anÅ¿wer them, and let not his affirmations, or miÅ¿takes provoke you to be angry.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I Å¿aid, I Å¿ent him to Sir William Parkins, for a Note to have the HorÅ¿es from Mr. Lewis.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Did you Å¿end him with a Letter, or was it a MeÅ¿Å¿age by word of Mouth?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I did Å¿end him by word of Mouth, for a Note.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen obÅ¿erve the Evidence, Sir William Parkins was to give a Note for 2 HorÅ¿es, and Capt. Porter Å¿ent Cranburn for the Note.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
