sp.p: The QueÅ¿tion therefore that I ask, is, VVhether he Å¿ent a Letter for the Note, or whether by word of Mouth?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I Å¿ent by word of Mouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: Pray will you tell the Court what you Å¿aid upon the 22th to Mr. PendergraÅ¿s and me, after you came down from the Blew-PoÅ¿ts leaning upon the Rail.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I dont remember a word of it, for I cannot remember every word that I have Å¿poken.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: If you can remember one particular, Å¿ure you can remember another. If you can't remember this, how came you to remember any part of the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e that happened at the Blew-PoÅ¿ts.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: BecauÅ¿e that was material to this BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, for I had very Å¿oon after a particular occaÅ¿ion to recollect it upon the breaking out of the Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: Pray what Hour was it this Saturday the 15th that you Communicated this DeÅ¿ign to me?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I cannot tell what Hour, but I Å¿ay you met me at the Blew-PoÅ¿ts Saturday the 15th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: You Å¿ay, you Communicated it to me the 15th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He Å¿ays he Communicated it to you, before the 15th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cranburn.
sp.p: I deÅ¿ire to know where he was the 14th.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I Å¿ay, one Day before the 15th, in that Week I Å¿ent for you to come to my Lodgings, and you did come, and there I Communicated it to you.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Sir. I was not at your Lodgings that Week.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: What Day of the Week?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I cannot be poÅ¿itive whether it was ThurÅ¿day, or Friday, or what Day; but one Day in that Week it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: You ought to be poÅ¿itive when it was.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I do tell you as near as I can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: With Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, my Lord, he ought to be poÅ¿itive one way or other.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Nay, I don't Å¿ee that he ought to be poÅ¿itive to a Day; he may be Å¿o if he can.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Pray what Day did you Å¿ay you Å¿ent me to Sir George Barclay?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I do not Å¿ay that I ever Å¿ent you to Sir George Barclay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Can you take upon you to Å¿ay, That he was at your Lodgings that Week before the 15th?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: To the beÅ¿t of my Knowledge it was one Day that Week.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: To the beÅ¿t of your Knowledge: Are you Å¿ure of it?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Speak as certainly as you can.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Indeed, I believe Å¿o, it was before the 15th. I am Å¿ure, I think, it was within Three or Four Days after Sir George Barclay had acquainted me with it, I Å¿ent to the PriÅ¿oner to come to me to my Lodgings, at Mrs.âin Norfolk-Å¿treet, and acquainted him with it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: And when you acquainted him with it, What did you tell him? What Part was he to act in it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I told him, I would have him go along with me, and that I had Å¿et him down for one of my Party, and would provide him HorÅ¿e and Arms; and he did agree to go along with me.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Mr. Webber, Pray let me Å¿ee Chernock's Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sh. Buckingham.
sp.p: Why, Sir Bartholomew, is the Tryal any Evidence?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Mr. Sheriff, I know what uÅ¿e I can make of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Will you ask him any more QueÅ¿tions?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol Gen.
sp.p: Then Swear M. De la Rue.
Pray, Sir, give the Court, and the Jury, an Account what you know of the intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and what Share the PriÅ¿oner had in it.

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p:
It is too long a Story to tell you all that I know of this Matter; but, if you pleaÅ¿e, I will tell you what concerns the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar. I am heartily Å¿orry that I have occaÅ¿ion to appear againÅ¿t him, as I wou'd be truly againÅ¿t any Body: But Å¿ince I am here upon my Oath, I muÅ¿t declare the Truth, and nothing but the Truth; and I hope I Å¿hall not declare any thing but what is Truth. Upon Saturday, the 15th. of February, the Day that the DeÅ¿ign was to have been put in execution againÅ¿t His MajeÅ¿ty, and all that were in the Coach with him, and againÅ¿t his Guards, I went to Mr. Chernock's Lodgings in Norfolk-Å¿treet, to inform my Å¿elf, whether they reÅ¿olved on that Day to go out upon the DeÅ¿ign; and I found by Mr. Chernock that they did reÅ¿olve it, and I Å¿tay'd there a while, till Å¿uch time as Mr. Chambers came in; I did not know whence he came then, but, as I was informed afterwards, he came from KenÅ¿ington to Mr. Chernock, and his Boots were dirty; and Mr Chernock told me he had Å¿ent a MeÅ¿Å¿enger to Mr. Porter, And, Å¿ays he, if you will Å¿tay a little time, I Å¿hall have an AnÅ¿wer. The MeÅ¿Å¿enger came back, and told him, That Capt. Porter din'd at the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in Spring-Garden. I did not go to Dine with him, but went home, where I Å¿aw Mr. King at my Lodging, who told me, that the King did not go out that Day. I told him, I heard he did not: I found by Mr. Chamber's coming back, and that we had no notice from Mr. Chernock, that it was concluded the King did not go out as it was Å¿uppoÅ¿ed he Å¿hou'd have gone. When I had din'd at my Lodging, I went to the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in Spring-Garden, to
Mr. Porter, and there were Four, or Five, or Six People with him; there was one Mr. Sherborn, and Mr. Kendrick, and Two People that I never Å¿aw before, and another PerÅ¿on, but I can't tell now who he was. When we had been there a little while, comes in this unfortunate Man at the Bar, Mr. Cranburn; I don't know where he had been; but by his coming in Å¿o late, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e he had not din'd, and he ordered the Drawer to get him Å¿ome CoÅ¿telets. This is all that I can Å¿ay as to that Day: I had Å¿een Captain Porter twice or thrice between that, and the 22d. and he deÅ¿ired me to be at home on Friday Night, between Eight and Nine, and he wou'd Å¿end to me: He did Å¿end, and I was from home. But when I came, I was informed his Servant had been to Å¿peak with me; and in the Morning, about Eight or Nine a Clock, Saturday the 22d. he Å¿ent his Servant to me to tell me his MaÅ¿ter would Å¿peak with me at his Lodgings. I went to his Lodgings, and he then lay in Maiden-Lane, at one Brown's a Surgeon's: When I came in, he was in Bed; and he told me in French, Tonts Parties Å¿ont PreÅ¿ts. All Parties are ready. I underÅ¿tood all along that there were Three Parties to be engag'd; one to attack the King's Coach, and the Two others the Guards; Sir George Barclay was to head the firÅ¿t, and Porter and Rookwood, the reÅ¿t. Mr. Porter aroÅ¿e and dreÅ¿s'd himÅ¿elf, and in came Mr. Cranburn; and Mr. Porter went out to him into the Dining-Room, and what he Å¿aid I can't tell: But Å¿oon after came in PendergraÅ¿s, Mr. Key, and Mr King, and then he takes Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Who took that?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: Capt. Porter took Pen, Ink, and Paper, and writes down a LiÅ¿t of his Party, and puts me down firÅ¿t. Mr. PendergraÅ¿s ask'd me if I was the Captain, and I made him Å¿ome AnÅ¿wer, but what in particular I cannot tell; I think I told him, I knew of the thing before the moÅ¿t did: But I can remember particularly that LiÅ¿t was given to Mr. Cranburn, to carry to Mr. Chernock; upon what Account it was, I cannot tell; but I concluded, that Mr. Chernock was to be acquainted with thoÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons that Porter was Å¿ure off: And Mr. Porter at that time told me that he was diÅ¿appointed of Å¿ome People, and deÅ¿ired me to get him Å¿ome other Men in their rooms; and he Å¿ent particularly to one that Mr. King propoÅ¿ed; and I did go, and brought him to the Blue-PoÅ¿ts, where Captain Porter told me he was to Dine; and the Gentleman I went to, told me he wou'd meet me at the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in Spring-Garden. When I came back to Mr. Porter's Lodgings, Mr. Porter, and Mr. PendergraÅ¿s, and Mr. Oldfield, and I, went in a Coach to the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in Spring-Garden; and when we had been there a little while, Mr. Cranburn came back to give an Account of the Errand Mr. Porter had Å¿ent him upon, and he brings this LiÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: Mr. Cranburn?

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Whether did I bring it?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: To the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in Spring-Garden.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: You muÅ¿t not ask any QueÅ¿tions till they have done with him. But, M. De la Rue, let me ask you what Day was this?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: This was Saturday, the 22d. of February; and he told Mr. Porter there was a LiÅ¿t of Mr. Chernock's Men at the bottom of that LiÅ¿t, and I took the LiÅ¿t in my Hand, and there was Mr. Chernock's LiÅ¿t of Six or Seven, or thereabouts, of his Party, and at the bottom of it was R. C. I think, for Robert Chernock. Mr. Porter takes Mr. Cranburn from the Company into another Room, and I went after them, and he told Captain Porter, in my hearing, that the King did not go out that Day. There is one thing I forgot, which now I recollect, and I am upon my Oath to tell the Truth, and the whole Truth: When I was at Mr. Porter's Lodging, he told me the King was to go out; and that Mr. Chambers, the Orderly Man, had Å¿ent word, That the King reÅ¿olv'd to go out between Ten and Eleven.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Who Å¿aid Å¿o?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: Mr. Cranburn told me Å¿o at Mr. Porter's Lodgings, I Å¿ay I had forgot it, but it occurs to my memory now, that he told me there before we went to the Blue-PoÅ¿ts, that the King did go out that Day between 10 and 11; for Mr. Chambers the Orderly man had been with Mr. Chernockâª or Sir William Parkyns, to let them know Å¿o much. And afterwards when he came back with the LiÅ¿t of Captain Porter's Men, to Captain Porter at the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in the Spring-Garden; there was at the foot of that LiÅ¿t, a LiÅ¿t of Mr. Chernock's men in another hand. I Å¿uppoÅ¿e writ by himÅ¿elf, but that I cannot Å¿wear whoÅ¿e hand it was, and Mr. Porter took him into another Room, and then Cranburn told him the King did not go out, and I believe it was then between 11 and 12 a Clock, and he alÅ¿o told Mr. Porter, that Mr. Chernock was apprehenÅ¿ive the thing was DiÅ¿covered, and therefore deÅ¿ired him to have a care of himÅ¿elf, for he himÅ¿elf was reÅ¿olv'd not to lie at home that Night; I think my Lord, Mr. Porter did Å¿end back Mr. Cranburn to Mr. Chernock, I cannot be poÅ¿itive whether he did or not, but I believe he did, becauÅ¿e I am Å¿ure Mr. Cranburn did tell Mr. Porter, Sir George Barclay would Å¿peak with him, and Mr. Porter made anÅ¿wer, Why Å¿hould he deÅ¿ire me to go to him, when he knows I am under Å¿ome Ill CircumÅ¿tances, and he can better come to me? and I believe Mr. Porter did Å¿end Mr. Cranburn once again to Mr. Chernock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well, pray do not Å¿ay any thing of any Matter but what you can be poÅ¿itive in.

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: But Mr. Porter did not go to Mr. Chernockâª nor did Mr. Chernock come to him, therefore they Å¿tay'd there and din'd; and after Dinner, or a little before Dinner, Keyes the Trumpeter, came up, and told us that my Lord of Oxford's Regiment of the Guards was return'd from Richmond, foaming: Keyes wen down Å¿tairs again to learn Intelligence as I thought, and came up and told us he Å¿aw the King's Coaches newly return'd to the Mews, and Mr. Cranburn was by all the time; I think this was before Dinner, and then we went to Dinner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: I tell you again, don't Å¿peak any thing that is material but what you can be poÅ¿itive in.

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: I am poÅ¿itive as to the thing, and that it was the 22th. of February, but I cannot be poÅ¿itive as to all the CircumÅ¿tances: After Dinner there was the uÅ¿ual Healthsâª the Jacobite Healths to King James and the Prince of Wales, and the ReÅ¿toration, and the like; and after thatâª I think it was Mr Porter took an Orange in his hand and Å¿queez'd it, I am Å¿ure one in the Company did, and drankâª Å¿omething to the Rotten Orange, I cannot very well remember juÅ¿t now what it was; but I wou'd be cautions of Å¿aying any thing but what is Truth, but if your LordÅ¿hip will give me leave to recollect my Å¿elf, I will tell you what it wasâOh! it was to the Å¿queezing of the Rotten Orange, and the Health went round, and Mr. Cranburn was in the Company, and drank the Health, but being diÅ¿appointed and fruÅ¿trated of the DeÅ¿ign by the King's not going abroad that Day, and Mr. Porter being caution'd by Mr. Chernock to take care of himÅ¿elf, and being told that Mr. Chernock wou'd not lye at home that Night: and the Guards returning in that manner, they were all apprehenÅ¿ive that the Thing had taken Air, and the deÅ¿ign of AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inating the King was DiÅ¿covered, and therefore Mr. Porter concluded of going out of Town; Å¿everal Healths were drink round, and I think about Two a Clock he went out of Town, and then the Company broke up. This is what I can Å¿ay as to the PriÅ¿oner, and I hope I have Å¿aid nothing but what is Truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, we deÅ¿ire to know whether they will ask him any QueÅ¿tions?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: At the time you Å¿ay this LiÅ¿tâª was given by Captain Porter, to Mr. Cranburn, Did Mr. Porter declare to what purpoÅ¿e the LiÅ¿t was Å¿ent?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: No, Sir, not a word of any Å¿uch thing. Mr. King was by, and Mr. PendergraÅ¿s was by, and I think Mr. Keyes was by, and he writ a LiÅ¿t of his Party, putting me down FirÅ¿t, and Mr. PendergraÅ¿s Å¿aid to me, You are Captain, and he gave it to Mr. Cranburn to carry it to Mr. Chernock; what the particular MeÅ¿Å¿age was, I cannot be poÅ¿itive: Indeed I don't very well remember the MeÅ¿Å¿age, but the LiÅ¿t was carry'd to Mr. Chernock, and to the beÅ¿t of my Memory it was to give Mr. Chernock an Account what men he was Å¿ure of; for Mr. Porter told me of Å¿everal diÅ¿appointments he had had, of PerÅ¿ons that had promis'd him and fail'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Can you remember what Mr. Cranburn Å¿aid upon that?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: What MeÅ¿Å¿age was that you Å¿ay, I brought from Sir George Barclay?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: I do not Å¿ay that you brought any MeÅ¿Å¿age from Sir George Barclay.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: You Å¿aid that I brought a MeÅ¿Å¿age that Sir George Barclay would Å¿ee him.

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: I do not Å¿ay Å¿o; but I Å¿ay that you told Mr. Porter that Mr. Chernock Å¿ent you with a MeÅ¿Å¿age to let him know that Sir George Barclay was deÅ¿irous to Å¿ee Mr. Porter, to confer about taking care of themÅ¿elves.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Did you hear me name Sir George Barclay's Name?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: Yes, I Å¿ay you told Mr. Porter that Mr. Chernock bid you caution him to take care of himÅ¿elf, and that he wou'd go that way, for Sir George Barclay, and he, deÅ¿ired to Å¿ee him; and Mr. Porter Å¿aid it was an unreaÅ¿onable thing for Mr. Chernock to deÅ¿ire it, becauÅ¿e they knew he was under CircumÅ¿tances that it was not proper for him to go, and he wondered rather they would not come to him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: What time a Day was this?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: It was about Twelve a Clock, I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Was it after Å¿uch time as the News was brought that the King did not go abroad that Day?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it was after that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Were you with Sir George Barclay when he was here in England? Did you Å¿ee him here?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: I did not Å¿ee him on this Å¿ide of the Water. I knew him abroad, and a great many other Unfortunate PerÅ¿ons, that were concern'd in this Affair; I knew Å¿ome of them here, and that they were concern'd in the DeÅ¿ign, but I did not converÅ¿e with many, indeed with but a very few about it; for to Å¿hew that I was not a man that deÅ¿ign'd to trappan or inÅ¿nare any man, I did never exchange Two Words about this Matter with any PerÅ¿ons that I knew were concern'd in it, but Sir William Parkyns, (and that but in a Å¿mall meaÅ¿ure) and Mr. Chernock, and Mr. Porter, and Mr. King, and Col. Parker, except what paÅ¿t upon the 22th. between Mr. Porter, and Mr. Chernock, when Mr. Porter Å¿ent Mr. Cranburn to Mr. Chernock. Mr. Cranburn was one who Mr. Porter called his Quarter-MaÅ¿ter: I know this Gentleman was commonly depending upon Mr. Porter, but I think I never was much in his Company, I did not know what DeÅ¿ign he had upon him, but I was told by Mr. Porter, that he Intended to make him his Quarter-MaÅ¿ter, and I underÅ¿tood Mr. Porter was to have a Troop of HorÅ¿e in Col. Parker's Regiment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: You Å¿ay you knew a great many of them that were concern'd, but you diÅ¿cours'd and converÅ¿ed but with a few?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: I do Å¿o, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: How do you know that they were concern'd, when you did not diÅ¿courÅ¿e with them?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: By Information from Mr. Chernock, and Mr. Porter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Do you know any thing more of Mr. Cranburn, than the LiÅ¿t, and what you have Å¿aid already?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: I give you an Account of all that I do know.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: AnÅ¿wer that particular QueÅ¿tion. Do you know nothing more than what you have Å¿aid?

sp.speaker: M. De la Rue.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I do not remember nor know any more as to Mr. Cranburn than what I have declared, and I am Å¿orry I had OccaÅ¿ion to declare Å¿o much.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then call Mr. PendergraÅ¿s.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray will you give my Lord and the Jury an account of what you know of the Intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and how far Mr. Cranburn, the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, was concerned in it.

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: My Lord, the 13th of February laÅ¿t, I came out of HampÅ¿hire, Mr. Porter Å¿ent for me to come to Town, and I met him that day at the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in Spring Garden, and there he told me of the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination that was to be done on Saturday following: The next day we dined at the RoÅ¿e-Tavern, where the PriÅ¿oner dined with us, and we talk'd of the BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, that was Friday the 14th. and we were to be in readineÅ¿s the next day to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, as he was coming from Richmond; but Å¿ome Company coming in afterwards; we left off the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e and talk'd no more that Night. The next day that we were to do the BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, we met at the Blue-PoÅ¿ts in Spring-Garden, and finding the King did not go abroad that Saturday, we dined there at the Blue-PoÅ¿ts, and talk'd over again of AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inating the King, and the PriÅ¿oner was by at the Å¿ame time, they were all mightily concerned the King did not go that Saturday; but when we had dined there, we had no further DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination that day, but every body was to prepare againÅ¿t the next Saturday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Was that agreed upon then?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Yes it was, by all the Company; Å¿o we parted that day. Some time the next Week I met Mr. Porter, and Mr. Porter ask'd me if I had a HorÅ¿eman's Sword; I told him no: Says he to Mr. Cranburn, let Captain PendergraÅ¿s have one of the HorÅ¿emens Swords that you have got. Says Mr. Cranburn to me, if you will come to my HouÅ¿e you Å¿hall make choice of one your Å¿elf, for I have Å¿everal at home. Said I, Mr. Cranburn, I cannot go that way, but I'll take one of your ChooÅ¿ing, if Å¿o be you'll leave it at my Lodgings: He Å¿aid he would do it, and did; he left it at my Lodgings in Suffolk-Street, which Sword I have Å¿till. The day following I met him, and he ask'd me if I had receiv'd the Sword; I Å¿aid I had it; and he Å¿aid, it was very well. After this I did not Å¿ee Mr. Cranburn till Saturday the 22d. at which time I came to Mr. Porter's Lodgings between Nine and Ten a Clock in the Morning, and the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar was there, and I heard Mr. Porter give him a MeÅ¿Å¿age to go to Sir William Parkyns for Å¿ome HorÅ¿es, I know not how many. The PriÅ¿oner went, and in Å¿ome time after, came back again, and brought an account that the King went out that Saturday the 22d. to Richmond; Å¿o every body was to get ready: And Mr. Cranburn Å¿aid, that Mr. Chernock deÅ¿ired that Mr. Porter would Å¿end a LiÅ¿t of his Men; upon which Mr. Porter wrote a LiÅ¿t of his Men, and gave it to the PriÅ¿oner to carry it to Mr. Chernock, and bid him meet him at the Blue-PoÅ¿ts; and Mr. Porter and M. De la Rue and I took Coach, and went down to Spring-Garden, and when we came to the Blue-PoÅ¿ts, there were Å¿ome PerÅ¿ons that I think Mr. De la Rue had appointed to come there; the PriÅ¿oner comes thither, and brought the LiÅ¿t back, with a LiÅ¿t of Mr. Chernock's Men underneath. I know not who the Men were, for I Å¿aw it only on the one Å¿ide of the Table, in Mr. Porter's Hand; at the Å¿ame time the PriÅ¿oner brought an account, that the King did not go abroad that day, and preÅ¿ently after we had the Å¿ame account from other Hands; and Captain Porter and I went out of Town, and we heard no more of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Are you Å¿ure that he did agree to this matter before the 15th.?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Yes, I am Å¿ure of it, he agreed to it Friday the 14th. at the RoÅ¿e Tavern in Covent-Garden.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: On the 15th. it Å¿eems they were diÅ¿appointed; are you Å¿ure there was an Agreement to purÅ¿ue it the 22d.?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Yes, I am Å¿ure there was, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Was the PriÅ¿oner there?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am Å¿ure that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar was there?

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. PendergraÅ¿s, was there any DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about this thing when I was there?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Cranburn, you cannot but remember there was.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: What hour did I come there, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Truly, I cannot be poÅ¿itive to an Hour, but you was there while the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e was.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Whether did I Å¿tay there all the while, and who was in the Company?

sp.speaker: Captâª PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: All the Company broke up about Å¿ix a Clock, there was Mr. King, Captain Porter, Mr. Kendrick, Mr. Cranburn, Mr. Keyes, and my Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Was Kendrick there when I was there?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Yes, I am Å¿ure of it, I will do you all the JuÅ¿tice in the world that I can.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: You Å¿ay, Sir, he did agree upon the 14th. to this DeÅ¿ign, pray what Words did he uÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: He did agree, that we Å¿hould attack the King the next day.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray Sir, if you can, recollect your Å¿elf; what did the PriÅ¿oner Å¿ay, or whether you took him to agree by being Å¿ilent?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: He Å¿aid he hop'd we Å¿hould execute our BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s the next Day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: What day was that?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: That was the 14th. of February, and the Å¿ame Night I gave account of the matter to my Lord Portland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Did he agree to be one in the Execution of the DeÅ¿ign?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Yes, he did; he diÅ¿courÅ¿ed the matter to me himÅ¿elf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we have done with our Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: VVell, then what Å¿ay you to it for the PriÅ¿oner?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p:
My Lord, what we have to Å¿ay on behalf of the PriÅ¿oner in this ReÅ¿pect is this, here are but three VVitneÅ¿Å¿es produced, and as to one of them, De la Rue, there is no Evidence that he gives Your LordÅ¿hips and the Jury, that affects this matter, but only that there was a LiÅ¿t given by Captain Porter, and carried by the PriÅ¿oner to Mr. Chernock, and Å¿o brought back again. But he does not recollect, nor Å¿wear to any MeÅ¿Å¿age that was Å¿ent from Porter by the PriÅ¿oner to Mr. Chernock: Now, my Lord, the bare carrying of a Note of Names will be no Evidence of TreaÅ¿on. M. De la Rue does not Å¿wear to any Privity of the PriÅ¿oner, what the LiÅ¿t was for, nor to the Delivery of the LiÅ¿t, which is the Overt Act in the Indictment, nor upon what account this LiÅ¿t was written, or Å¿ent, or brought back againâª or any VVord that proceeded from Captain Porter to him upon giving the LiÅ¿t, or any VVord when it was brought back again. So that as to De la Rue's TeÅ¿timony, we muÅ¿t Å¿ubmit it to the Memories and Recollection of your LordÅ¿hip and the Jury, we think he only proves a Plot in general, of which there is no peradventure, every Body is Å¿atisfied, that there was Å¿uch a horrible ConÅ¿piracy: thoÅ¿e that have been condemned and executed for it, have own'd it, and Å¿o it can never be doubted, but he does not Å¿ay any thing to affect the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar; for as to the drinking of Healths, and being preÅ¿ent when thoÅ¿e Healths were drank, tho' it be an
Evidence of DiÅ¿affection to the Government, or too much good Manners and ComplaiÅ¿ance to the Company a Man is in, yet that DiÅ¿affection, or Evil Temper, or ComplaiÅ¿ance, we hope are no Evidences of TreaÅ¿on. It is plain the PriÅ¿oner did depend very much upon Captain Porter; he was in truth his Servant to go of his Errands, and expected an Office from him, God knows when; but it does not appear by any particular Action, that he did any thing that can be TreaÅ¿on, upon M. De la Rue's Evidence. Then as to what Mr. PendergraÅ¿s Å¿ays, I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s his Evidence comes home: For he Å¿ays there was a DeÅ¿ign of the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and Å¿ome Agreement of the PriÅ¿oner to it; but I muÅ¿t beg your LordÅ¿hips Favour to obÅ¿erve, upon Mr. PendergraÅ¿s's Evidence, if that Å¿tand alone, it will be but one WitneÅ¿s, and then we are Å¿afe by the Purview of this Act of Parliament.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Ay, and by the Law, before the making of that Act.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Then, as to Captain Porter, I muÅ¿t beg leave to Å¿ay, If our WitneÅ¿Å¿es are come that were abÅ¿ent at the other Tryal, and they prove what is in my InÅ¿tructions, it well be very much QueÅ¿tionable, whether there be any Credibility due to his TeÅ¿timony: Then if you take off his TeÅ¿timony, there is only the Evidence of Mr. PendergraÅ¿s; and if he be to be believed, to which I have nothing to Å¿ay at preÅ¿ent, in the CaÅ¿e of a Man's Life, upon an Indictment of TreaÅ¿on, where the Law requires two credible WitneÅ¿Å¿es, his Å¿ingle TeÅ¿timony is not Å¿ufficient to convict the PriÅ¿oner. We beg leave to call our WitneÅ¿Å¿es, and then we Å¿hall leave it to your LordÅ¿hip, and the Jury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: As to the particular Overt-Act laid in the Indictment, the carrying about the LiÅ¿t, only M De la Rue Å¿peaks to it, and Sir Bartholomew Shower has given it an AnÅ¿wer, and I Å¿hall not repeat it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Look ye, for that, if any one Overt-Act is prov'd by Two WitneÅ¿Å¿es, it's well enough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: BeÅ¿ides, they miÅ¿take, my Lord, extreamly; for Captain Porter, and Mr. PendergraÅ¿s, Å¿peak both of them to that particular, as to the LiÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: We do not deny it; the QueÅ¿tion is, Whether you have Two Credible WitneÅ¿Å¿es?

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. PendergraÅ¿s, do you remember what Captain Porter Å¿aid to you, and I, when we came down to the Blue-PoÅ¿ts, leading from the Rail?

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I do not.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I would have you recollect your Å¿elf; as we Å¿tood againÅ¿t the Rails in Spring-Garden, when we came down from the Blue-PoÅ¿ts, after the DeÅ¿ign miÅ¿carry'd, Mr. Porter Å¿aid, Mr. Chernock, and they, might thank themÅ¿elves if it were diÅ¿covered; For, Å¿ays he, I never communicated a Word of this thing to any of my Party.

sp.speaker: Capt. PendergraÅ¿s.
sp.p: Indeed I don't remember a Word of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: My Lord, we have one piece of Evidence to offer againÅ¿t the TeÅ¿timony of Captain Porter: He Å¿ays, That he Å¿ent Cranburn with Gunn from the Cock-pit to Å¿ee for Hackney-HorÅ¿es, and that Cranburn came to him to the Sun Tavern, and there they had Å¿ome DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about executing the DeÅ¿ign the next Day; and being ask'd who was by, when he communicated the DeÅ¿ign to Cranburn, and particularly, Whether Mr. Gunn was by? he Å¿ays he came in afterwards, but was not there at the time of the Communication about the DeÅ¿ign. Now we Å¿hall prove that Gunn came in with the PriÅ¿oner, and was with him all the time, and there was no Å¿uch DiÅ¿courÅ¿e happen'd.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Call Geoffry Gunn, and Mary Gerrard.

Your LordÅ¿hip will obÅ¿erve, what Captain Porter Å¿wore, That he went in to the Room to Cranburn, and Gunn was not there: Now, if we falÅ¿ifie him in that Particular, we Å¿hall Å¿ubmit to your LordÅ¿hip how far he is to be believed in the reÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Bartholomew, ask your WitneÅ¿Å¿es what you will, but make no DeÅ¿cants upon their Evidence till you have heard them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well look ye, you are both upon your Oaths, ConÅ¿ider what you Å¿ay, Å¿peak the Truth, and tell all that you know, and nothing but the Truth. Which do you begin with?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Jeffery Gunn, Pray, Mr. Gunn, did you go to the Sun Tavern at any time with Mr. Cranburn?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: What day of the Month was it?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I cannot tell poÅ¿itively the Day, it was of a Friday.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Was it of a Friday, in February, or January?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: It was in February.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Was it before the Plot broke out?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes, It was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: How long was it before the Plot broke out?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I cannot tell that, truly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Whence did you go?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I was at the Cock-pit, and I went from thence to the Sun Tavern.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Who did you meet there?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I Å¿aw Captain Porter there.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: What Room were you in?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: We went into a Room next the Å¿treet.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Who was there with you?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: There was Mr. Cranburn, and I, and Mr. Keyes.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long was it before Mr. Porter came in to you?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: He came in about Half a Quarter of an Hour after I was there.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Were you there from the beginning till Mr. Cranburn went away.

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Mr. Cranburn, and I, went from the Cock-pit together.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long did you Å¿tay there?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I was there about an Hour and a Half.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Were you out of the Room at all in that time?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes, I was out of the Room once.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long were you out of the Room?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I went home to my Lodging

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Were you ever with Mr. Cranburn at the Sun Tavern at any time beÅ¿ides this?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Never in my Life.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Who did you you leave with him when you went out?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Capt. Porter, and Mr. Keyes, as I remember.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Were you there before Capt. Porter came to him?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I was with Mr. Cranburn, and Capt. Porter came in about a Quarter of an Hour after, we came from the Cock-pit together.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray recollect your Å¿elf, and tell us upon your Oath, were you there when Capt. Porter came in?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes, I think I was there when Capt. Porter came in.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you go and leave him there?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: We went all out together. I was there about an Hour and half.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Nay, but you Å¿aid you were abÅ¿ent Å¿ome time.

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I went home, and came back again.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: When you went home, did you leave Mr. Cranburn behind you?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes, I think Å¿o.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Did you leave Capt. Porter with him?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I think Capt. Porter was with him then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: But upon your Oath, was you in Company with Mr. Cranburn at the Sun Tavern, when Capt. Porter came firÅ¿t in?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Captain Porter went in and out Å¿everal times.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you Å¿ee Capt. Porter before you went to your own HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes Å¿ure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Then it cannot be true what Mr. Porter Å¿ays, that Gunn did not come in till afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now Mr. Gunn I would ask you a QueÅ¿tion or two firÅ¿t, Were you there all the while that Mr. Cranburn was there, or did you go home?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I went home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you come back again?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes, I came home and eat Å¿ome Victuals.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long were you abÅ¿ent?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: I came back in half a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How far is it to your HouÅ¿e? Gunn. 'Tis not above 100 yards.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did Mr. Porter come into you before you went home, when you firÅ¿t came in with Cranburn?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: He came in after we were in the Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Capt. Porter Å¿aid, when he came into the Room Gunn was not there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: He did not Å¿ay poÅ¿itively, but as he remembred; now I would ask you a QueÅ¿tion or two.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, our Inference from this Evidence is thus; Capt. Porter Å¿ays, that upon Fryday the 21th. of February he was with Cranburn at the Sun Tavern, and out of one Room into another he came to Mr. Cranburn, and talk'd with him of this DeÅ¿ign, and after that Gunn came in to the Room, after the Communication was over: Now this man Å¿wears he went from the Cock-pit with Mr. Cranburn, he was with him in the Room at firÅ¿t when Capt. Porter came in; Å¿ome time afterwards he went to his own HouÅ¿e, and left Captain Porter with Mr. Cranburn, and came back again, and they came away together: Now we Å¿ay, theÅ¿e two are inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent; for Capt. Porter Å¿wears that Gunn was not there till after the Communication was over. L. C. J. Holt. As he remembers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Nay, I think he was poÅ¿itive he came in afterwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: As I remember he was not poÅ¿itive, but call Capt. Porter again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: When you came back from your HouÅ¿e, who were in the Room?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: The Å¿ame Company as I left, as far as I remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mountague.
sp.p: Was Capt. Porter in the Room when you came back?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Indeed I can't directly tell, I believe he was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Pray obÅ¿erve what your WitneÅ¿s Å¿ays: He Å¿ays Capt. Porter came in and out, and was there Å¿everal times before he went away.

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, he was Å¿o.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: And you were abÅ¿ent Å¿ome time, but were you there Å¿ome time before Porter came in? Gunn. Yes, I believe I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Look ye Capt. Porter, you Å¿ee that man there?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray give an Account of what you know of that mans coming in to you at the Sun Tavern.

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I came Å¿everal times out of Sir George Barclay's Room into theirs, and to the beÅ¿t of my Remembrance, Mr. Cranburn was there before Gunn came in.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Do you remember whether the firÅ¿t time that you went out of Sir George Barclay's Room to Å¿peak with Mr. Cranburn, Mr. Gunn was there?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: To the beÅ¿t of my remembrance he was not; to the beÅ¿t of my remembrance Mr. Gunn, I Å¿aw Mr. Cranburn in the Room before you was there.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did not you order Gunn to come with him to the Sun Tavern?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: Yes Sir I did.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Can't you tell whether they came together?

sp.speaker: Capt. Porter.
sp.p: I was not in the Room when they came in firÅ¿t, but to the beÅ¿t of my remembrance he was not there when I came in the firÅ¿t time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Now Gunn, you hear what Capt. Porter Å¿ays, before you went away to your own HouÅ¿e did Mr. Porter come into the Room to you?

sp.speaker: Gunn.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord I am not poÅ¿itive, I think he did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Neither of them is poÅ¿itive, and it is a CircumÅ¿tance not very material; for it Å¿eems he was abÅ¿ent, and then the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e might be.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: No, it is not material, but you Å¿ee upon a Å¿trict Examination what it comes to?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: They are agreed upon it I perceive, to be poÅ¿itive on neither Å¿ide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Mr. Cranburn pray ask Mrs. Gerrard what you have a mind.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Pray what do you know of Capt. Porters going out in DiÅ¿guiÅ¿e, and wearing falÅ¿e Hair and Vizards, and going upon the High-way, and Å¿uch things?

sp.speaker: Gerrard.
sp.p: I know not what Mr. Cranburn means:

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: It is no laughing matter, when a man is upon his Life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: No, no, let him have fair play; AnÅ¿wer the QueÅ¿tion.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of your MaÅ¿ters going abroad in DiÅ¿guiÅ¿es?

sp.speaker: Gerard.
sp.p: I do not know any thing of my MaÅ¿ters going upon the High-way.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Did he go out with Vizards, or any Å¿uch things?

sp.speaker: Gerrard.
sp.p: I never Å¿aw him wear a Vizard or falÅ¿e Beard in my Life, but he had once a Patch on when he was forced to keep out of the way, upon the Account of the Dog Tavern BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s in Drury-Lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: See if Mr. Edward Bouchier is here.
sp.stage: [He was call'd, but did not appear.]

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Call Mrsâª Burton, (which was done); but Å¿he did not appear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phipps.
sp.p: Is William Hardyman here; he was cal'edâª but did not appear.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Then call Simon DawÅ¿on, and we have done

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: They are all call'd, but they do not appear.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: My Lord, we muÅ¿t Å¿ubmit it to your LordÅ¿hips Directions upon the Evidence that has been given, as to the Credibility of theÅ¿e WitneÅ¿Å¿es, and whether what Capt. Porter Å¿ays, and what Gunn Å¿ays be conÅ¿iÅ¿tent; Å¿o that you can be Å¿atisfied there are Two Lawful Credible WitneÅ¿Å¿es to prove any Overt-Act.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Yes Å¿ure, but I would have you debate it if you believe there be any thing in it. Sir B. Shower. I Å¿ubmit it to your LordÅ¿hips Directions.

sp.speaker: L. Câª J. Holt.
sp.p: The QueÅ¿tion is, Whether I Å¿hould give any Directions at all or no, or whether there be any occaÅ¿ion for it.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I declare this openly before this Honourable Court, and Å¿o many Noblemen as are here, that Mr. Porter never made me acquainted with this DeÅ¿ign, till what he Å¿wore here. L. C. J. Holt. I can't tell, tis Å¿worn by 2 WitneÅ¿Å¿es.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I do declare, tho' Capt. PendergraÅ¿s Å¿ays he does not remember it, that Capt. Porter did declare in Spring Garden the 22th. when we came out of the Blew PoÅ¿ts by the Rails, if this DeÅ¿ign miÅ¿carry, Å¿ays he, Mr. Charnock may thank himÅ¿elf, for I never communicated this Secret to any of my Friends.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: But hark ye, do you conÅ¿ider what you Å¿ay, if this DeÅ¿ign miÅ¿carryed: Pray what DeÅ¿ign was that?

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: He never named any thing but the DeÅ¿ign, he did not Å¿ay what it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: But why were you imploy'd to carry a LiÅ¿t from Capt. Porter to Mr. Chernock, and to bring a LiÅ¿t back again from him to Capt. Porter?

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I did carry the Note, but there was nothing mentioned what the LiÅ¿t was for.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Then when you were there on Fryday the 14th. and there the DeÅ¿ign was propos'd to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King the next Day, and you engag'd in it.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: Not a Word of it True my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Aye but Mr. PendergraÅ¿s Å¿wears it, and that you were hearty in the Matter, and hop'd you Å¿hould do your BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s the next day.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I can't help it if he does Å¿wear it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Then you were at the Meeting at the Sun Tavern the 21th.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: My Lord you hear what Gun Å¿ays.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: As to that they are neither of them poÅ¿itive, but you did there promiÅ¿e and undertake the Matter, that Capt. Porter is poÅ¿itive in, that it was agreed by you all to do it the 22th. and Mr. PendergraÅ¿s Å¿ays, when you were diÅ¿appointed the 15th. you agreed all to purÅ¿ue the Å¿ame DeÅ¿ign the Saturday following.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: My Lord, I did not dine at the Blew PoÅ¿ts that day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: But you were there; I think indeed Mr. PendergraÅ¿s Å¿ays you came in after Dinner, and had Å¿ome Stakes.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I never heard Directly nor Indirectly of this DeÅ¿ign, till what I heard them Å¿wear here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Jury, you do underÅ¿tand for what Crime this PriÅ¿oner at the Bar is Indicted: It is for High-TreaÅ¿on in deÅ¿igning and compaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death of the King, which was to be effected by an AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, in the moÅ¿t Barbarous and wicked manner, that any attempt of that nature can poÅ¿Å¿ibly be made, being to Å¿urpriÅ¿e the King, and murder him in his Coach.

The QueÅ¿tion Gentlemen is, whether this PriÅ¿oner be Guilty of this Crime or no; there have been three WitneÅ¿Å¿es produced that have given evidence againÅ¿t him; Captain Porter, Mr. De la Rue, and Mr. PendergraÅ¿s, and they do all tell
you, that there was Å¿uch a deÅ¿ign on Foot to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, as he came from Hunting at Richmond, after he came on this Å¿ide the Water, in the Lane between Brentford and Turnham-Green. There were DiverÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons Ingaged in this DeÅ¿ign, which Sir George Berclay was come from France, to promote and manage Captain Porter, as it does appear upon his Evidence, was a PerÅ¿on that was principally Ingaged, and at that time was hearty in the ProÅ¿ecution of it.

As to Mr. Cranburn, Cap. Porter tells you he was a Man that he had had a long acquaintance with, and had Imployed him and deÅ¿igned to imploy as an Officer under him, in caÅ¿e a Revolution happened, which it Å¿eems about that time, and Å¿ome time before it was expected. Cap. Porter was to have been a Cap, and I think he deÅ¿igned to promote Cranburn to be his Quarter MaÅ¿ter; and he Å¿ent him to buy Arms; and preparations were made for that buÅ¿ineÅ¿s; but that is not the thing that we are now upon, the matter that now properly falls under our ConÅ¿ideration, is this, the coming over of Sir George Berclay, the latter end of January, or the beginning of Febuary laÅ¿t, upon which as it Å¿eems Mr Porter was Engaged, and having an IntereÅ¿t in this Cranburn, and there being HorÅ¿es to be furniÅ¿ht to attack the King and his Guards about Turnham green. This Man Cranburn, was a PerÅ¿on that was ingaged to be one of the HorÅ¿e-Men that were to make the attack, and he tells you that he did Imploy him to provide HorÅ¿es and Swords, and to prepare the PiÅ¿tols, and that he did Engage in it, and particularly that the deÅ¿ign was to be Executed on Saturday the 15th of February, and that he was then ready to go with Captain Porter; but on that Saturday the King did not go abroad, whereby the deÅ¿ign was DiÅ¿appointed for that time: Afterwards there was a meeting at the Sun Tavern in the Strand, where he met with Sir George Berclay and others of them, and there comes to that Tavern Mr. Cranburn and others, and they were in an other Room, and Captain Porter Å¿ays he came to them, and did DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about purÅ¿uing the deÅ¿ign the very next Day, which was agreed, and Cranburn was ready to go the next Day.

Then he tells you farther, that the next day being Saturday the 22. The Å¿econd time that this AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was to have been Executed, upon the deÅ¿ire of Mr. Chernock, who was a PerÅ¿on alÅ¿o that was Ingaged in this deÅ¿ign. Captain Porter writes a LiÅ¿t of the Men he could bring, and Å¿ent it by Cranburn to Charnock; Cranburn carries the LiÅ¿t to Mr. Charnock, and brings it back again with an Addition of the names of Mr. Charnock's Men underneath.

Mr. De la Rue is called, and he Swears to that very CircumÅ¿tance, that Mr. Cranburn was Å¿ent by Captain Porter with a LiÅ¿t to Mr. Charnock, and brought it back again from Mr. Charnock, with an Addition of other Names.

Then Mr. PendergraÅ¿s tells you, that he was with this Mr. Cranburn, the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, the fourteenth of February, and there was a diÅ¿courÅ¿e of going in purÅ¿uance of this deÅ¿ign the next day, and the PriÅ¿oner agreed to it, which he is poÅ¿itive in: he tells you, that when they were diÅ¿appointed the 15th, being at the Blew-PoÅ¿ts, they then agreed to purÅ¿ue it the next Saturday; Cranburn was one of them that agreed.

Captain Porter and De la Rue informs you that Healths were drank to the late King, and the late Queen, and the Prince of Wales, as they called him, and then at length, as the Concluding health, Captain Porter or Å¿ome of them in the Company, having an Orange in his Hand, Å¿queezed it, and drank a Health to the Å¿queezing of the Rotten Orange, which was Pledged by all, and particularly by Mr. Cranburn, as is proved by both Captain Porter and De la Rue.

So that now Gentlemen I muÅ¿t leave it to you, whether this is not Evidence Å¿ufficient to prove this Man Guilty of the TreaÅ¿on; whereof he is Indicted, that is of DeÅ¿igning and Intending the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination of the King, and being engaged as a Party to execute this DeÅ¿ign, when ever there was an Opportunity

The Council inÅ¿iÅ¿t upon it, on the behalf of the PriÅ¿oner, that what Captain Porter Å¿ays is not Evidence: In the firÅ¿t place they urge that he is not a Man of Credit, for they have mentioned that he uÅ¿ed to be DiÅ¿guiÅ¿ed, and wear a Vizard Mask, and go abroad under odd CircumÅ¿tances, and therefore his Reputation they hope is not good enough to make him a Credible WitneÅ¿s againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner: Now the PriÅ¿oners WitneÅ¿s being produced, Å¿ays he never knew him go in any DiÅ¿guiÅ¿e or wear a Vizard Mask, but once he wore a Patch, becauÅ¿e he was under Å¿ome Ill CircumÅ¿tances about a Riot in Drury-Lane; every body underÅ¿tands what the meaning of that was, his drinking of Healths at a Riotous aÅ¿Å¿embly, upon the 11th of June, and he being under Å¿ome ProÅ¿ecution for that, occaÅ¿ioned him to wear that DiÅ¿guiÅ¿e, but it was not done to Injure any PerÅ¿on, or do any miÅ¿chief.

But then Å¿ay they he is miÅ¿taken in his Evidence, of the meeting at the Sun-Tavern the 21Å¿t of February, the day before the laÅ¿t, that this deÅ¿ign was to have been executed, for whereas he Å¿ays, that Gunn was not there when he came to them, yet Gunn was in the Company at that time, and whereas he Swears poÅ¿itively that they diÅ¿courÅ¿ed of going upon the Å¿ame deÅ¿ign to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King the next day, as was agreed the Saturday before; Gunn heard no Å¿uch diÅ¿courÅ¿e. Gunn is called, and he tells you he did come to the Sun Tavern at that time, with Cranburn and Captain Porter, he came into the Room, and he heard no Å¿uch diÅ¿courÅ¿e. They did open it indeed that Gunn had been there all the while, and if Å¿o then, if there had been Å¿uch a diÅ¿courÅ¿e he muÅ¿t have heard it. Gunn has been Examined, and does tell you he was not there all the while, but went out and was abÅ¿ent for Å¿ometime, about half a Quarter of an Hour.

They have made a QueÅ¿tion whether Captain Porter came in, when Gunn was there, he Å¿ays truly he thinks that Captain Porter did come into the Room while he was there, before he went out, but he cannot tell certainly, he was there Å¿ometime, while he was there. Then Captain Porter was called again, and Cap. Porter does Å¿ay he knows Gunn was there, but whether he were there at the time he came in, he cannot Å¿ay poÅ¿itively; but Gunn Å¿ays Captain Porter was goeing in and out Å¿everal times, as Porter Å¿ays himÅ¿elf; and Gunn was abÅ¿ent for Å¿ome part of the time. So that I cannot Å¿ee any Å¿ort of Contradiction between the Evidence that Porter gives, and the Evidence that Gunn gives; the one is uncertain, and Å¿o is the other as to that CircumÅ¿tance.

But Gentlemen, they would infer that if there was any Å¿uch DiÅ¿courÅ¿e while Gun was there, it muÅ¿t be of neceÅ¿Å¿ity that Gunn muÅ¿t have heard it; but it is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary the diÅ¿courÅ¿e Å¿hould be when Gunn was there: Captain Porter Swears poÅ¿itively that there was Å¿uch a diÅ¿courÅ¿e of going the next day to purÅ¿ue the deÅ¿ign, and he Å¿ays he thinks Gunn was not preÅ¿ent at that time when the diÅ¿courÅ¿e was, and Gunn Å¿ays he was abÅ¿ent Å¿ome part of the time.

And Å¿o I muÅ¿t leave it to you, upon the whole matter, if Mr. Cranburn the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, did ConÅ¿ent and agree to Act in this Bloody and wicked DeÅ¿ign, then you are to find him Guilty; if you are not Å¿atisfied of that upon the Evidence you have heard, or you think there is any InconÅ¿iÅ¿tency, or Incoherence in the TeÅ¿timony on the one Å¿ide, and the other; and that there is good ReaÅ¿on to disbelieve the Evidence againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner, Then you are to acquit him. You have heard your Evidence, and you had beÅ¿t conÅ¿ider of it.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Crown.
sp.p: Who keeps the Jury?

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: there is an Officer Sworn.
Then the Jury withdrew to conÅ¿ider of their Verdict, and about a quarter of an Hour after Returned.

sp.speaker: Cl of Ar.
sp.p: Gentlemen anÅ¿wer to your Names, John Kaine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kaine.
sp.p: Here. And Å¿o of the ReÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Are you all agreed of your Verdict?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Who Å¿hall Å¿ay for you?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Foreman.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Charles Cranburn hold up thy Hand, (which he did) look upon the PriÅ¿oner, how Å¿ay you, is he Guilty of the High-TreaÅ¿on whereof he Å¿tands Indicted or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl of Ar.
sp.p: What Goods, or Chattles, Lands or Tenements, had he at the time of the TreaÅ¿on Committed, or at any time Å¿ince.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: None to our Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Then hearken to your Verdict, as the Court has Recorded it. You Å¿ay that Charles Cranburn is Guilty of the High-TreaÅ¿on whereof he Å¿tands Indicted; but that he had no Goods, Chattles, Lands or Tenements, at the time of the High-TreaÅ¿on committed, or at any time Å¿ince, to your Knowledge, and Å¿o you Å¿ay all?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kaine.
sp.p: My Lord, the Jury humbly deÅ¿ires they may be diÅ¿charged from their attendance to Morrow

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: We cannot do it, unleÅ¿s the Jury be full without them; If you come early, we Å¿hall diÅ¿patch you preÅ¿ently.

div.p: Then the PriÅ¿oner was taken from the Bar, and the Court adjourned till Seven a Clock the next Morning.

THE Arraignment, Tryal, and Condemnation OF Robert Lowick, For the Horrid and Execrable CONSPIRACY To AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate His Sacred MajeÅ¿ty KING WILLIAM, In Order to a French INVASION of the Kingdom. Who upon full Evidence was found Guilty of High TreaÅ¿on before His MajeÅ¿ty's JuÅ¿tices of Oyer and Terminer, at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, on WedneÅ¿day the 22th of April, 1696, and was Executed at Tyburn on the 29th day of the Å¿aid Month. In which Tryal All the Learned Arguments of the King's Council, and likewiÅ¿e the Council for the PriÅ¿oner, upon the New Act of Parliament for Regulating Tryals in CaÅ¿es of TreaÅ¿on.
LONDON: Printed for Samuel Heyrick at Grays-Inn-Gate, Holbourn; and IÅ¿aac Cleave at the Star next Serjeants-Inn-Gate in Chancery-Lane. M DC XC VI.

div.head:
Die Mercurii ViceÅ¿imo Secundo Die Aprilis, Anno Domini 1696. Anno
que Regni Regis GULIELMI III. OCTAVO.
div.p: THIS Day the JuÅ¿tices of Oyer and Terminer holden for the County of MiddleÅ¿ex, adjourned over to Seven this Morning, met, and the Court was ReÅ¿um'd by Proclamation in uÅ¿ual Form.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Arraignments.
sp.p: Keeper of Newgate, Å¿et Robert Lowick to the Bar, (which was done) You the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, Robert Lowick, thoÅ¿e Men that you Å¿hall hear called and perÅ¿onally appear, are to paÅ¿s between our Sovereign Lord the King and You, upon Tryal of your Life and Death; if therefore you will Challenge them, or any of them, your time is to Å¿peak unto them, as they come to the Book to be Sworn, and before they be Sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p:
If your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es to favour me with one Word for the PriÅ¿onor at the Bar; I Å¿hall not trouble your LordÅ¿hip with any thing that was urged by the Gentlemen that were of Council YeÅ¿terday, but I Å¿hall Rely upon Å¿omething that has not yet been Å¿poken to. My Lord, they have not laid any Time or Place where the ConÅ¿ent or Agreement was for the Forty Men that were to Å¿et upon the King and his Guards: There is a Time laid before where they met and diÅ¿courÅ¿ed of the Ways and Means how to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate and Kill the King; but when it comes to the AÅ¿Å¿encerant, ConceÅ¿Å¿erunt & Aggreaverunt; with SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, this being another Act; there ought to be another Time and Place laid, and for that I Å¿hall Cite your LordÅ¿hip two or three CaÅ¿es; for Men may meet and PropoÅ¿e and DiÅ¿courÅ¿e and ConÅ¿ult of Å¿uch Things, though they be
very Ill Things, and yet that may not be TreaÅ¿on. It's the Agreement that is the TreaÅ¿on, and Å¿o 'twas held in Captain Blagues CaÅ¿e about Taking the Tower: They may meet at one Time and Place, and at another Time and Place they may agree, in Dyer, 68. B. and 69 Pl. 28. a Man was Indicted for Murder, that he at Å¿uch a Place in and upon the PerÅ¿on that was Murdered in Sultumferit & ipÅ¿um, the PerÅ¿on that was Murdered, cum Quodam Curtello, of Å¿uch a Price, percuÅ¿Å¿it; and he does not Å¿hew the place where he Å¿truck him, nor had the Indictment the Words, ad tunc & Ibidem, and therefore the Court held it void: So it is likewiÅ¿e Ruled in Goodrick's CaÅ¿e, H â¢ ll. 35. & 119. and therefore in Indictments for Murder, Å¿ince they generally Å¿et forth not only the Time and Place of the AÅ¿Å¿ault, but likewiÅ¿e of the Blow; Å¿o likewiÅ¿e in things of a more inferiour Nature, as ReÅ¿cues, Returned by the Sheriff, that the Capias was Å¿erved, but does not Å¿hew where the ReÅ¿cue was, or though he Å¿hews where the ArreÅ¿t was, and an & Coupled the ReÅ¿cue to it, yet it was adjudged and Ill Return, Dyer 69. Pl. 29. 10 Edw. 4. 15 Fitz. Ret. Vic. 32 Bro. Ret. Det. Bre. 97. and Errour 194. Palm. 563. And in Noy 114. there are theÅ¿e Words, Note, It was Moved in DiÅ¿charge of a ReÅ¿cue, the Return was, that they, viz. A. B. aforeÅ¿aid the Bayliffs, ad Tunc & Ibidem Vulneraverunt, &c. And the aforeÅ¿aid George, &c. ReÅ¿cuÅ¿erunt without ad tunc & Ibidem, Referred only to the Vulneraverunt, and not to the ReÅ¿cuÅ¿erunt, and therefore the Return was adjudged InÅ¿ufficient; for my Lord, although in Conveyances, a ClauÅ¿e or Word in the beginning or end may Refer to the whole, yet in Indictments every Sentence muÅ¿t be Certain, Plain, and ExpreÅ¿s, and have its own Time and Place: Therefore in Noy's Rep. 122. Raymond was Indicted for Å¿topping a CroÅ¿s Way leading from a certain Ville called Stoake, into a Ville called Melton in the County of DorÅ¿et, and the Indictment was QuaÅ¿ht, becauÅ¿e in the County of DorÅ¿et Å¿hall refer only to Melton, and not to both: So an Indictment of Forceable Entry into a MeÅ¿Å¿uage exiÅ¿tent Liberum Tenementum of J. S. is not good for want of the Word ad Tunc, though the Participle exiÅ¿tens does Å¿trongly Imply that it was his HouÅ¿e at that time, 3 Cro. 754. Het. 73 Noy. 131. Palm. 426. Bridg. 68. 2 Cro. 214, & 610. Sid. 102. Lat. 109, &c. and my Lord Coke tells us in Calvin's CaÅ¿e 5. B. That Indictments of TreaÅ¿on of all others are the moÅ¿t CuriouÅ¿ly and Certainly Indicted and Penn'd; and all thoÅ¿e that I have Å¿een and obÅ¿erved, have Contained more Certainty than
the Indictment now before your LordÅ¿hip in Reginald Tuckers CaÅ¿e: The Indictment was, that he and Thomas Place apud Bridgwater, in Com. SomerÅ¿ett. praedict. CompaÅ¿Å¿averunt, to Kill and DepoÅ¿e the King, &c. And to bring their TreaÅ¿onable purpoÅ¿es to effect, they the Å¿aid Reginald Tucker and Thomas Place the Å¿ame Day and Year, at Bridgewater aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, againÅ¿t the King with a great Multitude of People, Arrayed in a Warlike manner, viz. with Swords, &c. Å¿e ipÅ¿os illicite & proditorie inÅ¿imul ad tunc & Ibidem Congregaverunt & AÅ¿Å¿emblaverunt & Guerram publicam Contra dictum Dominem Regem apud Bridgewater proedict. in Com. proedict. Dicto ViceÅ¿imo Die Junii anno primo Å¿upro dicto proditorie paraverunt ordinaverunt & Levaverunt; Å¿o in the Indictment of Gate as it is Å¿et forth at large in a Plea in Bar of Dower, brought by his Wife, he with Force and Arms, apud Villam de Ware, &c. aÅ¿Å¿embled with a great many PerÅ¿ons, & Bellum Crudele Contra Dictam Dominam Reginam apud Ware, praedict. ad tunc falÅ¿o & proditorie publicavit & Levavit ac in Å¿uper ad tunc & Ibidem falÅ¿o & proditorie, Proclaimed the Duke of Northumberland to be Lieutenant General of their Forces; & etiam falÅ¿o & proditorie apud Ware proedict. ad tunc, Proclaimed the Lady Jane Dudley Queen. This is in Bendlowes Reports, PubliÅ¿h't by Serjeant Rowe, fol. 55. placito 91. So in Earl of LeiceÅ¿ter's CaÅ¿e Plowd. Com. 385. the Indictment is laid much after the Å¿ame manner, and many other Indictments, which at preÅ¿ent I am unwilling to trouble your LordÅ¿hip with; and this being one of a new Form and of the FirÅ¿t ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion, I hope your LordÅ¿hip will hold it inÅ¿ufficient. And my Lord, when they go farther, and Å¿ay, Et Quilibet eorum proditorie Å¿uper Å¿e Å¿uÅ¿cepit eÅ¿Å¿e unum, there is no place or time alledged where that was done, which of neceÅ¿Å¿ity Å¿hould be mentioned: For it is a conÅ¿tant Rule in our Books, that what is IÅ¿Å¿uable ought to have a place where it may be tryed. Now this is IÅ¿Å¿uable, and the moÅ¿t material thing in the Indictment, is for compaÅ¿Å¿ing the King's Death. The Overt Acts are that ChriÅ¿topher Knightley the PriÅ¿oner, and Two others, did ConÅ¿ult to kill the King; and afterwards did agree how to do it, viz. by Forty HorÅ¿emen Quorum, theÅ¿e Å¿hou'd be Four, and every one of them did agree to be one; then comes the other Overt Act of Providing Arms for them. Now Å¿uppoÅ¿e they Å¿hould not prove the laÅ¿t, viz. the Providing Arms; then, my Lord, they muÅ¿t reÅ¿ort to one of the other Overt Acts, that theÅ¿e Four did ConÅ¿ult and Agree to Kill the King; or that theÅ¿e Four did agree, the manner how to do it, as is laid in the Indictment; and it is plain they muÅ¿t fail of proof of either of theÅ¿e, for by the not ProÅ¿ecuting any one of the Name of ChriÅ¿topher Knightley, but preferring a new Indictment, againÅ¿t one Alexander Knightley, it appears that ChriÅ¿topher Knightley was not there, and the proving theÅ¿e Three others making a ConÅ¿ult and Agreement, is not a proof of the Å¿ame Overt Act, that is laid in the Indictment as it ought to be by
the late Act; unleÅ¿s they can prove that a ConÅ¿ult of Three is a ConÅ¿ult of Four: and if it be anÅ¿wered, that it is alledged, that Quilibet eorum Å¿uper Å¿e Å¿uÅ¿cepit, then will that come to be IÅ¿Å¿uable and the moÅ¿t material part of the Indictment; and conÅ¿equently a place ought to have been laid where it Å¿hould be Tryed; this, my Lord, is a diÅ¿tinct Sentence of it Å¿elf, it is in a ParentheÅ¿is, and though you take it away the Å¿enÅ¿e of what remains is perfect and intire, and conÅ¿equently this Sentence is or Å¿hou'd be intire of it Å¿elf, and therefore ought certainly to be expreÅ¿t. BeÅ¿ides, if your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es, it is not poÅ¿itively laid, what theÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons Å¿everally undertook, to be there is indeed mention made before of Forty HorÅ¿emen, agreed upon to Å¿et upon the King, then comes the ParentheÅ¿is, Quorum Iidem ChriÅ¿tophorus Knightley, Robertus Lowick, AmbroÅ¿ius Rookwood & Carolus Cranburn forent Quatuor & quilibet eorum proditorie Å¿uper Å¿e Å¿uÅ¿cepit eÅ¿Å¿e unum: It is perhaps expreÅ¿t fully enough by the word Quorum, that it was agreed theÅ¿e Å¿hou'd be Four of the Forty HorÅ¿emen; but there wants the repetition of the word Quorum, to expreÅ¿s what they Å¿everally engaged to be; and the word & cannot joyn and connect the Sentences: For forent and Å¿uÅ¿cepit Differ not only in Number but alÅ¿o in Mood and TenÅ¿e, and the Å¿enÅ¿e is not neceÅ¿Å¿arily coherent; for it might be true, that the Majority of the Company might agree, theÅ¿e Å¿hou'd be Four, and yet they themÅ¿elves might not Å¿everally Ingage therein, and one or Å¿ome of them might undertake it, and yet the Company not agreed to it; and it cannot be mended by Intendment. There was Vaux's CaÅ¿e, in the 4 Rep. 44. He was Indicted for Murder, for perÅ¿wading a Man to take Cantharedes; it was laid, That he PerÅ¿wadebat eundem Nicholaum Recipere & Bibere Quendam potem mixtum cum Quodam veneo vocat Cantharedes; and the Indictment Å¿ays, Quod proedictas Nicholaas NeÅ¿ciens proedictum potem cum Veneno proedicto flore in toxicatum Å¿ed fidem ad Hibens Dicte perÅ¿waÅ¿ioni Willielmi ReÅ¿epit & Bibit; but does not Å¿ay, veneum proedictum, but yet it adds, Per quod praedictus Nicholaas imediate poÅ¿t Receptionem veneni proedicti, LanguiÅ¿h'd and Dyed here, one wou'd think was a Å¿ufficient Implication, that he took and drank the PoiÅ¿on; but it was Rul'd, that none of theÅ¿e words were Å¿ufficient to maintain the Indictment; for the matter of the Indictment ought to be plain, expreÅ¿s, and certain, and Å¿hall not be maintained by Argument or Implication, and therefore for want of thoÅ¿e words the Indictment was held inÅ¿ufficient, and the Man again Indicted for that Offence, and there Å¿eems much more in-certainty in this Indictment, and therefore I humbly pray your LordÅ¿hip that it may be QuaÅ¿h't.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower,
sp.p: My Lord, we think the Objection is fully put, and therefore we deÅ¿ire to have their AnÅ¿wer to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
We think, my Lord, this Objection will receive a very plain AnÅ¿wer. The Indictment Å¿ets forth, that at Å¿uch a Place the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar did imagine and compaÅ¿s the Death of the
King: There is a particular place where the imagining was, and that they to accompliÅ¿h that TreaÅ¿on, in compaÅ¿Å¿ing and imagining the Death of the King, did amongÅ¿t others poÅ¿tea eidem due anno apud parochiam praedictam, Meet and ConÅ¿ult, &c. So there's the Å¿ame place Å¿et forth again, wherein they did Meet and ConÅ¿ult of the Ways and Means, and Time and Place, when, where, and how to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King: And immediately it follows, & Conce Å¿erunt & agreaverunt, &c. that Forty Men, whereof they were to be Four, and every one of them undertook to be One, Å¿hould do Å¿o and Å¿o. Now, my Lord, Å¿ay they, It is not Å¿aid that the Agreement, that there Å¿hould be Forty Men to do it, was at the Å¿ame Time and Place where they did Meet and ConÅ¿ult about the Ways and Means: But my Lord, with SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, it is very plain, that the Agreement for Forty Men, and the particular Agreement for them to be of the Numberâª is but the effect of the ConÅ¿ultation that is mention'd juÅ¿t before: For it is Å¿aid, they ConÅ¿ulted how they Å¿hou'd do it, and they agreed to do it in this manner; the particular manner is Å¿et forth immediately afterthat, it is Å¿aid they did ConÅ¿ult of the Manner, Å¿o that, my Lord, it is part of the former Sentence; a particularizing of what they did agree upon at that ConÅ¿ultation; but it is no diÅ¿tinct Overt Act: If it had been a diÅ¿tinct Overt Act, then the CaÅ¿es that have been Cited by the Council, do Å¿how, that there Å¿hou'd be a particular time and place mentioned for every Overt Act, but this is only a part of that Overt Act, that was mentioned generally before: This tells you particularly what the means were they did agree upon, and the Sentence is not compleat till you have gone over this; Å¿o that, my Lord, with SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, it had been very Improper when they agreed at Å¿uch a Time and Place, of the means and ways how it Å¿hou'd be effected, then to Å¿et forth, that it was at the Å¿ame time and Place where they did ConÅ¿ult of the Ways and Means, that cannot be proper; for it is not laid at firÅ¿t, that there was any particular way propoÅ¿ed, but only in general, they ConÅ¿ulted of the Ways and Means; therefore, my Lord, all this that Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on has Å¿aid, will not be pertinent to this CaÅ¿e; it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to have been otherwiÅ¿e; it is but a part of the Sentence; and it is not compleat till you have gone over the Å¿everal particulars, as to the CaÅ¿e of a ReÅ¿cus, that is, the Offence upon which the matter is to be grounded; the Verbaravit and Vulneravit are not the Offence but the ReÅ¿meing; but where there is not one Sentence compleat, till you come to the end of theÅ¿e words, there it muÅ¿t be all taken together; Å¿o it is here, they ConÅ¿ulted of the Way, and agreed this to be the Way, which they Å¿et forth in particular: It is join'd to the former part of the Sentence, and the whole is not compleat without it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: With SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, my Lord, it cannot be otherwiÅ¿e, nor can they make it Å¿enÅ¿e otherwiÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: They Å¿ay you might, and Å¿hou'd have put in, Ad tunc & Ibidem.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p:
With SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, my Lord, I Å¿ay it cannot be repeated again: Indeed if you wou'd make it like the CaÅ¿e, as Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on wou'd have it, that Forty Men did agree to it, and Forty Men did it, it were neceÅ¿Å¿ary to name Time and Place, as it is in the CaÅ¿e of Murder; that he did agree to Murder him, and afterwards Knock't him on the Head, there you Å¿hou'd lay Time and Place where he agreed, and where he did the Act, for there is an Act done; but in this CaÅ¿e there is no Act done, but only an Agreement that Forty Å¿hou'd do it, whereof theÅ¿e Four were to be part of the Number. Now, they cry, you do not Å¿ay what theÅ¿e Four were to be for; Yes, we do, the Forty were to do Å¿uch an Act, and theÅ¿e were to be Four of that Forty, and every one of them undertook to be one, Å¿o that it cannot be expreÅ¿t otherwiÅ¿e then it is; for what they Å¿ay of the Indictments being not in the Å¿ame Form that other Indictments are, that will be no Argument at all; for it does not follow, that there muÅ¿t be one expreÅ¿t Form of Indictments, of right there are divers Forms of Indictments, and all of them good, becauÅ¿e Indictments are to be framed, according to the particular CaÅ¿e, and they cannot put me an InÅ¿tance of Å¿uch a particular CaÅ¿e as this. As to that of the miÅ¿take of the name of Knightley. that unqueÅ¿tionably can be no Objection at all; for how does it appear to the Court, that this againÅ¿t the Å¿ame PerÅ¿on that was before Indicted by the Name of ChriÅ¿topher, there may be another ChriÅ¿topher
â¢ or ought they know: But I will Å¿uppoÅ¿e, that the ConÅ¿ult was proved not as it is laid, that they were to be Four; but only that they were to be Three of them, it would be well enough againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, if he be proved to be one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: FirÅ¿t, we have here laid a time and place for the TreaÅ¿on alledged in the Indictment, and alÅ¿o for the Two Overt Acts, how, when, and where it was to be done, and the providing of Arms for it; and for this particular of the Forty Men, that they wou'd have us put the ad tunc & ibidem to that is but part of the Overt Act, which was before alledged for the firÅ¿t Overt Act mentioned, is the Meeting and ConÅ¿ulting, and there we lay both Time and Place; that on Å¿uch a Day, and at Å¿uch a Place, they did meet and ConÅ¿ult of the way and manner how to do Å¿uch an Act: And then we continue on the Sentence, by particularizing how it was to be effected; that they did agree there Å¿hou'd be Forty HorÅ¿emen to do it, whereof they were to be Four; this is but a part of the Overt Act, which is the ConÅ¿ulting and Agreeing upon the ways and means; this particular means agreedâª upon, being but the ReÅ¿ult and Effect of the ConÅ¿ultation before; Å¿o that we conceive there is no want of time or place, upon which to take IÅ¿Å¿ue in this CaÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p:
My Lord, I think with Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, there is nothing in their Objection, and I take it to have Received a full AnÅ¿wer already; yet I would ask one thing
of the Gentlemen of the other Å¿ide had the Sentence run without the Words de iis modis & mediis, &c. which follow after the word conÅ¿ultavit, and before the words & aggreavit; in this manner, That they did then and there TrayterouÅ¿ly treat, propoÅ¿e, conÅ¿ult and agree, that 40 HorÅ¿emen, or thereabouts, with Guns, and Å¿o forth. If then there had been any Colour to think it neceÅ¿Å¿ary, that it Å¿hou'd be laid in this manner, That they did then and there TrayterouÅ¿ly treat, and then and there TrayterouÅ¿ly propoÅ¿e, and then and there TrayterouÅ¿ly conÅ¿ult, and did then and there TrayterouÅ¿ly agree: and if not, then I wou'd deÅ¿ire them to tell me why then and there is more neceÅ¿Å¿ary to one Verb did agree, than it is to all the reÅ¿t, in Å¿ence and common Å¿peaking. The only uÅ¿e of a Conjunction Copulative, is to derive the force of Å¿ome Words in a Sentence foregoing, down to a Sentence following, to avoid repetition: And here, though after the ConÅ¿ultation be put many Words that relate to that matter by way of ParentheÅ¿is; yet the ad tunc & ibidem Å¿till does referr to all the Verbs following, being joyned by the Conjunction Copulative; it does not vary the CaÅ¿e at all, the putting in that ParentheÅ¿is; it is notwithÅ¿tanding but as one Sentence: and the Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that the ParentheÅ¿is Å¿tood outâª makes it very plain, there can be no Colour to Å¿ay there wanted a Repetition of the ad tunc & ibidem to every Verb.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: With Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to your LordÅ¿hips Judgment, there is no AnÅ¿wer made to this Objection: I do agree, if there had been Å¿everal Verbs and no other Words had intervened, that an Et wou'd have Coupled all together, and you need not have repeated ad tunc & ibidem to every one: But here is a Fact after the Verbs that makes one compleat, intire Sentence; and if this of the 40 Men were left out, it had been a good Sentence, that they did propoÅ¿e and treat how, where and when; that's a Sentence of it Å¿elf, the ConÅ¿ulting and the Treating of the Ways and Means: But then they Å¿ay, And they did agree and aÅ¿Å¿ent that 40 Å¿hou'd do it; now there is no neceÅ¿Å¿ity for the interpreting of theÅ¿e words, That they Å¿hou'd conÅ¿ult and agree at the Å¿ame place and time; there is no neceÅ¿Å¿ity to conjoyn this Agreement for the 40 Men with the ConÅ¿ultation; they might propoÅ¿e and conÅ¿ult at one time and place, and not agree, and afterwards agree at another time and place; it is not a Specification, or, as they call it, a Å¿pecifick Account of the ConÅ¿ultation, nor a neceÅ¿Å¿ary Effect of it, Å¿o as to make it neceÅ¿Å¿ary to joyn them together; they might meet and conÅ¿ult at one time and place; and at another time and place they might agree that 40 Å¿hou'd do it; and therefore when you Å¿ay at one time and place they did conÅ¿ult and propoÅ¿e, and afterwards they did agree; it is not neceÅ¿Å¿arily imply'd, that it muÅ¿t be at the Å¿ame time and place; and when it is not neceÅ¿Å¿arily imply'd, we think it neceÅ¿Å¿ary in Indictments, for Certainty-Å¿ake, to have ad tunc & ibidem inÅ¿erted again.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p:
My Lord, Mr. Sollicitor Å¿ays, That as to other Precedents, th â¢â¢ does not make it neceÅ¿Å¿ary that this Å¿hou'd be like them; and that it is no Argument that it ought to be Å¿o here. My Lord Coke, in Calvin's CaÅ¿e, tells us, That by Precedents the Law is known, and that Indictments of TreaÅ¿on are of all things the moÅ¿t curiouÅ¿ly Penn'd; and it is common to inferr the Law is Å¿o, becauÅ¿e uÅ¿ually it is Å¿o in the Precedents of Indictments. Mr. Sollicitor Å¿ays likewiÅ¿e, That there may be a ChriÅ¿topher Knightley beÅ¿ides an Alexander; but I cannot take that for an AnÅ¿wer to the Exception I urge, which is the want of ad tunc & ibidem at the Quorum, and the Quilibet for the Quilibet may come to be in QueÅ¿tion as the moÅ¿t material part of the Indictment, becauÅ¿e the Agreement of the Four upon the meeting of the Four is alledg'd as an Overt-Act: Now, with Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, they muÅ¿t prove the AÅ¿Å¿embly of the whole Four,
or they do not prove the Overt-Act expreÅ¿sly laid; then as to the Quilibet Å¿uÅ¿cepit, which is the moÅ¿t material part, it has no time nor place.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No Å¿ure, we do not need to prove all Four, for it is a diÅ¿tinct Offence in each; and if any one undertook, it is well enough againÅ¿t him; and for the time and place, we tell you, it is part of the former Sentence, and makes but an intire one.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: As for the ReÅ¿idue of the Verbs, if they had been omitted, it had been good Sence; but this is a perfect intire Sentence of itÅ¿elf, when it tells you what they conÅ¿ulted and treated off, as in the CaÅ¿e of the ReÅ¿cous that I put; if it had Å¿topt there, it had been a good Sentence without the Vulneraverunt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The ReÅ¿cous is the Offence in that CaÅ¿e, the other is diÅ¿tinct: But here, in this CaÅ¿e, nothing can be plainer than that all is one Act, as we have laid it, That at Å¿uch a time and place they did conÅ¿ult and treat of the Ways and Means; but then there is no Agreement mentioned till after we have Å¿aid they did conÅ¿ult of the Ways and Means, and did agree that this Å¿hou'd be the Way: This is certainly one intire Sentence that Å¿hows what the Agreement was upon the ConÅ¿ultation as the ReÅ¿ult of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: As to what Sir Bartholomew Shower Å¿ays, That we ought to repeat the ad tunc & ibidem, unleÅ¿s the Å¿ence of the Words implies a NeceÅ¿Å¿ity that the ConÅ¿ultation and the Agreement Å¿hould be at one time and place. My Lord, there can be nothing in that, for it does not ariÅ¿e from the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of the thing one way or t'other; but we take it as an intire Sentence, and that the whole Matter is Å¿ufficiently connected and laid to one time and place, though it might be divided, it muÅ¿t be taken, as alledged, to be one intire Fact, or elÅ¿e it Recurrs to the Å¿ame Objection, that ad tunc & ibidem muÅ¿t as well be put to every Verb; for 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible they might propoÅ¿e at one time and place, and conÅ¿ult at another, and debate at another, as well as agree at another: So that nothing is to be argued from the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of the thing more in one CaÅ¿e than the other; for one Man might propoÅ¿e it in one place, and the reÅ¿t might then Å¿hake their heads at it, and then they might again meet and conÅ¿ult at another place, and afterwards agree at a third: But when it is Å¿aid then and there they did meet, conÅ¿ult and agree, it cannot be underÅ¿tood but that the Agreement was at the Å¿ame time and place with the meeting and conÅ¿ult.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: But this can be no AnÅ¿wer that Mr. Cowper gives now, for PropoÅ¿ing, and ConÅ¿ulting, and Treating, and Debating, are all of the Å¿ame Å¿ignification, for one Man's propoÅ¿ing to another; and the other's propoÅ¿ing to him, is ConÅ¿ulting, Treating and Debating; but now ConÅ¿ulting and Agreeing are different things.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: So is PropoÅ¿ing and ConÅ¿ulting; One may propoÅ¿e, but there muÅ¿t be at leaÅ¿t Two to conÅ¿ult: there is that nice Difference between them.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Every one muÅ¿t agree for himÅ¿elf, and that muÅ¿t be certainly laid with Time and Place, let the PropoÅ¿al and ConÅ¿ultation be what it will.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on puts that CaÅ¿e in Dyer upon an Indictment of Murder, That on Å¿uch a Day, and at Å¿uch a Place, the Party made an AÅ¿Å¿ault upon the perÅ¿ons Å¿lain, & percuÅ¿Å¿it; but does not Å¿ay, Et ad tunc & ibidem percuÅ¿Å¿it, and for not alledging that the Indictment was held nought.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, that is a different CaÅ¿e from this, becauÅ¿e inÅ¿ultum fecit, and the percuÅ¿Å¿it, are different Crimes; there is a great Difference between an AÅ¿Å¿ault and a Stroke: But here it is, That they did PropoÅ¿e and ConÅ¿ult of the Ways and Means, and agreed upon this particular Way; that is the Å¿ame thing; it is not an intire Sentence till you come to the end of it, then it is compleat when you Å¿how what was the Effect of the ConÅ¿ultation; what they were agreed upon, and not till then.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: A Man's holding up his Hand is an AÅ¿Å¿ault, but he muÅ¿t actually Å¿trike to be Guilty of Murder: So a Man may debate, and yet not agree; it is the Agreement that is the TreaÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Read the Indictment.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.q:
