cum Bombardis, Å¿clopis & Å¿clopetis, pulvere bombardico, & globulis plumbeis oneratâ & cum gladiis, enÅ¿ibus & aliis Armis armatâ inÅ¿idiati forent & eÅ¿Å¿ent in Å¿ubÅ¿eÅ¿Å¿u, AnglicÃ¨ in AmbuÅ¿h, ad eundem Dominum Regem in Rheda Å¿ua, AnglicÃ¨ his Coach, exiÅ¿ten quando foris iret invadendâ Quodque quidem & competens numerus de hominibus illis Å¿ic armatâ in Å¿atellites, AnglicÃ¨ the Guards, ipÅ¿ius Domini Regis eum tunc attendend & Å¿ecum exiÅ¿tenâ aggreÅ¿Å¿i forent & eos expugnarent & devincerent, dum alii eorundem hominum Å¿ic armatâ ipÅ¿um Dominum Regem percuterent, interficerent, occiderent & murdrarent.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: The ConÅ¿ult is like the AÅ¿Å¿ault, and the Agreement is like the Stroke.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: It is a nice CaÅ¿e as you wou'd have it, but I think it is very natural as the King's Councel put it at firÅ¿t; they lay the ConÅ¿ultation of the Ways and Means how it Å¿hou'd be done, and then they conclude that thus it Å¿hall be done: all which makes but one intire thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: They Å¿ay they met that day at St. Paul Covent-Garden, that's in the beginning, and did conÅ¿ult how to Kill the King; and they conÅ¿ented and agreed among themÅ¿elves, that it Å¿hou'd be done in this manner: Does not this referr to both Time and Place in the beginning? It is a continuing on of the Å¿ame Sentence, and makes all but one and the Å¿ame Act; it is the ReÅ¿ult of the ConÅ¿ultation at that time and place.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: But, my Lord, it might be at another place: they might ConÅ¿ult at one place, and Conclude at another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: But it is laid to be at the Å¿ame place, for no other place does appear, and it is one continued Sentence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: You wou'd make the Repetition Å¿o frequent and reiterated, that it wou'd become abÅ¿urd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Indeed I do not know what theÅ¿e Gentlemen wou'd have.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: We wou'd have this Indictment as all others are, the Precedents are as we Å¿ay, and we hope this Å¿hall purÅ¿ue 'em, or elÅ¿e be quaÅ¿ht.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Look ye here, Sir Bartholomew Shower; SuppoÅ¿e this part Å¿hou'd not be right, that will not Vitiate the whole Indictment.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: But your LordÅ¿hip wont Å¿uffer them to give Evidence of that part that is Vitious.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; it comes within the firÅ¿t Words of the Time and Place laid; they may give Evidence of itâª becauÅ¿e this is but a Å¿etting forth the Manner agreed upon for the Execution of the DeÅ¿ign that was before conÅ¿ulted and treated off; it is comprehended in the former Words; and if they had omitted this out of the Indictment, the Indictment had been never the worÅ¿e; there had been a Å¿ufficient Overt-Act alledged to prove the CompaÅ¿Å¿ing and Imagining the Death of the King; for if People at Å¿uch a place and
time meet, and propoÅ¿e the way and means how to effect it, do you think the Indictment wou'd not be good enough without laying the particular means agreed upon? Certainly it had been well enough if this had been omitted. Do you think they cannot give in Evidence this as a Proof of the Overt Act? Certainly they may.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: The QueÅ¿tion will be, my Lord, then upon the whole, Whether the ConcluÅ¿ion of the Indictment, contra legiantiae Å¿uae Debitum, Å¿hall be taken DiÅ¿tributively to every Fact, and if Å¿o, then there ought to be time and place alledg'd to every Fact.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: SuppoÅ¿e you lay Å¿everal Overt Acts, and prove but one yet he is to be found Guilty of the High TreaÅ¿on, which is the Imagination, and CompaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death of the King, which is the Crime laid in the Indictment; then Å¿uppoÅ¿e this was left out of the Indictment they might give it in Evidence as a Proof of the Overt Act, that is well laid for time and place; and therefore though it be expreÅ¿s'd, and not Å¿o fully and particularly laid, we cannot quaÅ¿h the Indictment for it, becauÅ¿e the Indictment would have been good, though that had been omitted.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: That is certainly true, it is no CauÅ¿e for quaÅ¿hing the Indictment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: The Indictments againÅ¿t the Regicides were for CompaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death of the King, and they gave in Evidence that he was put to Death, though they charg'd in the Indictment only the CompaÅ¿Å¿ing and Imagining the Death of the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Ay Å¿ure, That is an Overt Act with a WitneÅ¿s, the Indictment was not laid for Murdering the King, but for CompaÅ¿Å¿ing his Death, which is the TreaÅ¿on according to the Act of Parliament of 25th, Ed. the 3d. and as an Overt Act they gave the cutting off his Head in Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The Indictment Å¿ays, they CompaÅ¿s'd and Imagined the Kings death, and they agreed to do it in this manner; if this be not all one intire Sentence I know not what is

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: As to your CaÅ¿e, Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on, which you quote out of Dyer, it is poÅ¿Å¿ible a man may make an AÅ¿Å¿ault at one time, and at another time make an AÅ¿Å¿ault and give a Å¿troke, but this is all one Act, it does but Å¿pecifie what was generally conÅ¿ulted off and propoÅ¿ed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Pray, do you think a man may Demurr upon a Common Action of Battery where, 'tis Å¿aid firÅ¿t, at Å¿uch a time and place, InÅ¿ultum fecit & verberavti, vulneravit, becauÅ¿e there is not a place Å¿et to every word.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Indictments ought to be very curiouÅ¿ly Penn'd, and what is good in an Action will not be good in an Indictment, with Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: But Å¿uppoÅ¿e you Å¿how'd it for CauÅ¿e upon Å¿pecial Demurr.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot tell what it wou'd amount unto.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: You cannot quaÅ¿h the Indictment at this time, that is not poÅ¿Å¿ible, becauÅ¿e the Indictment is good as to the reÅ¿t, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing this was not Å¿o well as it might be.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, I am in your LordÅ¿hips Judgment, whether they Å¿hall be admitted to give in Evidence this particular thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: They may certainly give in Evidence, the Agreement to have 40 men to kill the King, as a proof of the ConÅ¿ultation, Agreement and ConÅ¿ent to kill the King; and the ConÅ¿enting to have 40 HorÅ¿emen is an Evidence of their treating, propoÅ¿ing and conÅ¿ulting to kill the King. Then for your Objection of Quilibet Å¿uÅ¿cepit to be one, that is well enough, it is all Å¿till but one Sentence.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: One of which is it, for they have not laid in the Indictment what it is, whether it be one of the Four, or one of the Forty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Whether it be one of the Four, or the Forty is not material, for cannot one be found Guilty and the reÅ¿t Acquitted? the one is not charg'd with the Act of the other, but they are Å¿everal Offences, and each muÅ¿t anÅ¿wer for himÅ¿elf in all Indictments. Offences are Å¿everal. SuppoÅ¿e an Indictment of ConÅ¿piracy, and it is laid in the Indictment that Four did ConÅ¿pire, can't you prove that two ConÅ¿pired? no QueÅ¿tion you may. It is not certainly neceÅ¿Å¿ary that every one Å¿hou'd be proved to have ConÅ¿pired. SuppoÅ¿e it were alledged that Four did beat a man, and does not Å¿ay Quilibet eorum beat him, you may give in Evidence that one did beat him.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: No QueÅ¿tion of that in CaÅ¿e of a Battery, but in the CaÅ¿e of a ConÅ¿piracy there muÅ¿t be more than one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Nay, I will ask you even in an Action of ConÅ¿piracy, where the very GiÅ¿t of the Action is ConÅ¿piring together, cannot two be found Guilty and the reÅ¿t Acquitted? In Riots there muÅ¿t be Three or more It may be you'll lay Ten, but it is Å¿ufficient; I hope, if you prove it upon any Three of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The Difference is betwixt Contracts and Crimes, for Contracts they are joynt, but Crimes they are in their own Nature Å¿everal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: BeÅ¿ides, my Lord, though they be out of time, yet this is not to the Abatement of the Indictment; but to the Evidence; how do they know, but we will give it in Evidence that ChriÅ¿topher Knightly was one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on moves it as a Caveat againÅ¿t your giving it in Evidence.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: If in an Outlawry againÅ¿t divers they leave out theÅ¿e words, Nec eorum aliquis comperuit, that is every day held to be nought, and for that ReaÅ¿on we Å¿ay, the Quilibet eorum Å¿uÅ¿cepit is neceÅ¿Å¿ary too, and without being laid cannot be given in Evidence, and if it be laid, it ought to have time and place.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: The Default of appearance muÅ¿t be a Å¿everal thing, and when he lays it joyntly non comperuerunt, it may be true that all did not appear, if any one made Default; but when you Charge men with a Fact done, though in the plural number, yet it is a diÅ¿tinct Å¿eparate Charge upon every one.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Robert Lowick thoÅ¿e men that thou Å¿halt hear call'd, and perÅ¿onally appear, are to paÅ¿s between our Soveraign Lord the King, and you, upon Tryal of your Life and Death; if therefore you will Challenge them, or any of them; your time is to Å¿peak to them as they come to the Book to be Å¿worn, and before they be Å¿worn. George Ford.

sp.speaker: Cryer.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p:
Oyez, If any one can Inform My Lord's the King's JuÅ¿tices of Oyer and Terminer, the King's Serjeant or the Kings Attorney General, before this InqueÅ¿t be taken of the High TreaÅ¿on, whereof the PriÅ¿oner at the Barr Å¿tands Indicted, let them come forth, and they Å¿hall be heard, for now the PriÅ¿oner Å¿tands at the Bar upon his Deliverance; and all others that are bound by Recognizance to give Evidence againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, let them come forth and give their Evidence, or elÅ¿e they forfeit their Recognizance. The Names of the Twelve Sworn are theÅ¿e;
George Ford. EÅ¿q Jur.
Thomas Trench. EÅ¿q Jur.
John Wolfe. EÅ¿q Jur.
John Raymond. EÅ¿q Jur.
George Hawes. EÅ¿q Jur.
Matthew Bateman. EÅ¿q Jur.

Elias Fletcher. Gent. Jur.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p:
Robert Lowick hold up thy hand; which he did. You that are Sworn, look upon the PriÅ¿oner and hearken to his CauÅ¿e. He Å¿tands Indicted by the Name of Robert Lowick, late of the PariÅ¿h of St. Paul Convent-Garden, in the County of MiddleÅ¿ex, Gentleman; for that he, together with ChriÅ¿topher Knightley, late of the Å¿ame PariÅ¿h and County, Gentleman; AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, late of the Å¿ame PariÅ¿h and County, Gentleman; and Charles Cranburne, late of the Å¿ame PariÅ¿h and County, Yeoman; not having the Fear of God in their Hearts, nor weighing the Duty of their Allegiance, but being moved and Å¿educed by the InÅ¿tigation of the Devil, as falÅ¿e Traytors againÅ¿t the moÅ¿t Serene, moÅ¿t IlluÅ¿trious, moÅ¿t Mild and moÅ¿t Excellent Prince, our Soveraign Lord, WILLIAM the III. by the Grace of God, of England, Scotland, France and Ireland King, Defender of the Faith, &c. their Supreme, True and Rightful, Lawful and Undoubted Lord; the Cordial Love and True, and Due Obedience, Fidelity and Allegiance, which every Subject of our Å¿aid Lord the King, that now is, towards him our Å¿aid Lord the King, Å¿hould then of right, ought to bear, withdrawing and utterly to extinguiÅ¿h, intending and Contriving, and with all their Å¿trength PurpoÅ¿ing, DeÅ¿igning and ConÅ¿piring the Government of this
Kingdom of England, under him our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, our right, duly, happily, and very well eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed, altogether to Å¿ubvert, change, and alter; as alÅ¿o the Å¿ame our Lord the King to Death and final DeÅ¿truction to putâª and bring, and his faithful Subjects, and the Freemen of this Kingdom of England, into intollerable and moÅ¿t miÅ¿erable Slavery to Lewis the French King, to Å¿ubengate and inthral, the 10th day of February, in the Seventh Year of the Reign of our Soveraign Lord the King that now is, and diverÅ¿e other days and times, as well before, as after, at the PariÅ¿h of St. Pauls Covent-garden aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, falÅ¿ely, malitiouÅ¿ly, deviliÅ¿hly, and traiterouÅ¿ly, did CompaÅ¿s, Imagine, and Contrive, PurpoÅ¿e, DeÅ¿ign, Intend, our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, to Kill, Slay, and Murder; and miÅ¿erable Slaughter among the faithful Subjects of our Å¿aid Lord the King throughout this whole Kingdom of England, to make, and cauÅ¿e, and the Å¿ame their moÅ¿t wicked, impious, and devilliÅ¿h TreaÅ¿ons, and traiterous CompaÅ¿Å¿ings, Contrivances, and PurpoÅ¿es aforeÅ¿aid, to fulfil, perfect, and bring to effect, they the Å¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightly, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburn, and very many other falÅ¿e Traitors to the Jurors unknown; afterwards, to wit the Å¿ame Tenth Day of February, in the Year aboveÅ¿aid, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, and divers other Days and Times, as well before, as after; there, and elÅ¿ewhere, in the Å¿ame County, falÅ¿ly, malitiouÅ¿ly, adviÅ¿edly, Å¿ecretly, and traiterouÅ¿ly; and with Force and Arms did meet together, propoÅ¿e, treat, conÅ¿ult, conÅ¿ent, and agree, him our Å¿aid Soveraign Lord the King, that now is, by lying in Wait and Wild, to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate, kill, and murder, and that execrable, horrid, and deteÅ¿table AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination and Killing, the Å¿ooner to execute and perpetrate; afterwards, to wit, the Å¿ame Day and Year, and divers other Days and Times, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid; traiterouÅ¿ly did treat, propoÅ¿e, and conÅ¿ult, of the Ways, Manner, and Means, and the Time and Place, where, when, how, and in what manner, our Å¿aid Lord the King, Å¿o by lying in Wait, the more eaÅ¿ily they might kill; and did conÅ¿ent, agree, and aÅ¿Å¿ent, that Forty HorÅ¿emen, or thereabouts; of whom the Å¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightly, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburn, would be Four; and every one of them traiterouÅ¿ly took upon himÅ¿elf to be one, with Guns, Muskets, and PiÅ¿tols, loaden with Gun powder and Leaden Bullets; and, with Swords, Rapiers, and other Arms, armed, Å¿hould lye in Wait, and be in AmbuÅ¿h, the Å¿ame our Lord the King in his Coach being, when he Å¿hould go abroad to Å¿et upon, and that a certain and competent number of thoÅ¿e Men Å¿o armed Å¿hould Å¿et upon the Guards of him our Å¿aid Lord the King then attending on him, and being with him, and Å¿hould fight with them, and overcome them, whilÅ¿t others of the Å¿ame Men Å¿o arm'd, him, our Å¿aid Lord the King, to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate, kill, Å¿lay, and murder: and they the Å¿aid ChriÅ¿toÅ¿topher Knightly, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburn, their TreaÅ¿ons, and all their Traiterous Intentions, DeÅ¿igns, and Contrivances aforeÅ¿aid, to execute, perpetrate, fulfil, and bring to effect afterwards, to wit the aforeÅ¿aid 10th day of February,
in the Seventh Year aboveÅ¿aid, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, divers HorÅ¿es, and very many Arms, Guns, PiÅ¿tols, Rapiers, and Swords, and other Weapons; Ammunition, and Warlike things, and Military InÅ¿truments, falÅ¿ly, malitiouÅ¿ly, Å¿ecretly, and traiterouÅ¿ly did obtain, buy, gather together, and procure; and did cauÅ¿e to be bought, obtain'd, gather'd together, and procured with that Intent, them, in and and about the deteÅ¿table, horrid, and execrable AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, Killing, and Murder of our Å¿aid Lord the King, that now is, as aforeÅ¿aid, to uÅ¿e, imploy, and beÅ¿tow; and the Å¿ame promiÅ¿es the more Å¿afely, and certainly to execute, do, and perpetrate, he the aforeÅ¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightly, with one Edward King, lately of High TreaÅ¿on, in contriving and conÅ¿piring the Death of our Å¿aid Lord the King that now is, duly convicted and attainted, by the ConÅ¿ent and AÅ¿Å¿ent of divers of the Traitors and ConÅ¿pirators aforeÅ¿aid, the Å¿aid tenth day of February, in the Seventh Year aboveÅ¿aid, traiterouÅ¿ly did go and come to the place propoÅ¿ed, where Å¿uch intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, Killing, and Murder, of our Å¿aid Lord the King, by lying in Wait, Å¿hould be done, perpetrated and committed, to view, Å¿ee, and obÅ¿erve, the Conveniency and FitneÅ¿s of the Å¿ame place for Å¿uch lying in Wait, AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and Killing, there to be done, perpetrated and committed; and that place being Å¿o viewed and obÅ¿erved afterwards, to wit, the Å¿ame day and year, his ObÅ¿ervations thereof to Å¿everal of the Å¿aid Traitors and ConÅ¿pirators, did relate and impart, to wit, at the PariÅ¿h aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, and the aforeÅ¿aid Charles Cranburn, the Å¿ame Day and Year there in order, the Å¿ame execrable, horrid, and deteÅ¿table AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and Killing of our Å¿aid Lord the King, by the Traitors and ConÅ¿pirators aforeÅ¿aid, the more readily and boldly to execute, perpetrate, and commit, adviÅ¿edly, knowingly, and traiterouÅ¿ly, did bear and carry among divers of thoÅ¿e Traitors and ConÅ¿pirators forwards and backwards, from Å¿ome to others of them, a LiÅ¿t of the Names of divers men of thoÅ¿e who were deÅ¿ign'd and appointed, our Å¿aid Lord the King, Å¿o as aforeÅ¿aid, by lying in Wait to kill and murder, againÅ¿t the Duty of the Allegiance of them the Å¿aid ChriÅ¿topher Knightly, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburn; and againÅ¿t the Peace of our Å¿aid Soveraign Lord the King that now is, his Crown and Dignity, as alÅ¿o againÅ¿t the form of the Statute in Å¿uch CaÅ¿e made and provided: Upon this Indictment, he has been arraigned, and thereunto hath pleaded Not Guilty; and for his Trial hath put himÅ¿elf upon God and the Country, which Country you are: your Charge is to inquire, whether he be Guilty of the High TreaÅ¿on
whereof he Å¿tands indicted, or Not Guilty; if you find him Guilty, you are to inquire, what Goods or Chattels, Lands or Tenements, he had at the time of the High TreaÅ¿on committed, or at any time Å¿ince, to your Knowledge. If you find him Not Guilty, you are to inquire whether he fled for it, if you find he fled for it, you are to inquire of his Goods and Chattels, as as if you had found him Guilty; if you find him Not Guilty, and that he did not fly for it, you are to Å¿ay Å¿o, and no more; and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mountague.
sp.p: May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury, this is an Indictment of High TreaÅ¿on againÅ¿t Robert Lowick, PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, and the Indictment does charge him with compaÅ¿Å¿ing and imagining the Death of the King, and endeavouring to Å¿ubvert the Government, and inÅ¿lave this Kingdom of England, and bring it under French Tyranny and Slavery, and the Indictment Å¿ets forth that Robert Lowick, the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, the Tenth of February, met Å¿everal falÅ¿e Traitors, and there conÅ¿ulted and treated how to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate his MajeÅ¿ty; and agreed, that 40 HorÅ¿emen to get together, Å¿ome to attack the Guards, while others were to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King in his Coach; and the Indictment charges him likewiÅ¿e, with getting together HorÅ¿es and Arms for this purpoÅ¿e, to this he hath pleaded Not Guilty. We will call our Evidence, and prove the Fact againÅ¿t him, and we do not doubt but you will do your Duty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, and you Gentlemen that are Å¿worn, this is an Indictment of High TreaÅ¿on, in conÅ¿piring and compaÅ¿Å¿ing the Death and DeÅ¿truction of the King, the nature of our Evidence againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar.

You will hear Gentlemen by the WitneÅ¿Å¿es that about ChriÅ¿tmas laÅ¿t a ConÅ¿piracy and DeÅ¿ign was Å¿et on foot to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, and accordingly to accompliÅ¿h it, there were Å¿everal perÅ¿ons Å¿ent over from France by the late King James, who were part of his Guards, and particularly Sir George Barclay was to be the Head of them; he was a Lieutenant of the Guards there, and he was Å¿ent over in January laÅ¿t, and there were a great many Troopers Å¿ent over, who were to be under his Direction, particularly Mr. Harris, who will give you an account, that he was Å¿ent over by order of King James, and he was told particularly King James had a Service for him to do in England,
and he hop'd it might be an opportunity to advance him. He was to obÅ¿erve the Orders of Sir George Barclay, and by what Token he Å¿hould know him; he was to meet him in Covent Garden, and he was told he might find him there twice a week in the Square, about Å¿ix a Clock after it was dark; and that he might know him, he told him, he would have his White Handerchief hanging out of his Pocket, accordingly Mr. Harris came over, and Mr. Hare came with him, and they came and did meet with Sir George Barclay, and they, together with Sir George Barclay, and Å¿everal others here in England, Mr. Porter, Mr. Charnock, and Sir William Parkyns, did enter into ConÅ¿ultation how to effect it; there were Å¿everal Meetings about it, and you will find the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar was at Å¿everal Meetings to that purpoÅ¿e, and they did undertake, among them, to provide Å¿o many Men as might make about the Number of 40, which they thought Å¿ufficient for the execuion of this DeÅ¿ign.

Gentlemen, you will hear that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar did treat with Å¿everal perÅ¿ons to be ingaged in it; particularly, about the 5th of February, he Å¿ent to one Bertram, and askt him, if he would be ingaged in a DeÅ¿ign for King James's Service that was quickly to be executed, without asking of QueÅ¿tions, and afterwards I think he undertook he would; Å¿o about the 14th February he met him again, and that was the day before the firÅ¿t time they intended to attack the Kingâª and then being Å¿o near the time when it was to be executed, he thought it proper to acquaint him with the thing he had ingag'd him in, and he did acquaint him, that the next morning they were to be ready to attack the King and his Guards, and bid him be Å¿ure to get his Boots and other things ready for that purpoÅ¿e, and he gave him a Guinea in order to it. Bertram, it Å¿eems, on the 15th of February did not come, and the King it Å¿eems did not go abroad that day, Å¿o they were diÅ¿appointed at that time; but the Sunday after Bertram met him, and Mr. Lowick complained that he had not come upon the Saturday according as he had undertaken; and he told him it would have been the Å¿ame thing, he would have diÅ¿appointed them if the King had been in the Field.

Gentlemen, you Å¿hall find, that as he thus engaged Mr. Bertram, Å¿o he was to provide Å¿everal others; and he did declare, that at his own Charge he had got 2 or 3, he complained of it as a HardÅ¿hip put upon him, that whereas Mr. Harris had 6 s. a day SubÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and was only to take care of himÅ¿elf, he, Mr. Lowick, had at his own Charges ingaged and provided Å¿everal.

You will find Gentlemen that Mr. Rookwood, who was tried YeÅ¿terday, had Å¿everal Meetings about it, with Mr. Lowick and Mr. Harris; they did think it to be a barbarous thing: but however they were reÅ¿olved to obey Orders, and the PriÅ¿oner in particular Å¿aid he wou'd obey Orders, tho he thought it a very wicked thing.

Gentlemen, you will find by the Evidence how the Matter was carried on; the PriÅ¿oner was to be engaged in it, and did not only imbarque himÅ¿elf in PerÅ¿on, but engaged others, and did treat with them about it. We Å¿hall call our WitneÅ¿Å¿es, who will give you a full account of it, and then we Å¿hall leave it with you, who we queÅ¿tion not will do JuÅ¿tice: FirÅ¿t call George Harris; who appeared and was Å¿worn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray will you give an account to my Lord and the Jury, what you know of the intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and what part the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar had in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Begin from the firÅ¿t, and tell your whole Knowledg as you did YeÅ¿terday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Harris.
sp.p: On the fourteenth of January, New Stile, I was ordered to wait King James at Dinner; after Dinner was over, I was called in, where was Coll. Parker, and Mr. Hare, at the Å¿ame time, and King James told me he was very Å¿enÅ¿ible of the good Service I had done him; and now he had an opportunity of doing Å¿omething for me: I was to go into England, and there to be Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿ted, and I was to follow the Orders of Sir George Barclay; the King told me I Å¿hou'd find Sir George Barclay in Covent-Garden, with a White Hanker cheif hanging out of his Pocket, on Mondays and ThurÅ¿days between the Hours of Å¿ix and Å¿even in the Evening, and that was the Å¿ign I was to know him by, and he ordered me to go to Mr. Caroll, that is Secretary to the late Queen, and Coll. Parher went along with me, and he ordered me ten LewedÃ³res, and Mr. Hare as much, which Mr. Caroll gave us; and if that were not Å¿ufficient, or if we were Wind-bound at Calice, we had Orders to apply to the PreÅ¿ident of Calice to be furniÅ¿h'd with what we wanted: Accordingly we went, and the Wind not Å¿erving when we came to Calice, we were forc'd to Å¿tay there, and our Charges were paid to our Landlady by the PreÅ¿ident of Calice, according to the Order we received at St. Germains; when the Wind Å¿erved fair we went on Board, and came to Rumney-MarÅ¿h, to one Mr. Hunt's HouÅ¿e, and from thence he furniÅ¿h'd us with a Couple of HorÅ¿es, and we came the Sandy-way to one Mr. Tucker's, and from thence to Mr. CroÅ¿s's, and from thence to Graves-end, and from thence to London: We came up in the Night-Tide, and being late when we came to Town. Sunday Night we lay at an Inn at the lower-end of Gracious-Å¿treet; the next Day we went to look for Sir George Barclay, but not finding him in Covent-Garden, according to what King James told us, I admired at it; but one Mr. Birkenhead meeting my Comrade the next day, Å¿aid Sir George Barclay deÅ¿ired to Å¿ee us, and appointed us to meet him, which we did that Night, where Sir George Barclay ask'd us how the King and Queen, Prince and PrinceÅ¿s did; he told us at that time he had no Money for us, but in a few Days we Å¿hou'd have Money; and accordingly he Å¿ent us Money. We had five Guineas but it was at twice, two Guineas at one time and three at another, and this was for a Months SubÅ¿iÅ¿tence at Five Shillings a Day, Guineas going then at Thirty Shillings. And afterwards when Major Holmes delivered the HorÅ¿e, upon Saturday the fifteenth, we had another Guinea that made up what we had to be Å¿ix Shillings a Day when we had HorÅ¿es, and five Shillings a Day when we had none: and as for Mr. Lowick, the firÅ¿t Saturday which was deÅ¿igned for the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, I happened to be at Mr. Counter's Lodgings in Holbourn, a Confectioners; and there I Å¿ee Mr. Lowick come in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Who Lodged there, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: Sir George Barclay and Mr. Counter had Lodgings there, and Mr. Lowick came in there, but I cannot Å¿ay he Å¿taid there any time, I think he went out preÅ¿ently afterwards. The next Week I met Mr. Lowick in Red-Lion-Fields and diÅ¿courÅ¿ed with him there about this Matter, and I told him what a barbarous and inhumane thing it was that we Å¿hou'd be the Murderers of the Prince of Orange, and that it wou'd render us odious to the World, and that we Å¿hould be a continual Reproach to our Selves; he did agree it was Å¿o: But in concluÅ¿ion Mr. Lowick Å¿aid he would obey Orders, and he Å¿aid Sir George Barclay he was Å¿ure wou'd not do it without Orders. That Day when we were walking out we met Sir George Barclay and Major Holmes riding in the High-way up towards IÅ¿lington, and we Å¿poke to him, for Mr. Lowick told me the Thing was diÅ¿covered, and his Name was given up, and other Gentlemens, and I think another; and Å¿o he told me that one HarriÅ¿on had told him of it, and forewarn'd him that Night from lying in his Lodging; and he told him that he believed it wou'd not be Å¿afe for the reÅ¿t to lye in their Lodgings, or to that effect.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When he Å¿aid he wou'd obey Orders, What was the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: We were talking of Murdering the Prince of Orange; and not only that, but I do believe that Mr. Lowick is Å¿o Å¿enÅ¿ible that what I Å¿ay is true, and he is a Man of Å¿o much ConÅ¿cience and Honour, that he will not contradict any thing that I affirm or have Å¿aid here. On Saturday the Two and Twentieth we dined at the CaÅ¿tle, a Tavern or a Cook's Shop, at the end of Red-Lyon-Street. I was much in a Sweat, and he ask'd me what made me Å¿o? I told him I had been getting Captain Rookwood's Party ready; and I told him laughing, that Captain Rookwood Å¿aid I Å¿hou'd be his Ayd du Camp, and Å¿o I was getting the Men together: Å¿ays he to me, you may very well do it, for you have Six Shillings a day, and I have nothing. Mr. Lowick, you know what I Å¿ay to be true, I know not why you lift up your hands; but you did tell me I might very well do it, having Six Shillings a day, and you had nothing, and yet brought a couple of Men at your own Charge, and that their HorÅ¿es could not be diÅ¿charged unleÅ¿s you went. TheÅ¿e were his Words, my Lord, or to this effect.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What do do mean by being diÅ¿charged?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: I mean this, that I believed he paid for them; and they were waiting at a HouÅ¿e till he came.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Why were they to be diÅ¿charged that day?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: The ReaÅ¿on why they were to be diÅ¿charged that day was, becauÅ¿e Captain Rookwood had told him before, that the Prince of Orange did not go out that day; and therefore we went together to walk towards IÅ¿lington.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: What day was that?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: The Å¿econd Saturday that it was to have been executed. I was not a Spy upon any Man's actions: I cannot tell what they did any more than I tell you: I do not wrong you any way in the World, Sir, I am Å¿ure on it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: When was it that you Å¿poke with Mr. Lowick about Murdering the King?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: It was Monday, TueÅ¿day, WedneÅ¿day, or ThurÅ¿day, I cannot be exact to the day, but it was one of theÅ¿e days, after the firÅ¿t Saturday; I cannot be poÅ¿itive what the day was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well, it was between the two days?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: How did you know of that DeÅ¿ign of Murdering the King?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: I was inform'd of it by Captain Rookwood the firÅ¿t Saturday, and I met Mr. Lowick and had this DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about it; and afterwards they informed me that Mr. La Rue did not lie at his Lodgings, and the thing was diÅ¿covered, and they believed that Rue had diÅ¿covered it: And I deÅ¿ire you'll call Mr. La Rue as to this Matter; for I believe he will own it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: How came you to truÅ¿t him with Å¿uch a DiÅ¿courÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: BecauÅ¿e we met there at Counter's Lodgings, and we had Å¿everal times DiÅ¿courÅ¿es of it; there was Major Bernard and Captain Rookwood beÅ¿ides, and I always declared againÅ¿t it, as a barbarous inhumane thing, not to be anÅ¿wer'd before God or Man, and that we Å¿hou'd be odious to all the World if the thing were effected, as I believed it wou'd not be. I wou'd never Å¿hew my Head after Å¿uch a thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember who began the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of this matter?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: I cannot tell that. I can't come to every particular.

sp.speaker: Sir Barth. Shower.
sp.p: You Å¿aid juÅ¿t now, you apprehended Mr. Lowick to be a Man of ConÅ¿cience and Honour; Pray what were his Sentiments about it?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: His Sentiment was, that he wou'd obey Sir George Barclay's Orders, and he was Å¿ure Sir George Barclay wou'd not do it without Orders.

sp.speaker: Sir Barth. Shower.
sp.p: Did not he declare it to be a Barbarous DeÅ¿ign?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: I can't remember every particular thing that he Å¿aid; for I am not a Spy upon any Man's Actions.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: When you were talking of that DeÅ¿ign that you Å¿peak of, pray did I conÅ¿ent to any Å¿uch thing?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: I tell you how far you conÅ¿ented; you Å¿aid you wou'd obey Sir George Barclay's Orders, and you was Å¿ure he wou'd not do it without Orders.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Did you Å¿ee any of Sir George Barclay's Orders?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: No, I did not, I was to follow his Orders; but what Orders he had I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What did Sir George Barclay tell you you were to do?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: Sir George Barclay declared on the firÅ¿t Saturday that we were his Janizaries, and talked of attacking and bringing away the Garter: I cannot Å¿ay this Gentleman was by then; and afterwards Sir George Barclay went out and returned, and came in again into the Room, and declared that we were Men of Honour, and that we were to attack the Prince of Orange.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Did Sir George Barclay give the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar any Orders.

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: I don't tell you he did.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: You Å¿ay you met Sir George Barclay and Major Holmes upon the Road going to IÅ¿lington: How do you know the PriÅ¿oner was there?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: Why, was not I with him? I am very Å¿orry to come upon this Account; but you know it is Truth all that I Å¿ay; and I am Å¿ure you are Å¿enÅ¿ible I do you no Wrong: he met Sir George Barclay and Major Holmes, and he went down and Å¿aid Å¿omething to Sir George Barclay in the Highway; what it was I don't know; but I Å¿tood, and Captain Rookwood and Mr. Bernard Å¿aid Å¿omething to him, which you very well know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: I can't tell, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We do not deÅ¿ire you to tell what you can't tell: Is this all you know?

sp.speaker: Harris.
sp.p: It is all at preÅ¿ent that I recollect.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then pray Å¿wear Mr. Bertram

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: Pray will you give an Account to my Lord and the Jury what you know of this Intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and how far the PriÅ¿oner was concerned in it.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: My Lord, about the beginning of February laÅ¿t, Major Lowick came to me, and ask'd me if I wou'd eÅ¿pouÅ¿e a thing with him that might be for my Advantage; I told him that I thought I might eÅ¿pouÅ¿e any thing that he thought fit to engage in.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Whom did you tell Å¿o?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Major Lowick; and he told me it was well, and deÅ¿ired me to ask no more QueÅ¿tions: I did not, but it went on till the 14th of February, when he deÅ¿ired me to be at his Lodgings at Twelve a Clock. I was Å¿o, about that time, but he was not within, and I Å¿taid till he came in, and he took me up into his Chamber, and told me he believed they Å¿hou'd Ride out in Å¿ome little time; and he told me he believed the King was to be Å¿eiz'd in his Coach; and he gave me a Guinea to buy me NeceÅ¿Å¿aries.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: What NeceÅ¿Å¿aries?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I can't Å¿ay he named any.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But for what purpoÅ¿e were thoÅ¿e NeceÅ¿Å¿aries?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I don't know that he named any thing, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Well, Did he tell you when you were to be ready?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p:
If you pleaÅ¿e to give me leave, I'll tell you: He deÅ¿ired me not to be out of the way; and the next Morning I was to meet him at the Purl HouÅ¿e in HartÅ¿treet. I did not meet him; and the next time I Å¿aw him, I am not poÅ¿itive whether it was the next day after the Fifteenth when I was to meet him at HartÅ¿treet, but did not Å¿o; but the next time I Å¿aw him he ask'd me why I did not meet him according to his Appointment? I told
him, I had Å¿ome ReaÅ¿on for it, and he anÅ¿wered me again, That he believed, if the King had been in the Field, I would have done the Å¿ame; but I have not Å¿een him Å¿ince till I Å¿aw him at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Had you no DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of HorÅ¿es that you were to provide?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I do not remember any particular thing more than I have told you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he not tell you what the DeÅ¿ign was you were to go about?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He did not tell me of any other DeÅ¿ign than as I tell you, for he believed I knew of it, I thought Å¿o at leaÅ¿t; the firÅ¿t time I knew of it was from Mr. Chernock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: What did he tell you was the DeÅ¿ign that you Å¿hould Ingage in for your Advantage upon Friday the 14th, when he gave you the Guinea?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He told me, he believed they Å¿hould ride out very Å¿uddenly, and that the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Did he tell you when the King was to be Å¿eized?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, he did not tell me when, but this was the 14th the next morning I was to meet him at Hart-Å¿treet, but did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Who did he tell you the King was to be Å¿eized by?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He did not nominate any one elÅ¿e, for he obliged me not to ask him QueÅ¿tions, nor I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he name himÅ¿elf to be concerned?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He named himÅ¿elf Å¿o far, as that he believed he Å¿hould ride out very Å¿uddenly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was it the next-morning, or the next day?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I cannot Å¿ay that he named any particular time.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Will they ask him any QueÅ¿tions?

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: No, I think we Å¿hall not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mountagu.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Bertram, will you anÅ¿wer me one QueÅ¿tion? What did he Å¿ay to you when he check'd you for not coming according to his Appointment?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I took it as a kind of a Check; he told me, that if the King had been in the Field, he believed I would have done the Å¿ame.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: There is one thing we muÅ¿t a little Examine this Gentleman to; Were not you under a NeceÅ¿Å¿ity before that time that he gave you the Guinea? Pray what Condition were you in?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Under NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, Sir! I was never very plentiful of money of late.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did he never give you a Guinea or two before in Charity, and out of CompaÅ¿Å¿ion to your NeceÅ¿Å¿ities?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He has given me money Å¿everal times before, and I believe if I would have ask'd him any money he would have given it me.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was this money given you for Charity, or for any other, and what purpoÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I did not ask him for any thing, but he gave it me, and Å¿aid, There's a Guinea to buy you NeceÅ¿Å¿aries.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What was the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e before that?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I told you, he Å¿aid, he believed they were to ride out very Å¿uddenly, and he believed the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, and he deÅ¿ired me not to be out of the way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: And when he gave you the Guinea to buy you NeceÅ¿Å¿aries, was it immediately after this DiÅ¿courÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Sir, it was at the Å¿ame time.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: Did not I give your Wife a Guinea two months before this?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I acknowledge I was informed you did, I was not in Town then.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: Pray let the Court know that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Did he tell you, the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach before he told you they were to ride out very Å¿uddenly?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, afterwards; and then he gave me the Guinea.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: His Words are not coupled together, they have no relation to one another.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: No, but he told him, they were to ride out very Å¿uddenly, and the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, and gave him a Guinea to buy him NeceÅ¿Å¿aries at the Å¿ame time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: There's no doubt he was ingaged in the DeÅ¿ign with thoÅ¿e other PerÅ¿ons.

sp.speaker: Mr. Conyers.
sp.p: And afterwards he rebuked him becauÅ¿e he had not met him; and he Å¿aid, it would have been the Å¿ame thing, if the King had been in the Field.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mountagu.
sp.p: What day in the week was it that you failed him?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: It was on a Saturday.

sp.speaker: Juryman.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, we deÅ¿ire to know, who he did underÅ¿tand by the King that was to be Å¿eized.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: What did he call the King?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He Å¿aid nothing but the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Who did you underÅ¿tand by that?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I leave it to the Court, I am not to interpret Things.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Treby.
sp.p: Did he name the Prince of Orange, or King James? Did you think King James was to be Å¿eized?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: My Lord, I tell you what he Å¿aid, I am not to interpret his Words.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Do you believe he meant King James, or this King, that was to be Å¿eized?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I believed it might be the King here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p:
Take the Words as they are; he ask'd him before, Whether he would ingage in a DeÅ¿ign that might be for his Advantage; on Friday the 14th of
February he meets him at his Lodging, and tells him, he was to ride out Å¿uddenly, and that the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, and appointed him to meet him the next morning, and gave him a Guinea to buy him NeceÅ¿Å¿aries.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Pray, has not Mr. Lowick given you Clothes, Linnen and other Things at any other time?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Sir, you have been always ready to Å¿erve me, I muÅ¿t acknowledge, and you have been very kind to me.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: If you pleaÅ¿e to give an Account of my Character, whether ever I was guilty of any bloody Thing.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long have you known Mr. Lowick?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I believe I have known him this 20 years.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: What Behaviour has he been of?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He has always had very good Behaviour, and the beÅ¿t; he has had the beÅ¿t Character of all Mankind.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you ever know him inclined to do a raÅ¿h Action?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Never in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Did you ever know him do a malicious Action?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: But he had always the Character of a good Man, and was always ready to Å¿erve any Man in his NeceÅ¿Å¿ities, and to do Good; he has that General Character abroad.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Where does he live?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He lived laÅ¿t at Brownlow-Å¿treet, but he has no Wife nor Family, and Å¿o has no fix'd Being.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: What was his way of Living?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He was bred a Soldier, and has been abroad.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: In Ireland.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: In whoÅ¿e Service?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: In the Service of King James.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: He knows particularly, that once I was upon a Party and Å¿aved 5 Officers from being killed in cold Blood.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: What Countryman is he?

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Was he accounted of a cruel or a bloody Nature?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, of a quite contrary.

sp.speaker: Juryman.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire to know for what CauÅ¿e he gave him or his Wife a Guinea.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I know not what that Guinea was for that he gave me the 14th of February any otherwiÅ¿e than as I have told you.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: What was the Guinea given to your Wife for?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: For that Guinea given to my Wife, it was out of his own KindneÅ¿s and GoodneÅ¿s to my Family and me.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What was the other Guinea for? You are upon your Oath.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I cannot tell, he gave it me to buy me NeceÅ¿Å¿aries.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there nothing elÅ¿e mentioned what NeceÅ¿Å¿aries thoÅ¿e were to be?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, Sir, upon my Oath there was not any Particular mentioned.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What made him Å¿o kind to you, pray?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: We were both born in a Town, and I believe we are near Related.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: You Å¿ay you are Towns-People, and have been long acquainted, and you knew him in Ireland, pray did you ever know that he Å¿aved any People's Lives?

sp.speaker: Bortram.
sp.p: I was not in that Action my Å¿elf, but all that were in it gave that Relation; that he was very favourable, and did Å¿ave Peoples Lives, particularly one Captain Harlow, and brought him and others PriÅ¿oners, and I remember the thing; it was about a Fortnight before the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of the Boyne, upon a Sunday Morning, that they took thoÅ¿e PriÅ¿oners, and he did perÅ¿wade Å¿everal Parties that he Commanded, to decline Killing, as much as they could; I was not in this Action, but this I heard of all that were in it, and from the PriÅ¿oner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Solli. Gen.
sp.p: When he gave you that Guinea, did not he Å¿peak any thing of a HorÅ¿e that was to be provided for you?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Not a word; I never did Å¿ee a HorÅ¿e upon that Account, nor was I MaÅ¿ter of a HorÅ¿e, nor was I told I Å¿hould have a HorÅ¿e in any reÅ¿pect whatÅ¿oever.

sp.speaker: Juryman.
sp.p: How could you Ride out as you Å¿ay they were to do, without a HorÅ¿e, or without knowing any thing of a HorÅ¿e to be provided for you?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I did not know of a HorÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: But he Å¿aid you were to Ride out Å¿peedily.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, he Å¿aid in general, we Å¿hould Ride out Å¿uddenly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Who was there beÅ¿ides your Å¿elf?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Then that we muÅ¿t mean you and him. And how were you to Ride out without a HorÅ¿e? Pray mind what you Swear?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I was to meet him the next Morning, but did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Pray what cou'd you underÅ¿tand by that, that you were to Ride out Å¿uddenly, and had no HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: That was underÅ¿tood, that if I did Ride out, I muÅ¿t have a HorÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Who Å¿hould you have it from, had you a HorÅ¿e of your own?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, I had not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Did you intend to Hire a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Did not you ask where you were to have a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, I did not Ask nor Inquire, nor was it promis'd me, I Å¿hould have a HorÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Did he tell you where you were to Ride?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: The next Morning I was to meet him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: For what, to Ride out was it?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I can't really tell whether it was upon that Account or not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Whether did he tell you where he was to Ride?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: Indeed he did not.

sp.speaker: Juryman.
sp.p: It is very Å¿trange that you did not ask him where he was to go, nor ask him for a HorÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I was Å¿o SenÅ¿eleÅ¿s, that I neither did ask him about a HorÅ¿e, nor ever knew of any that was to be provided for me.

sp.speaker: Juryman.
sp.p: Did you underÅ¿tand what was meant by the Riding out Å¿uddenly?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I did take it to be about the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, the Å¿eizing of the King.

sp.speaker: Juryman.
sp.p: Did he compare it to Attacking him in the Field?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, he did not; but he Å¿aid he believed the King would be Å¿eiz'd in his Coach; he made no CompariÅ¿ons.

sp.speaker: Mr. Montague.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Bertram, why did you not meet him, what ReaÅ¿ons had you for not doing it?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I thought it not requiÅ¿ite to meet him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Montague.
sp.p: What had you no mind to the thing?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: No, I had not, becauÅ¿e I thought the thing very unlawful.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Pray what was that thing you Å¿peak of, that you thought was unlawful?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I thought it was about Seizing and Killing the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Pray mind, there is no body deÅ¿ires you Å¿hould Å¿peak more then the Truth, but on the other Å¿ide, being upon your Oath, you are to Å¿peak the whole Truth, for if you Conceal any part of the Truth, tho' you have a KindneÅ¿s for your Countryman Mr. Lowick, who has been kind to you, you will forÅ¿wear your Å¿elf, for you make a different RepreÅ¿entation of the matter, and make it appear quite otherwiÅ¿e then it is; pray do not Å¿traine one Tittle, but let us have all the Truth.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I don't believe, I Å¿train one Bit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mountagu.
sp.p: Then tell my Lord, why did not you meet him.

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I did believe it was about Seizing and Killing the King, and I did think it to be Illegal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mountagu.
sp.p: Why did you think it was about that?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: BecauÅ¿e Mr. Charnock had told me of it before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: How did you know that was what Lowick Å¿poke to you about?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: I did Å¿uppoÅ¿e it to be the Å¿ame, becauÅ¿e he deÅ¿ired me at firÅ¿t to ask no QueÅ¿tions, no more did I, but I took it always to be the Å¿ame thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: What did he Å¿ay to you?

sp.speaker: Bertram.
sp.p: He told me he had a buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to propoÅ¿e to me, if I wou'd Ingage in, that wou'd be for my Advantage, but I muÅ¿t ask no QueÅ¿tions; talkt of Riding out Å¿uddenly, and that the King was to be Seized in his Coach and having heard of it from Charnock, I thought it was the Å¿ame buÅ¿ineÅ¿s.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Then my Lord, we have one WitneÅ¿s more, call Captain FiÅ¿her, [He did not appear.] If he does not appear, we Å¿hall let them go on, and when he comes in, we can examine him afterwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Is he a material WitneÅ¿s?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We do apprehend he is a very material WitneÅ¿s.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: If you think him a material WitneÅ¿s, it will not be proper for them to enter upon their Defence, till they have heard the whole AccuÅ¿ation.

div.p: The Court Å¿taid for Mr. FiÅ¿her's coming for near an Hour, and at laÅ¿t he came in and was Sworn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: This is one Captain FiÅ¿her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Captain FiÅ¿her, do you know Mr. Lowick, the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: I have not Talkt with Mr. Lowick Å¿ince the 8th of February, and then he Talkt that he wou'd be ready to Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter to the uttermoÅ¿t of his Power.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: What MaÅ¿ter?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: King James.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: What particular Service?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: He named no particular Service, but only that he wou'd be ready to Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter to the uttermoÅ¿t of his Power.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Where was this?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: At the Cock in Bow-street.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Who was in Company?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: There was Mr. HarriÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Pray give an Account of what you know of this Barbarous bloody DeÅ¿ign.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: I believe there was a DeÅ¿ign to Å¿eize the Prince of Orange.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: What do you know of it? you Å¿ay you believe it.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: I believe it by my Knowledge, becauÅ¿e I was concern'd in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor, Gen.
sp.p: By whom was that DeÅ¿ign carryed on?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: By Sir George Barctay and Mr. HarriÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: What was the DeÅ¿ign?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: We were to fall upon the Prince of Orange.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: You called him Å¿o, the Prince of Orange?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Well, tell us what happened.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: It was to have been done the 15th of February, and we met accordingly the 14th, but the King not going Abroad, it was put off.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Who met on the 14th?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: I met only Mr. HarriÅ¿on and Sir George Barclay, then it was put off till the 22th; upon the 21th, we met at the Three Tuns in Holborne, and from thence we came to the Sun Tavern in the Strand, and there was no body but Mr. HarriÅ¿on and I together, and Sir George Barclay came to us; I believe there were about 14 or 16 in the HouÅ¿e; there Sir George Barclay told me, Mr. Lowick was to meet me and two more at an Inn by St. Giles's Pound, and that we were to go together to Å¿eize the Prince of Orange the 22th.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: Did you meet him?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: I did not meet him, it being put off by the King's not going Abroad.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: This does not affect Mr. Lowick at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: It does not, we acknowledge, but at that time which you Å¿peak of, the 8th of February, had you any knowledge of the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: There was no AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination at that time, at leaÅ¿t it was not then declared.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: What was your DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about then?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: There was Notice of the King's preparing to come for England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: You Å¿ay Mr. HarriÅ¿on was there.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: Yes, and Talkt very little about the matter, but only that there were Preparations for the King's coming.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: What did Lowick Å¿ay to you?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: I have told you all that Mr. Lowick Å¿aid to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Repeat it again.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: He Å¿aid he would be ready to Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter, to the uttermoÅ¿t of his Power.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: Had you no diÅ¿courÅ¿e about an Act of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: Mr. Lowick Å¿aid it was not convenient to Talk with more then one at any time, for there was an Act of Parliament on Foot, that under two WitneÅ¿Å¿es nothing Å¿hould affect a Mans Life in TreaÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: The Act of Parliament was then a making.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. H.
sp.p: When Mr. Lowick Å¿aid he wou'd Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter, what DiÅ¿courÅ¿e had you about it.

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: Mr. Lowick Å¿aid not a word within, but at the Door he Å¿aid he wou'd Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter to his Power.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: What was that, that they wou'd not Talk with above one at a time?

sp.speaker: Captain FiÅ¿her.
sp.p: Nothing that was thought TreaÅ¿onable Practices Å¿hou'd be DiÅ¿cours'd of before above one at a time, Å¿o I underÅ¿tood it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then my Lord we have done.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p:
May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury;
I am of CounÅ¿el in this caÅ¿e for the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, and we do hope here is not Evidence Å¿ufficient to convict him of High TreaÅ¿on, the QueÅ¿tion is not whether there was a Plot or a ConÅ¿piracy to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, or to prepare for an InvaÅ¿ion, but all that you are to conÅ¿ider, Gentlemen, is, whether the Evidence againÅ¿t Mr. Lowick, be Å¿ufficient to convince you, that he did deÅ¿ign to Seize and AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King; there are three WitneÅ¿Å¿es produc'd, but we think this laÅ¿t WitneÅ¿s, FiÅ¿her, his TeÅ¿timony does not hurt him in the leaÅ¿t. We know your LordÅ¿hip will Declare and Direct the Jury, that the Evidence in a caÅ¿e of TreaÅ¿on ought to be plain, not only with reÅ¿pect to the Fact, that it was done; but alÅ¿o of Å¿uch Facts as are the Evidences of a man's intentions, and thoÅ¿e are not to be ConÅ¿trued by Strains and Intendments, or Implications; unleÅ¿s they be Å¿uch as Evidently, Naturally, and to common UnderÅ¿tanding expreÅ¿s the Intention, it cannot be good Evidence in TreaÅ¿on: Now we Å¿ay that Captain FiÅ¿her has Å¿aid nothing at all that will affect the PriÅ¿oner, for al that he Å¿ays is, that the Eighth of February he Å¿aid he was ready to Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter to the utmoÅ¿t of his Power, and any words as well as theÅ¿e may be ConÅ¿trued to make a Man Guilty of TreaÅ¿onable Intentions; for it might be a Recollection of Favours Received, or it might be a Grateful intent to Å¿erve him upon particular occaÅ¿ionsâª but that is no Evidence upon this Indictment. SuppoÅ¿e it was to Å¿erve him upon the Å¿uppoÅ¿ed intended InvaÅ¿ion, yet with Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, that is not Eviednce of the Overt Act laid here; here is no Overt Act mentioned of preparing Arms, or Incouraging Men, or Seducing the King's Subjects in order to the better reÅ¿toring of the late King James, or the expected Landing of the French, or the like All that's laid to the PriÅ¿oner's charge, is the CompaÅ¿ting the King's Death, and a DeÅ¿ign to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate him in his Coach, and in order to the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, he was to buy Armes and HorÅ¿es; now all that he Å¿ays is quite of another Nature, of a quite different Strain, and has no tendency to this matter, and nothing he Å¿ays that Lowick Å¿hou'd Å¿ay, but is applicable the other way, and tends more Naturally to the InvaÅ¿ion, then to the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination. Your LordÅ¿hip obÅ¿erves there was Å¿ome notice taken of what Mr. Lowick Å¿hou'd Å¿ay, concerning the Act of Parliament, that he would not talk with above one at a time; how far when life is concern'd Å¿uch looÅ¿e diÅ¿courÅ¿e ought to be inforc'd before a Jury I muÅ¿t leave to your LordÅ¿hip; tho a Man may be Innocent, yet he may be Cautious, and the more Innocent, perhaps the more Cautious; but that is applicable to the InvaÅ¿ion too, and has no Relation to the TreaÅ¿on in this Indictment more than any other. It Å¿hows he was more wary then others were, but it is not applicable to the Fact that he now Å¿tands charged with. Then the whole of the Evidence depends upon the TeÅ¿timony of Mr. Harris and Mr. Bertram, and we think they are not two WitneÅ¿Å¿es to one thing, and what they Å¿ay muÅ¿t be Å¿trained, and intended and preÅ¿umed, to make Evidence of TreaÅ¿on; for what Mr. Harris Å¿ays about the DiÅ¿courÅ¿es between him and the late King James, about Receiving Orders from Sir George Barclay, and his paÅ¿Å¿age over from France, and the Å¿everal Stages he and Mr. Hare travel'd, and the DiÅ¿courÅ¿es between Sir George Barclay and him; Your LordÅ¿hip will acquaint the Jury that is no Evidence to affect Mr. Lowick, no â¢ what Berkenhead and Hare agreed upon does any way affect Mr. Lowick, for thoÅ¿e things may be all true and yet Mr. Lowick innocent of what he Å¿tands charged with in this Indictment; he Å¿ays, that upon the firÅ¿t Saturday he Å¿aw Mr. Lowick at the Confectioners, but he cannot Å¿ay he Å¿taid there at all, there was not a word Å¿poken by Mr. Lowick that he remembers then, but what he Å¿ays that Å¿eems to touch, and the only thing that touches Mr. Lowick, in all this Evidence is, that that upon Monday, TueÅ¿day, WedneÅ¿day or ThurÅ¿day, it is a pretty large time, between the Fifteenth and the Twenty Å¿econd, he was talking with Mr. Lowick about the Barbarity of this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, and that Lowick after all, Å¿aid he would obey Orders; now with Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, my Lord, to make that to have Relation to the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination muÅ¿t be by a forc'd Å¿train'd Intendment; he does not Declare what the Orders were, nay, he does not affirm there were any Orders for the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination,
but only that he would obey Orders; here's no Order by Writing, no Order by Parole that Mr. Lowick declared he would obey: as to what Lowick declared about his Intention of Riding out and Seizing the King in his Coach; that cannot be intended the Order that he was to obey to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, that Order does not appear, there are no footÅ¿teps of it in all the Evidence, Å¿o that there is nothing in that TeÅ¿timony that will hurt Mr. Lowick: Then upon the Two and Twentieth when they Dined together, Mr. Harris Å¿ays, that there was a DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of two Men, but it does not appear, nor does the WitneÅ¿s give any account what thoÅ¿e two Men were to be for; 'tis true two Men he was to get DiÅ¿charg'd, but that is not Evidence that theÅ¿e Men were to make a Part of thoÅ¿e Forty, neither the words before nor the words after can have that ConÅ¿truction; nay it does not appear it was for any purpoÅ¿e at all, now in the caÅ¿e of Life, where a Man Å¿tands at the Bar, we hope Å¿uch an Evidence Å¿hall not be ConÅ¿trued to make a Proof of a TreaÅ¿onable intention, that theÅ¿e were to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, or to make part of the Forty that were to do it, when it does not appear they were there, nor who they were, nor any Å¿ort of Notice taken or given upon what account they were, Provided. And then as to Mr. Bertram's Evidence, it is Palpable that his Evidence and whatÅ¿oever he Å¿ays cannot amount to make one WitneÅ¿s to prove an Overt Act within this Statute, and that there muÅ¿t be two WitneÅ¿Å¿es the Law requires; what does Mr. Bertram Å¿ay to prove any Man Guilty of TreaÅ¿on, but only by Intendment, Thought or SuÅ¿picion? It is true, Mr. Bertram's Evidence would be good enough to commit a Man upon SuÅ¿picion for TreaÅ¿on, but to Convict him it cannot be; he Å¿ays that in the begining of February he Å¿poke to him and, told him he would imploy him in a buÅ¿ineÅ¿s that would be for his Advantage, but he muÅ¿t ask no QueÅ¿tions; this is very dark, for the meaning of it does not appear what was intended by it; it might be one thing as well as another, it might be to imploy him in his Family, or it might be to Å¿end him of a Journey, or it might be the taking of a Farm, but to apply that as an Evidence of a charge of High TreaÅ¿on, that we think is very hard, and we hope your LordÅ¿hip will think Å¿o too; but then he comes and tells you further of a DiÅ¿courÅ¿e upon the Fourteenth, of his Riding out Å¿uddenly, and that the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, but he does not Å¿ay that he was to Å¿eize him, nor that he would be concern'd in it, nor that he knew of it, nor did Declare at what time it was to be done, nor any thing certain whether it was a Prophecy, or a Dream, or a Story that he related again, or what it was; there is no Connection between the Riding out Å¿uddenly and the other words of Å¿eizing the King in his Coach; then he Å¿ays he gave him a Guinea to buy him neceÅ¿Å¿aries, the Man acknowledges Mr. Lowick Å¿everal times had given him in Charity Money, Cloaths and other things, and gave his Wife a Guinea, as you obÅ¿erve, in Charity, but he gave him this Guinea on purpoÅ¿e to buy him neceÅ¿Å¿aries, and it is hard that a Man's Charity to a Countryman, to a TownÅ¿man, to an ancient acquaintance of Twenty Years Å¿tanding, to a PerÅ¿on that he had been familiar with formerly, and known to have lived well, Å¿hould be miÅ¿ interpreted and Å¿train'd, to make it a giving him Money as SubÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and a Reward for the doing Å¿uch a MiÅ¿chievous Bloody Act; We Å¿ay his Charity to this Man formerly is inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with the SuppoÅ¿ition that he cou'd be Privy to Å¿uch a Barbarous DeÅ¿ign now, and we hope the Jury will conÅ¿ider the Character that that very Man has given to my Client, for the Å¿ame WitneÅ¿s gives you an account of his Behaviour all along, that he was not given to RaÅ¿h and Barbarous Actions, nor Guilty of any Malicious thing, nay, that he prevented MiÅ¿chief and the Killing of People in cold Blood. We muÅ¿t leave it to the Jury's ConÅ¿ideration, and your LordÅ¿hips Direction. All theÅ¿e things that they Å¿ay may be true, and Lowick be not Guilty, and the acquitting of Mr. Lowick will be no Reflection upon the WitneÅ¿Å¿es, nor any diÅ¿credit to the TeÅ¿timony that has been given of this ConÅ¿piracy, but we hope 'tis doing JuÅ¿tice to this Man, the WitneÅ¿Å¿es not coming up to the Proof of what is laid in the Indictment. We muÅ¿t beg your LordÅ¿hips patience a little
longer, and call Å¿ome WitneÅ¿Å¿es to give you an account how long they have known Mr. Lowick, and what his real Character is; they will tell you he is a peaceable good Man, and Å¿hew you that his Temper and Inclination was rather to a Å¿ober quiet Life than to lead him to Å¿uch action, and that they cannot think him likely to be tempted to be concerned in Å¿uch a DeÅ¿ign; and then we muÅ¿t leave it to the Jury. Call Mrs. Yorke.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: I believe there is no body here that knows me but will give me that Character.

div.p: Mrs. Yorke came in and was Sworn.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. Yorke how long have you known Mr. Lowick.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: About a Dozen or Fourteen Years.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: What Å¿ort of DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition is he of?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: He is a Civil HoneÅ¿t Man as ever I Å¿aw in my life, or ever knew of; and I never heard otherwiÅ¿e from any one that knew him.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: What was he in his Actions, was he Malicious, or good Natured?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: As good a Natured Man as ever I Å¿aw.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Has he the Reputation of a Cruel Bloody minded Man?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: Quite the contrary. He lodged in my HouÅ¿e half a year, it is not quite a year ago Å¿ince he lay at my HouÅ¿e. He was the moÅ¿t Obliging Man that ever lay in my HouÅ¿e: he was Å¿o Civil to all the Lodgers that they admired him for his goodneÅ¿s, and made them in love with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: How came he to Lodge at your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: He came from his other Landlady, they could not agree, his other Landlady was a Å¿ort of a Shrew, and therefore he did not care for Å¿taying there; and I deÅ¿ired his Company becauÅ¿e I knew him to be Å¿o Obliging and Civil a Man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Where is your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: In Bloomsbury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: What is his way of living, is he a Man of an EÅ¿tate?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I did not inquire into that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Had he no Imployment to get his Living by?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: I do not know any thing of that, I never inquired into it; he paid me very HoneÅ¿tly for my Lodging, and he is a very good Man for any thing I know.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Then call Mrs MoÅ¿ely.

div.p: She came in and was Sworn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well, what do you ask this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. MoÅ¿ely will you tell my Lord and the Jury: do you know Mr. Lowick?

sp.speaker: MoÅ¿ely.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: How long have you known him?

sp.speaker: MoÅ¿ely.
sp.p: Near twenty Years.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: Pray give an account upon your knowledge what DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition and Temper he is of, whether he is RaÅ¿h, Malicious, Bloody, and ill Natured.

sp.speaker: MoÅ¿ely.
sp.p: He is a Peaceable, Vertuous, HoneÅ¿t Man, and a Man that I never heard or Å¿aw that Creature that could Å¿peak any ill thing of him in my life; nor I never heard him Å¿peak any thing MaliciouÅ¿ly of any Creature in my life to do them a prejudice: Å¿o far from that, that he is a Man has a Character, perhaps, above any Man that I could Å¿peak or hear of in my life. I Å¿peak it even above my own Relations, they may have Å¿ome PaÅ¿Å¿ions; but I never Å¿ee that Gentleman in a PaÅ¿Å¿ion in my life. He has lain in my HouÅ¿e Å¿everal times, and he has had Company come to him, but never any that was Scandalous one way or other. I never Å¿aw him Fudled; nor ever heard him Swear, nor any one accuÅ¿e him of any of thoÅ¿e things.

sp.speaker: Mr. MompeÅ¿Å¿on.
sp.p: Call Dr. William Mew.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: The PriÅ¿oner has Å¿omething to Å¿ay for himÅ¿elf my Lord, but we muÅ¿t Å¿ubmit to your LordÅ¿hips ConÅ¿ideration, and the Juries, whether there be any Evidence but what is dark and Å¿avours of SuÅ¿picion only; SuÅ¿picious it is, but whether there be any Evidence that is plain and direct as the Law requires in CaÅ¿es of High TreaÅ¿on, we muÅ¿t leave it to your ConÅ¿ideration, for we apprehend there is none.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: My Lord, as to this BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, the thing that I Å¿tand accuÅ¿ed of, the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, I know nothing in the World of it, nor never did directly or indirectly; and if I am Convicted, and could to Å¿ave my life be the death of the pooreÅ¿t Child in the World, I would not Å¿ave my life to do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Look you, I would put you to make anÅ¿wer to Å¿ome things; you were at Sir George Barclays at the Confectioners in Holborn: and it is Å¿worn he came over upon Å¿uch a DeÅ¿ign. Then you were with Mr. Harris at Red Lion Fields, and there he was Å¿peaking to you of the horridneÅ¿s of the DeÅ¿ign that was to be Executed upon the Kings PerÅ¿on the Saturday before, and he told you he did miÅ¿like it; and thereupon you anÅ¿wered that you would obey Orders, and that Sir George Barclay had Orders for it, otherwiÅ¿e he would not do it.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: Sir George Barclay never Å¿poke one word of it to me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Every body knows now upon what DeÅ¿ign he came over from France, and when Mr. Harris Å¿howed this Å¿atisfaction with the thing, you made that anÅ¿wer to his DiÅ¿courÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: He never Å¿aid one Syllable to me of it. I truÅ¿t to your LordÅ¿hips Judgment, and the Juries Mercy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: And then I would have you anÅ¿wer to another thing, when you Dined together on the Saturday the two and twentieth, what were thoÅ¿e two Men that could not be DiÅ¿charged without you?

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: My Lord, I know nothing in the World of two Men.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: You went to DiÅ¿charge them, for the King did not go abroad that day.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: He Swears this, and that's as to him; but then as to Bertram, what DeÅ¿ign was that, that you were to ingage Bertram in for his Advantage, and he was to ask no QueÅ¿tions?

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: My Lord, He is a poor Man, and my Countryman, and I have at all times, from time to time, for this Å¿even Years, helped to SubÅ¿iÅ¿t him and his Family, that he will not deny, and I have Å¿everal times given him both Cloths and Mony.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Then I would ask you again, When he came to your Lodging on Friday the Fourteenth of February, and you told him the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, and Å¿aid that we were to Ride out very Å¿uddenly, and you appointed him to meet the next Morning; and becauÅ¿e he did not meet you blamed him, and Å¿aid it would have been the Å¿ame thing, if the King had been in the Field? Look you, I would have you give anÅ¿wer to this if you can.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: I remember nothing in the World of it, not a word I aÅ¿Å¿ure you, and to the beÅ¿t of my remembrance I did not Å¿ee him in two days after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
My Lord, I muÅ¿t beg leave to AnÅ¿wer to the Objection that the CounÅ¿el for the PriÅ¿oner have made, that there are not two WitneÅ¿Å¿es to prove the Overt-Act laid in the Indictment, and Å¿o the Law is not Å¿atisfied. In AnÅ¿wer to that, I deÅ¿ire your LordÅ¿hips favour to obÅ¿erve how the Evidence is, and then we Å¿hall Å¿ee whether there are not plainly two PoÅ¿itive WitneÅ¿Å¿es of the Overt-Act, by agreeing to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King. The firÅ¿t WitneÅ¿s is Mr. Harris, Your LordÅ¿hip obÅ¿erves that Mr. Harris gives an account that Mr. Lowick was at Sir George Barclay's Lodgings the firÅ¿t day that it was to have been Executed; and that afterwards between the Fifteenth and the two and twentieth, thoÅ¿e being the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd Days that this was to be done, when he and Rookwood, and the PriÅ¿oner Lowick, were walking together in Red Lion Fields; and there had Å¿ome DiÅ¿courÅ¿e about the intended AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, and the Barbarity and BloodineÅ¿s of it, and Mr. Harris and Mr. Rookwood were averÅ¿e to it. Mr. Lowick Å¿aid he would obey Orders, and he was Å¿ure Sir George Barclay would not do it unleÅ¿s he had direct Orders for it, that was twice Repeated by him, as Harris Swears: and afterwards Mr. Harris tells you that the Two and Twentieth he Dined with Mr. Lowick, and Mr. Lowick obÅ¿erved that Mr. Harris came in in a great Sweat, and asked him how it happened, he Å¿aid he had been about to get ready Rookwood's Party that were to Å¿eize the King, for he was to have one Party. Says Mr. Lowick to him, you need not Grudge to do it, you have Å¿ix Shillings a day, I
have nothing; and yet I, at my own Charge, am to provide two. This is as PoÅ¿itive Evidence as well can be of his being privy to the DeÅ¿ign; and his ingaging People at his own Charge, Å¿hows a great deal of forwardneÅ¿s and Zeal in the PriÅ¿oner to the BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s. My Lord, I think this is poÅ¿itive and plain Evidence, and not only made out by Inferrences and ConÅ¿tructions, as Sir B. Shower Å¿ays, but plain poÅ¿itive Proof. The firÅ¿t day he was with Å¿everal of them, and when they DiÅ¿courÅ¿ed of the thing afterwards, he declared he would obey Orders; and what could thoÅ¿e Orders be but for what they were DiÅ¿courÅ¿ing of, and nothing was DiÅ¿courÅ¿ed of but this DeÅ¿ign they were ingaged in, and this was to juÅ¿tifie the thing, and take off the apprehenÅ¿ion of the Barbarity of it: this is Harris's TeÅ¿timony. The next WitneÅ¿s is Bertram, and he tells you that the Fifth of February the PriÅ¿oner Å¿ent for him, and when he came to him, he asked if he would Ingage in a BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s that might be for his Advantage, and ask no QueÅ¿tions: Å¿o at that time he did not acquaint him what the thing was, but that Å¿hows it was a thing that was to be kept Secret at that time, in regard he did not think fit to acquaint him at the firÅ¿t InÅ¿tance. But the Fourteenth of February, when he met him again, the day before the firÅ¿t time that it was to be put in Execution; Bertram Swears he told him that they were to Ride out the next Morning, that muÅ¿t be Lowick and Bertram, for there was no Body elÅ¿e there; and that the Prince of Orange was to be Å¿eized in his Coach. Was it poÅ¿Å¿ible the PriÅ¿oner could be ignorant of it? When he ingaged him to go upon a DeÅ¿ign without asking QueÅ¿tions; Å¿ent for him the day before, acquainted him they were to Ride out the next Morning, and that the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, and bid him be ready againÅ¿t next Morning, and gave him a Guinea at that time; the WitneÅ¿s Å¿ays it was for NeceÅ¿Å¿aries, but he does not pretend that it was for Charity, as formerly. And that muÅ¿t be for NeceÅ¿Å¿aries for that purpoÅ¿e that they were then DiÅ¿courÅ¿ing of, when he deÅ¿ired him to be ready the next day, and gives him Mony to buy him NeceÅ¿Å¿aries: What can that be, but NeceÅ¿Å¿aries for what he was to be ready for? And then he did not come the next day, and he tells you why, becauÅ¿e he thought it a very wicked and unlawful thing, and Å¿o he diÅ¿appointed him; and the next time Lowick Chid him, and told him he would have Å¿erved him Å¿o if the King had been in the Field. This is plain, though I believe Bertram does Speak as tenderly as he can, being his Friend and old Acquaintance, and is willing to Å¿ay as little as he can of him; Å¿o that I believe no body thinks but what Bertram Å¿ays againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner is true, and what he Swears is plain and poÅ¿itive. To Å¿how that Lowick did ingage in the DeÅ¿ign, he acquainted him with it the Fourteenth, by telling him the King was to be Å¿eized, and they were to Ride out, and he was to be ready the next day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: He does not Å¿ay they were to Ride out the next day.

sp.speaker: Sir B. Shower.
sp.p: No, the words were we are to Ride out Å¿uddenly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I think he did Å¿ay they were to Ride out the next Morning.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: No, Call him in again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cowper.
sp.p: The Words were, we Å¿hall Ride out Å¿uddenly, and bid him meet him next Morning; and afterwards Chid him for not meeting accordingly, and told him it had been the Å¿ame thing if the King had been in the Field.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: If you cannot agree upon the Evidence, you muÅ¿t call in the WitneÅ¿s.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mountague.
sp.p: My Lord we are agreed upon the Evidence, it was Å¿uddenly.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Well then, there is no occaÅ¿ion, have you done on both Å¿ides.

sp.speaker: CounÅ¿el.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, we Å¿ubmit it to your LordÅ¿hip.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Jury, this PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, Robert Lowick, is Indicted of High TreaÅ¿on, for CompaÅ¿Å¿ing and Imagining the Death and DeÅ¿truction of the King by an AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination; you have heard what Evidence has been given upon this Indictment. And in the firÅ¿t place, It is proved to you that there was a DeÅ¿ign to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King; which was to be carried on under the Conduct and Management of Sir George Barclay. The QueÅ¿tion that you are now to ConÅ¿ider of, is whether the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar was concerned or ingaged in the ProÅ¿ecution of that DeÅ¿ign. There have been two WitneÅ¿Å¿es produced, who have given their Evidence, and have been very Å¿trictly Examined, and ObÅ¿ervations have been made upon the TeÅ¿timony they have given.

The firÅ¿t WitneÅ¿s is Mr. Harris, and he gives you Å¿ome account of the Original of this DeÅ¿ign. He tells you how he was at St. Germains, and Introduced to the late King James, who did expreÅ¿s a great kindneÅ¿s for him, and told him that he had an Opportunity of doing Å¿omething for him that would be for his Advantage: and that he and one Hare, who was preÅ¿ent at that time, Å¿hould go into England (for it Å¿eems they were both together Introduced by Collonel Parker) and Å¿hould be SubÅ¿iÅ¿ted in England, and thereupon Directions were given them what CourÅ¿e they were to take; which was to go to Calice, and to each of them ten Lewedores were given for their Charges, and they were acquainted that if it happened that they Å¿hould lie there Å¿o long for want of a Wind to bring them over hither that their Money was Å¿pent, ProviÅ¿ion Å¿hould be made for their Å¿upply there.
