They had farther Directions, that when they came into England they Å¿hould apply themÅ¿elves to Sir George Barclay, and follow his Orders, with InÅ¿tructions how to find him; being told that Sir George Barclay would be walking in Covent Garden every Monday, and every ThurÅ¿day Night, about the hours of Å¿ix or Å¿even a Clock, and that they Å¿hould know him by a White Handkerchief that was to hang out of his Pocket.

Mr. Harris further tells you, That they did come to Calice in order to Embark for England, and there they happened to Å¿tay a conÅ¿iderable time, even Å¿o long that their Mony would not defray their Expences there, and they found it true as it was promiÅ¿ed them; for the PreÅ¿ident of Calice paid the Reckoning for them at the place where they Lodged; and afterwards they came into England, and landed in Kent, and came to RocheÅ¿ter, and from thence to London. About the latter end of January Old Stile (for it Å¿hould Å¿eem it was the 14. New Stile, which is the 4. Old Stile, they were of St. Germaines) he tells you that he did go the firÅ¿t Monday, after their arrival, into Covent Garden, to look after Sir George Barclay, but then miÅ¿t him. But afterwards his Companion, Mr. Hare, met with one Berkenhead, and complaining that they had not met with Sir George Barclay according to the Directions they had abroad: whereupon, by the means of Berkenhead, they were brought to the Speech of Sir George Barclay, who gave them reception, and owned that he had Authority to SubÅ¿iÅ¿t them; but Å¿aid he had not then Mony, but Å¿hortly Å¿hould, and when he had they Å¿hould be Å¿ure to receive their SubÅ¿iÅ¿tence. He tells you, that after this, Sir George Barclay gave them SubÅ¿iÅ¿tence Mony, paying them at the Rate of five Shillings a day when they had no HorÅ¿es, and when they had, Å¿ix Shillings a day: Å¿o they put themÅ¿elves altogether under his Command and Conduct. He has given you an Account what DiÅ¿courÅ¿e he had with Mr. Rookwood, from whom he diÅ¿covered what the DeÅ¿ign was in which he was to be ingaged. And the DeÅ¿ign to AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King was firÅ¿t intended to be put in Execution on Saturday the 15. of February, at which day Mr. Harris, and others, being at Sir George Barclay's Lodgings; Sir George Å¿aid they were his JamÅ¿aries, and afterwards CareÅ¿t them, and Å¿aid they were Men of Honour, and told them that they were to Attack the Prince of Orange and his Guards; but it Å¿eems the King not going abroad that day, they loÅ¿t that Opportunity.

Truly, Then Mr. Harris began to be a little troubled, and concerned, when he underÅ¿tood the meaning of his being under Sir George Barclay's Conduct. And he Å¿ays that after that firÅ¿t Saturday the 15. and before the next Saturday the 22. he met with Lowick, Rookwood, and Bernarde, and he was complaining of his being ingaged in Å¿uch a DeÅ¿ign as this was. He called it then the Murder of the Prince of Orange, and Å¿aid it was a Barbarous thing, and he did not like it, nor Rookwood neither; but as for Mr. Lowick whether he diÅ¿liked it or no, I know not, but he made AnÅ¿wer to him I will obey Orders: Å¿ays he Sir George Barclay has Orders for it, or otherwiÅ¿e he would not do it.

Then you are told further, that after this, on Saturday the 22. Mr. Harris Dined with Lowick at a Cooks at the end of Red Lion Street, and being there together, Harris being in a Sweat, and was asked the reaÅ¿on by Lowick, he Å¿aid he had been giving of Orders for the getting Å¿ome Men together that were to go under Rookwood, and Lowick told him he might very well do it, for he had Pay 6 s. a day; but Å¿ays he, I am to SubÅ¿iÅ¿t two Men, and have nothing at all. Mr. Harris wiÅ¿hed him to go to Sir George Barclay, and Complain of it to him, but he Å¿aid he would not; but it Å¿eems, it being then underÅ¿tood by them that the King did not go abroad that day, Lowick Å¿aid he muÅ¿t go and DiÅ¿charge the two Men, and went about it. This is the Sum and SubÅ¿tance of Mr. Harris's Evidence againÅ¿t Mr. Lowick.

The next WitneÅ¿s is Bertram, and he tells you that Å¿ometime before the Fifteenth of February, which was, as I told you, the very firÅ¿t day that they did deÅ¿ign to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King, Mr. Lowick Å¿ent for him, and told him, that he would put you upon a BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s that Å¿hall be for his Advantage, if he would undertake it without asking any QueÅ¿tions, this was Å¿ometime before, but the certain Day Bertram does not remember; but he tells you farther, that on Friday the Fourteenth of February, he was with Lowick at his Lodgings, and he Å¿aid unto him, that the King, he did believe, was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, and we are to ride out Å¿uddenly, and then he gave him a Guinea to buy him NeceÅ¿Å¿aries, and withal, bid him meet him at the Purl-HouÅ¿e in Hart-Å¿treet next Morning; and Bertram tells you, he had underÅ¿tood what this DeÅ¿ign was, for he had it before from Chernock, and did forbear to go the next Morning, becauÅ¿e he did diÅ¿like it. After this Mr. Lowick met him and chid him for diÅ¿appointing of him, in not meeting him as he directed, for Å¿ays he, it would have been the Å¿ame thing if the King had been in the Field: This is the Å¿um and Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Evidence that Bertram has given againÅ¿t him.

Now Bertram, being croÅ¿s-examined on the behalf of the PriÅ¿oner, Å¿ays he hath known him a great while, and that he is a Man of a peaceable and fair DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition, very charitable, and that he has given him Money before, and particulary a Guinea to his Wife in his abÅ¿ence.

Indeed I might have mentioned the Evidence of FiÅ¿her to you, but that is but circumÅ¿tantial, and does not come home to the CaÅ¿e, but being given it may be mention'd, and that is, about the Eighth of February, FiÅ¿her had Å¿ome DiÅ¿courÅ¿e with Lowick, and it Å¿eems there was notice taken of the intended InvaÅ¿ion, and Lowick Å¿aid he would Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter faithfully; and that the WitneÅ¿s thought was meant of the late King; and he Å¿aid at another time, that he would not diÅ¿courÅ¿e with above one at a time, becauÅ¿e of the late Act of Parliament that was then a paÅ¿Å¿ing, relating to High-TreaÅ¿on, that required two WitneÅ¿Å¿es. Now, I Å¿ay, this is not any Proof againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner, but it is a CircumÅ¿tance that may Å¿hew his Inclination to the late King.

The Council for the PriÅ¿oner have inÅ¿iÅ¿ted upon the InÅ¿ufficiency of the Evidence that has been given on behalf of the King, and have Å¿aid, that the late Act of Parliament requires two WitneÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿es, which is true, but not two WitneÅ¿Å¿es to any one Overt-Act; but if there be two WitneÅ¿Å¿es, one to one and another to another Overt-Act, that is Å¿ufficient; but they Å¿ay that it is not Å¿o in this CaÅ¿e. In the firÅ¿t place they object againÅ¿t the Evidence that is given by Harris, they Å¿ay it is Å¿hort, that muÅ¿t be left to your conÅ¿ideration; whether the Evidence that is given by Harris, concerning Mr. Lowick, does prove to your Å¿atisfaction, that he conÅ¿ented and agreed to the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination of the King, you are to weigh the Evidence, when it is Å¿worn that when Harris, Rookwood, and the PriÅ¿oner were walking in Red Lyon Fields, and talking of this horrid DeÅ¿ign, and Harris complained that it was a barbarous thing to murther the Prince of Orange, as they call'd him, you muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider what AnÅ¿wer Lowick did make about obeying of Orders, then his Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿ting of Men at his own charge without Pay, and complaining of his having no Pay, and his diÅ¿charging them the laÅ¿t day that the AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination was intended, that I muÅ¿t leave to you, whether or no this is not an Evidence, if you believe the WitneÅ¿s, to Å¿atisfie you that he was engaged in this DeÅ¿ign.

Then Gentlemen he has alÅ¿o been deÅ¿ired to give an AnÅ¿wer to this QueÅ¿tion, and to tell upon what DeÅ¿ign he was to employ Bertram that Å¿hould be for his advantage; but he was to ask no QueÅ¿tions, and afterwards whether he did tell him the King was to be Å¿eized in his Coach, and they were to ride out Å¿uddenly and bid him meet him the next Morning, and when he did not meet him, he Å¿aid it would have been the Å¿ame thing if the King had been in the Field. If this be an Evidence of Mr. Lowick's engaging in and agreeing and conÅ¿enting to the DeÅ¿ign, then here will be another WitneÅ¿s againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner beÅ¿ides Harris.

Gentlemen, you are to judge of this matter and of the Evidence. It is true, we are not to put, in the caÅ¿e of a Mans Life, any forced and violent ConÅ¿tructions upon any Words or DiÅ¿courÅ¿es; but if the Evidence be plain and clear, tho he did not Å¿ay in expreÅ¿s Words, that he did deÅ¿ign to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate or kill the King; yet, if upon the whole DiÅ¿courÅ¿e that paÅ¿t between them it appears plainly, clearly, and Å¿atisfactorily to you that he did conÅ¿ent and agree to this DeÅ¿ign, or was engaged in it, here's another WitneÅ¿s, I Å¿ay, to prove him guilty, beÅ¿ides Harris, you are to conÅ¿ider the whole Evidence, the Å¿ubject matter of DiÅ¿courÅ¿e, and if you are Å¿atisfied, I Å¿ay, that he was engaged in Å¿uch a DeÅ¿ign by the Proof of Bertram, as well as of Harris, then there are two WitneÅ¿Å¿es, which is as much as the Law requires.

But, indeed, the Council have called Å¿everal WitneÅ¿Å¿es to prove that the PriÅ¿oner has lived very peaceably and quietly; one Woman Å¿ays Å¿he has known him Twelve Years, and that he lodged at her HouÅ¿e, and that he was a Man of great Temper and Candor, and not diÅ¿orderly, but had a general good EÅ¿teem and Character: And then there is another, Mrs. MoÅ¿ely, that proves the like, and Å¿ays, Å¿he has known him theÅ¿e Twenty Years, and Å¿he Å¿ays no Man has a better Character: And Mr. Bertram hath Å¿aid that he was not of a raÅ¿h or bloody Temper.

Now Gentlemen, I muÅ¿t leave it to you upon the Evidence that you have heard, there are theÅ¿e WitneÅ¿Å¿es that have been produced, and there are theÅ¿e CircumÅ¿tances that appear in the CaÅ¿e; if you are Å¿atisfied upon this Evidence that has been given, that the PriÅ¿oner Mr. Lowick, did conÅ¿ent to and engage himÅ¿elf in that DeÅ¿ign of aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inating the King, then you are to find him guilty; if you are not Å¿atisfied, you are to find him not guilty; you have heard your Evidence, and had beÅ¿t conÅ¿ider of it.

div.p: Then an Officer was Å¿worn to keep the Jury, who withdrew, and Å¿taid out about half an hour, and then returned.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Jury anÅ¿wer to your Names. George Ford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ford.
sp.p: Here, &c. And Å¿o of the reÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Are you all agreed of your Verdict?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Who Å¿hall Å¿ay for you?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Foreman.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Robert Lowick, hold up thy hand. (Which he did) Look upon the PriÅ¿oner, how Å¿ay you? Is he guilty of the High-TreaÅ¿on whereof he Å¿tands indicted or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: What Goods or Chattels, Lands or Tenements had he at the time of the TreaÅ¿on committed, or at any time Å¿ince?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: None, to our knowledge, we do not find any.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Then hearken to your Verdict, as the Court hath recorded it. You Å¿ay that Robert Lowick is guilty of the High-TreaÅ¿on whereof he Å¿tands indicted, but that he had no Goods, Chattels, Lands or Tenements at the time of the High-TreaÅ¿on committed, or at any time Å¿ince to your knowledge, and Å¿o you Å¿ay all.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: DiÅ¿charge the Jury.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Jury, the Court diÅ¿charges you, and thanks you for your Å¿ervice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Mr. Attorny, Will you have the PriÅ¿oners Å¿et to the Bar?

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor.
sp.p: Yes, if your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿e.

div.p: Then the Keeper of Newgate brought Rookwood and Cranburn, and all three were Å¿et to the Bar.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: If your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿e to give Judgment againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oners that are convicted.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Ask them what they have to Å¿ay for themÅ¿elves in arreÅ¿t of Judgment.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Robert Lowick, hold up thy Hand; you Å¿tand convicted of High-TreaÅ¿on, in conÅ¿piring the Death of the King by AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, what can you Å¿ay for your Å¿elf why the Court Å¿hould not give Judgment againÅ¿t you, to die according to Law.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: No, no, he need not kneel; if you have any thing to Å¿ay, Mr. Lowick, we will hear you.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: I throw my Å¿elf upon the Kings Mercy.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, hold up thy hand, (which he did) you Å¿tand convicted of the Å¿ame High-TreaÅ¿on, for conÅ¿piring the Death of the King by AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, what can you Å¿ay for your Å¿elf why the Court Å¿hould not give you Judgment to die according to the Law.

sp.speaker: Rookwood.
sp.p: All that can be Å¿aid has been Å¿aid already, and Å¿o I Å¿hall Å¿ay no more.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Charles Cranburn, hold up thy Hand, thou Å¿tandeÅ¿t convicted of High-TreaÅ¿on, in conÅ¿piring the Death of the King by AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ination, what canÅ¿t thou Å¿ay for thy Å¿elf, why the Court Å¿hould not give the Judgment to die according to Law?

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I have nothing to Å¿ay but what I have Å¿aid already.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Then Cryer make Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: O, yes, all manner of PerÅ¿ons are commanded to keep Å¿ilence while Judgment is in giving, upon pain of ImpriÅ¿onment.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: You the PriÅ¿oners at the Bar, Robert Lowick, AmbroÅ¿e Rookwood, and Charles Cranburn, you have been indicted, and upon full and clear Evidence have been convicted of High-TreaÅ¿on; a TreaÅ¿on that was advanc'd to the higheÅ¿t degree both of Malice and MiÅ¿chief againÅ¿t the King and Kingdom; you deÅ¿ign'd to aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inate the King with an intent to Å¿ubvert the State, and by the introducing of a foreign Power to deÅ¿troy the antient Liberty and ConÅ¿titution of England.

Our French and PopiÅ¿h Enemies, by whom you were imployed in this bloody EnterpriÅ¿e, did very well know, that the WiÅ¿dom and Courage of his preÅ¿ent MajeÅ¿ty has reÅ¿cued this Kingdom from that Slavery and OppreÅ¿Å¿ion which they often threatened to bring upon us; they knew that under his Government we have been protected in the enjoyment of our Religion, Laws and Liberty for Å¿everal Years, and that his MajeÅ¿ty is the Head of the ProteÅ¿tant IntereÅ¿t, and the Protector and PreÅ¿erver of the Liberty of Europe, and that upon the PreÅ¿ervation of his Life and the Safety of his PerÅ¿on, the Good and HappineÅ¿s of multitudes of People do depend, which the French King's Pride and Ambition has been ready to take hold of any opportunity to enÅ¿lave and oppreÅ¿s.

Your being engaged in Å¿uch a horrid DeÅ¿ign againÅ¿t Å¿o precious a Life, and to be the bloody InÅ¿truments to give that diÅ¿mal Stroke, which would have brought MiÅ¿try and DeÅ¿olation upon Å¿o many Men, renders you worthy to undergo a greater and more Å¿evere PuniÅ¿hment than by the Law of England can be inflicted; but that there is no greater provided for Å¿uch Criminals, is to be imputed to the antient HoneÅ¿ty and Integrity of EngliÅ¿h Men, who, when they fram'd this ConÅ¿titution of Government, never imagin'd England Å¿hould produce Å¿uch degenerate Wretches, as would endeavour by Plots and Contrivances to betray their Country to a foreign Yoak, and Å¿ubject themÅ¿elves and their Fellow-Subjects to the Å¿laviÅ¿h Dominion of Strangers.

Your Crime being Å¿o great it is now high time for you Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to reflect upon it; and tho you deÅ¿erve to Å¿uffer the greateÅ¿t of PuniÅ¿hments, yet I have that CompaÅ¿Å¿ion for your PerÅ¿ons, that I wiÅ¿h heartily you would make uÅ¿e of that Opportunity which is now put into your Hands, to repent. And Å¿ince you are adjudg'd by the Law unworthy to live here, that you will make preparation to appear at another Tribunal, where you muÅ¿t have another Tryal, and without an hearty and Å¿incere Repentance, receive a more Å¿evere Sentence. I hope this Calamity, and the Judgment that is to fall upon you, will be an Admonition to you to take better advice in the laÅ¿t part of your time which is left you, than you have done in the whole courÅ¿e of your Lives, and that you will be wiÅ¿er than to follow the Direction of thoÅ¿e Guides whoÅ¿e Principles and Doctrines have Å¿o far perverted and corrupted you, as to engage you in Å¿uch a bloody DeÅ¿ign. I Å¿hall leave you to make that Preparation for another World, which is proper for Men in your condition, and pronounce the Judgment of the Court, which the Law hath appointed and the Court does award;

p.hi: That all of you be conveyed from hence to the PriÅ¿on from whence you came, and from thence every one of you is to be drawn upon a Hurdle to the place of Execution, where you are to be hanged by your Necks, and to be cut down while you are alive, your Privy Members are to be cut off, and your Bowels to be cut out of your Bodies and burnt in your view, your Heads are to be cut off, and your Bodies to be divided into four parts, and your Heads and Quarters are to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed where his MajeÅ¿ty Å¿hall appoint. And I pray God to have Mercy on all your Souls.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: I humbly deÅ¿ire the liberty of my Wife and Relations to come to me, and Å¿uch Divines as I Å¿hall deÅ¿ire may have free recourÅ¿e to me.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: You Å¿hall have that liberty that is allowed to all PerÅ¿ons in your condition.

sp.speaker: Rookwood.
sp.p: I muÅ¿t beg the Å¿ame Favour, to have Å¿ome few Friends and Relations come to Å¿ee me without a Keeper.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: You Å¿hall have a Warrant for your Friends to come to you.

sp.speaker: Rookwood.
sp.p: I beg your LordÅ¿hip that you would pleaÅ¿e to Å¿pecifie it in the Warrant, becauÅ¿e they would not grant hitherto without a Keeper being by.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: You mean, you would have your Brother permitted to come to you.

sp.speaker: Rookwood.
sp.p: Yes, and Å¿ome few Relations.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: What is uÅ¿ually done in Å¿uch CaÅ¿es let it be done.

sp.speaker: Lowick.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire the Å¿ame thing, that my SiÅ¿ter may come to me, and that the little time I have I may be private with my Friends.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: If your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿e, they may give the Names of thoÅ¿e they would have admitted to them, and then the Keeper will attend your LordÅ¿hip for your Direction.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: That the Keeper muÅ¿t take care of, leÅ¿t they allow Å¿uch a Liberty as may indanger an EÅ¿cape; for their being alone may prove a dangerous thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It is reaÅ¿onable they Å¿hould tell who they are, before they be admitted.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: You allow them, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e, to have private DiÅ¿courÅ¿e in the Å¿ame Room, if a Keeper be by.

sp.speaker: Cranburn.
sp.p: No, my Lord, we never had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Such as your LordÅ¿hip thinks proper to be admitted to them may have DiÅ¿courÅ¿e with them in private, if the Keeper be in the Room, but no others but Å¿uch as your LordÅ¿hip Å¿hall allow; for we know what has been the effect of a Liberty of acceÅ¿s to Å¿ome PriÅ¿oners.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J. Holt.
sp.p: Let us have a Note of thoÅ¿e Names that you would have come to you, and we will give Directions that Å¿hall be proper in it.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: Sheriff of MiddleÅ¿ex, you muÅ¿t take them into your cuÅ¿tody till Execution is done.

div.p: Then the Keeper took away the PriÅ¿oners, and the Court adjourned the CommiÅ¿Å¿ion of Oyer and Terminer to Hicks's Hall, at Three of the Clock that Afternoon.
